DEBATE.TITLE: INSURANCE LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1991[COGNATE BILLS:INSURANCE ACQUISITIONS AND TAKEOVERS BILL 1991LIFE INSURANCE POLICY HOLDERS' PROTECTION LEVIES BILL 1991LIFE INSURANCE POLICY HOLDERS' PROTECTION LEVIES COLLECTION BILL 1991LIFE INSURANCE SUPERVISORY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1991GENERAL INSURANCE SUPERVISORY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1991]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 June, on motion by Mr Free:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the House to debate the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1991 concurrently with the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill 1991, the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Bill 1991, the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Bill 1991, the Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1991 and the General Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1991? If there is no objection, I will allow that course of action to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the House is a package of six Bills-the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill, the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill, the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Bill, the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Bill, the Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill and the General Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

``the House is of the opinion that the Bill should not be proceeded with until the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration conducts a thorough inquiry into, and reports on:

(a) the regulatory and prudential requirements necessary to ensure that life and general insurance funds are operated so as to maximize returns to policy holders and protect their investments, and on proposals to achieve the same and the costs and benefits of such; and

(b) the costs likely to be borne by policyholders in funds levied under the associated levy proposals, the benefits to policy holders in funds receiving the benefit of the levy and the general desirability of the proposed levy''.

There is no doubt that superannuation is assuming greater importance in the national financial structure of Australia. Superannuation is to be encouraged. If people are able to provide for their own retirement they have the opportunity to provide for themselves a better standard of living in their retirement. This has commensurate benefits to the national accounts. If people provide for their own retirement this will, in due course, lessen the costs to the revenue in terms of aged pensions.

This is a matter of dramatic importance in Australia as the proportion of our population ages, as proportionately more people go on to the aged pension or go into retirement compared with those who are in active working life and paying taxes. It is of vital importance in this country that people are encouraged to take up superannuation arrangements. It is estimated that, as at December 1990, $125 billion will be invested in superannuation funds. The former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), has estimated that there could be as much as $600 billion by the year 2000.

If we are to encourage people to provide for their own retirement and take up the option of superannuation, one thing we need to do above all else is ensure that there are stable rules which govern superannuation and life insurance-rules that are laid down in advance that people know about so that they can make their own decisions when taking out policies and investing in superannuation. There need to be rules that have certainty. People who invest today need to know that the rules that apply to the benefit they are going to receive in 20 or 30 years time-maybe more-will still be applicable.

People need to be able to make informed decisions in the knowledge that the rules will be stable and will guarantee the integrity of the decision making process. They need to know that they have the opportunity to choose a good investment rather than a bad investment. They need to know that they will be protected against fraudulent activity which may rob them of their lifetime insurance or lifetime superannuation. They need to know that there will be rules which will maximise returns to them and provide the best possible benefits to them in their retirement. They also need to know that their assets will not run the risk of dissipation by reason of fraud or fraudulent conduct of one kind or another.

It is vitally important that this Parliament gets it right-that it gets it right by establishing long term stable rules for the benefit of policyholders and also for the benefit of those administering the funds. The people administering the funds need to be able, in the best way possible, to look after the interests of their policyholders.

In this respect, the Government has dragged its heels. The Government has not paid sufficient attention over the last couple of years to ensuring a proper prudential and supervisory regime in relation to the life insurance and superannuation industry. The Government has not paid enough attention to protecting the interests of investors.

This package comes forward today not because the Government has been carefully and in a measured way trying to put into place that framework, as it should have been doing over the last eight years of its term of office, but because of what can only be described as a scandal in the life insurance and superannuation industry. Make no mistake about it, this package of Bills has come forward now in response to a specific crisis in relation to Occidental Life and Regal Life funds.

As is common knowledge and as has been reported widely in the press, the Battery Group was to settle the sale of two life insurance companies-Occidental Life and Regal Life-in September of last year. An amount of $65m was to be paid as a deposit for the purchase of the funds on that day. The $65m was in fact paid. The Battery Group upstreamed that in reduction of its liabilities to the Commonwealth Bank, which received the sum of approximately $57m. The ANZ Bank received the sum of approximately $8m. It now appears, however, that the $65m deposit to be paid by the purchaser of the funds came out of the funds themselves. The assets of the purchase were used for the purchase transaction. This has left those statutory funds short to the tune of $65m.

Litigation is currently proceeding to unravel liability in relation to that. I do not comment on what the outcome of that litigation may be. But litigation has been commenced against those who may have had an involvement in this transaction and against the financial institutions through which the transfers were arranged. For my part-and I believe for the part of the Government and members of the Opposition as well-I hope that these proceedings result in an outcome which will protect the interests of those who had their savings in the Occidental and Regal groups.

We have profound sympathy for those who had invested in the Occidental and Regal groups, those who had placed their savings in those funds, those who now run the risk of not having those entitlements paid out because of conduct which appears, on the face of it, to be fraudulent. We hope that as a result of that litigation those moneys can be returned and those investors can be protected.

I should make it clear that the $65m has not disappeared. It has not been taken by a fly-by-night character who has removed it from the jurisdiction. The $65m is still there. It is held by the Commonwealth Bank and the ANZ Bank-admittedly in reduction of liabilities that were owed to those banks by the Battery Group, but the money is there. I have always thought that there was a simple solution to this problem; that is, if the transactions were reversed, the $65m would come back to Occidental and Regal, the liability of the Battery Group to those banks would stand, and nobody would be in a worse position than they were when this transaction took place.

I do not suggest for a moment that the banks have no right to keep that money. Under principles of law, they do. But there is a way out of this impasse that would leave nobody in a worse position than they were as at 27 September 1990. I do not know what the Government has done to investigate that possibility. The former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland, was questioned about this in the Parliament, but he took the view that it was no responsibility of his to try to have those funds returned. In fact, when the former Treasurer was questioned in this Parliament back in November 1990 he was adamant that there was no need to return the funds because the whole thing would be fixed up by a voluntary levy on other life insurance companies.

I questioned the Treasurer on whether the other funds had voluntarily decided to levy themselves to make good this loss or whether they had been coerced into it by the threat of legislation. The Treasurer was adamant that there had been no threat of legislation against the life offices at that stage. They had voluntarily come forward to impose this levy upon themselves to fix up the problem. He said on 7 November that the life offices understood the gravity of this position, that the life offices spent a lot of time and gave a lot of attention to them, and that they saw the importance to their industry. The Treasurer said:
. . . it did not require any . . . pressure or arm twisting from the Government to bring the major life funds into this issue. They brought themselves into it.

Again, on 12 November the Treasurer was asked whether the life offices had been told about possible legislation. `Not that I am aware of', said the Treasurer. The matter was again revisited in a second question on 12 November 1990.

One can imagine our surprise, having had those assurances from the then Treasurer that there had been no spectre or threat of legislation, to see legislation actually introduced into this House to levy the funds to make up the shortfall in Occidental and Regal Life. One can imagine our surprise when this package of Bills came forward. Make no mistake about it: although it is a package, and only two of the six Bills refer to a levy, this package has been brought forward by those events in relation to Occidental and Regal.

There has been a report made on the whole transaction surrounding the Occidental and Regal saga by Mr R. Grellman, who took office as a judicial administrator of the funds. To my knowledge, that report has not been tabled in the Parliament, and I am surprised at that. There was no reference to it during the Minister's second reading speeches; no attention seems to have been paid to the recommendations that were made; and one cannot help getting the feeling that the Government, by reason of the levy which it now proposes, would like to sweep this sad and sorry saga under the carpet.

Mr Grellman reported that he thought there should be an examination pursuant to section 597 of the Corporations Act. He was concerned about the transactions regarding the sale. He said all transactions exhibit the common feature that the company is not presently in possession of sufficiently complete information to ensure protection of the interests of policyholders. He was scathing in his report as to the way in which these funds had been administered. This raises the spectre either that the regulators were not performing properly or that the legislation was not sufficient to allow them to perform properly.

We have not seen any statement of concern or, indeed, any interest from this Government about those particular issues. There is no reference at all to the Grellman report in this package of legislation. The Government ought to come in here, table the Grellman report, state quite clearly who it considers to be responsible, state quite clearly what it intends to do about sheeting home liability to those responsible, and state quite clearly that it will give every support to the regulatory authorities-the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, the Australian Securities Commission and other regulatory authorities-who have a responsibility in this area to investigate and to bring to justice those who are responsible. Its failure to do so is a major shortcoming in relation to those Occidental Life and Regal Life investors, who at the moment are $65m short. Those who are responsible ought to be brought to justice and the Government ought to concentrate and focus its mind very clearly on bringing to justice those who were involved. It owes that to the Occidental and Regal policyholders-and not just to them; it owes that to the community. After all, the Government is charged with administering the law. It owes it to the community to ensure that those responsible are brought to justice.

I have this worrying, disturbing, nagging feeling that the Government would like to see this problem go away rather than engage in the very hard work of identifying where it went wrong and what its responsibility was and rather than indicate quite clearly what it intends to do about it.

The Opposition has deep and pressing concerns about the proposal for the levy in this legislation. What is proposed is that the Parliament will enact legislation enabling life and superannuation companies to be levied up to $65m to provide a fund which could be drawn down by those administering the Occidental and Regal funds to make good the shortfall. As I understand it, there is provision in the Bill for those moneys to be repaid in the event of the litigation proving successful and the $65m coming back through the law into the funds themselves. But there are a lot of questions about this levy that is proposed in relation to life and superannuation companies.

First of all, if $65m is drawn from the other life and superannuation companies, what is the effect of that on those policyholders? Does this mean that policyholders in other funds are going to be $65m poorer; that they are going to see the dissipation of some of their own investments to cover this particular fraud? What is the effect in dollar terms of this particular levy? Secondly, what is the value of this levy to those who have policies in Occidental Life and Regal Life? Will it enable them to get 100c in the dollar? How much will it cover?

I take great heart from the fact that the levy is not supposed to cover bad investment decisions; and, as we know, there have been bad investment decisions in Occidental Life and Regal Life which may have created a liability even in excess of the loss of the fraud. How much; how far will the $65m go in protecting those particular policyholders? We need to know what the costs are; we need to know what the benefits are; we need on the public record a statement by the other life and superannuation companies as to what their attitude is-whether they consider this a proper discharge of the obligations they owe to their policyholders; whether they consider it is in the interests of their policyholders; how it is going to affect their policyholders. Policyholders in the AMP and the National Mutual and other funds have a right to know what the effect of this particular legislation is going to be upon their investment.

We have recommended that this legislation go off to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, so that the Committee can investigate it, take evidence and get on the public record the attitude of the other funds and the attitude of the judicial administrator.

Let me make it clear: we do not for a moment want to hold up this proposal. We want to know whether the proposal is a good one. If the evidence is taken, and it appears from the public evidence that it is a good proposal, then there is a warrant for the Parliament proceeding, but at the moment it is being asked to punt in the dark. We do not think we should treat the policyholders, in the funds which would be levied, with such disregard. We think that the Parliament ought to show an interest in their views before it legislates in this matter. That is why I urge the Government to support our move to refer this legislation to the House of Representatives Standing Committee.

The second part of the package concerns acquisitions and takeovers in relation to the insurance industry generally. This Bill will provide for a control over the acquisition of assets or shares in insurance companies. The Bill is quite extensive and it confers very wide powers upon the Minister. It provides that there is to be a trigger point of 15 per cent, where a person is to increase his control by 15 per cent in relation to shares and assets. That has to be notified. The Minister can give a temporary stay order, or a permanent one, on various grounds.

I do not for a moment want to criticise the drafting of this particular legislation, because it is a complicated area, but the provisions are very complex. We believe that they warrant investigation in order to see how they will work and whether they will work. For example, the Minister will have the power to grant a permanent restraining order if satisfied that the change in ownership of shares or assets is contrary to the public interest.

Section 5 of the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill 1991 tells us what is deemed to be contrary to the public interest. Something is deemed to be contrary to the public interest if, for example, it is `likely to result in an unsuitable person being in a position of influence over the company'. What does that mean? What does it mean when it says, `an unsuitable person being in a position of influence'? What does it mean when it says that the person is unsuitable? We should remember that this is at the Minister's discretion. What does it mean when it says `a position of influence'?

Another ground on which an acquisition can be prevented is where it is likely to unduly concentrate economic power in the Australian general insurance industry. What does that mean? What is the threshold test? How is the Minister going to decide it? I know the Minister can lay down principles, but how is he going to decide what those principles should be? This is very wide legislation. How does it mesh with other controls over the insurance industry? For example, there was a proposed merger between the ANZ Bank and National Mutual. The then Treasurer intervened to stop that, not under this particular legislation, but under his control of the banking industry.

How will these proposals sit with controls over the banking industry? How will these proposals sit with controls in the Trade Practices Act, which also has another test of mergers and acquisitions? There is also a provision in the legislation for the Minister to stop an acquisition if it is contrary to the national interest. What does `contrary to the national interest' mean? That could mean absolutely anything. I do not criticise the drafting of the legislation, because the draftsmen have, no doubt, acted on the instructions that were given to them, but it is poorly thought through. This shows all the signs of a knee-jerk reaction to this crisis in Occidental and Regal.

We do not know whether it will work well-or whether it will work at all-how it will mesh in with other provisions and what it will mean in practice. The Government cannot give us any answers to those questions because, if it is honest, it does not know either. That is why we say the matter should go off to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. That Committee has done an inquiry into the banking industry, and it is looking at supervision and prudential controls in that industry. It can in the course of that inquiry look at supervision and prudential controls in the insurance industry.

We ought to make a determined effort to get these rules right, to mesh them well together, to make them comprehensive and to lay them down in a thoughtful way rather than in a knee-jerk way. The Insurance Laws Amendment Bill deals with prudential controls. That too should be examined. The supervisory levies, which increase the amount that insurance and life insurance companies pay for supervision, can be examined. We need to know how much this will cost; how much will be recovered by way of the supervisory levies; whether the levies, as set, are adequate or whether they are too high; what the cost will be; and what the level of recovery for this supervision will be.

All the facts point to the result that we should have a thorough inquiry into these proposals. If the Minister wants to say that the Finance and Public Administration Committee is the wrong committee or that it is too busy, we will accept that, but he should put a proposal as to what committee can carry out an inquiry. We would even support the Minister if he wanted to have a select committee of people who perhaps are not so busy as those on the Finance and Public Administration Committee. I see the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) there; he might volunteer for that committee. No doubt he would have some interesting views on this. How will we mesh this and how will we put it all together? These are the questions that desperately need to be answered.

Yesterday's Budget outlined proposals for increasing taxes on employers who do not pay superannuation, designed to force superannuation from employers and produce more funds for superannuation investments over the future. Obviously the Government is very concerned about the level of prudential supervision that will be conducted in relation to the moneys that will be raised. The Government ought to be very concerned about its proposal because the proposal is misguided; but, given that the proposal will go ahead as a Budget measure, this Government being the current government, it is concerned about prudential controls.

I was astounded that yesterday, as part of the Budget release, we had a statement by the Treasurer on prudential supervision of the superannuation industry. The Government says that it does not believe it can, or should, attempt to guarantee funds. I think that it is going down the right track there. It goes on to say that we should minimise risks and that there should be adequate legislative sanctions. We have common law controls on trustees, we have the corporations law control on trustees, we have the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, and we have the Trade Practices Act. Where is the thought about meshing all of those into a coherent platform?

The Government itself does not believe the package is right, because riddled through this statement are announcements about further investigations the Government has to make. On page 2 of paper No. 1 attached to the statement on prudential supervision of the superannuation industry, it says:

In addition, while prudential policies should lessen the risk of fraudulent or criminal behaviour, action to remedy such behaviour must ultimately be addressed by law enforcement agencies rather than prudential supervisors.

That is what the Government said yesterday: law enforcement agencies should protect against fraudulent or criminal behaviour. Today there is no proposal for a law enforcement agency to do anything about Occidental and Regal Life, but there is a proposal for a supervisory levy. The Government's own statement of yesterday conflicts with the thrust of its legislation today. Paper No. 1 goes on to say:
There is a need to ensure that the prudential framework for the superannuation industry is appropriate . . .
There is a need to ensure that. The Government says it will look at that. On page 5 the document says:
The Government proposes to develop a prudential framework which fosters rather than inhibits competitiveness . . .

Of course the Government ought to be developing a prudential framework to foster competitiveness. Yesterday's statement said, `We are proposing to develop it'-so let us do it. The Government will get our help. Why would the Government proceed with this legislation when it is saying in its Budget statement that there is a lot of work to be done-`We are proposing to develop it.'? In its statement of yesterday the Government is not saying, `It is already done; it is here in this package': it is saying, `We are still proposing to do it; it is yet to come; there is more work to be done'. Of course there is more work to be done. That is why these Bills are not adequate at the moment and should be referred for further discussion. The statement goes on:
The Government is examining improved and more direct enforcement powers . . .

It is still examining more direct and improved enforcement powers. If the Government is examining them, why do we not send this proposal to a committee and examine them? Why pass legislation here when the Government admits that it is still working on a package? This is half-baked and the Government runs the very real risk of getting it wrong. We know we are going to have to come back here anyway, so why do we not get it right? The statement continues:
The Government is also considering possible measures to control entry to the superannuation industry.
The Government is currently examining the possibility of requiring superannuation funds and institutions . . . to be subject to additional solvency.

The whole of the Government's statement of yesterday contradicts the thrust of this legislation. Anyone who gives adequate thought to this will know that this package is not sufficient. The Government does not even know whether it is necessary. It has real problems in the area and it ought to cooperate with the Opposition to get the whole supervisory framework right.

The Government ought to support our calls to get it right from the outset in a measured and considered way, rather than react in a knee-jerk way with the real and present risk of creating major problems down the track in relation not only to prudential and supervisory requirements but also indemnity against fraud. This package is not ready for passing by this Parliament and it ought to be referred to a House committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether I should be standing on this side of the House to respond to this debate, having heard the impassioned pleas by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) about referring this package of legislation to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which I chair.
—You are attracted to the idea.

—I am attracted to the idea that at last recognition has been given to the role played by parliamentary committees in looking at legislation and a range of issues that come before this place, and that at last there is recognition that backbenchers in this place-people from both sides of the Parliament-can develop an area of expertise and that they can bring that area of expertise to bear onto legislative requirements and legislation that has been introduced into this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I am attracted also to the suggestion by the honourable member and shadow spokesman that in this area of insurance and prudential supervision it is the committee which I have the privilege to chair that has developed the expertise and the fundamental responsibility for looking at issues. To that extent, I find that I do have a degree of sympathy with the view that he has put. But I would like to go to some of the issues that he has raised and then we may see that the options associated with that are not necessarily closed off by the work that is being done at present.

The heart of what was being suggested to us this morning by the honourable member for Higgins was that there was a need to ensure that the prudential supervisory regime is put in place not only for the insurance Bills that we are debating but also for superannuation. I take it a step further in terms of the role being played by the banking industry in this country. We can extend it into the financial sector of the Australian economy, because over the past several months, during our inquiry into the Australian banking industry, we have taken a great deal of evidence, and I have spoken on a number of occasions in different forums, about the need to enhance prudential supervision in this country.

I have taken it upon myself to raise a few issues in public forums to see the sort of response that I would get. I think it is worth spending a bit of time on that particular issue now. As it stands at the moment, in this country essentially three levels of supervision exist. The Reserve Bank of Australia is charged with the responsibility of supervising banks as defined by the Banking Act. In that way, it takes into consideration the four major banks, the foreign banks that are operating in this country and also, by an arrangement, the State banks. The Reserve Bank therefore has the role of looking after the prudential supervisory requirements of those organisations. It imposes capital adequacy ratios; it requires information to be made available so that on a day-to-day basis it can supervise the banks of this country in such a way that people can sleep well at night knowing that their money basically is safe.

At the second level, we have the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. It is that body which is directly responsible for the supervision of insurance and superannuation, to which the honourable member for Higgins was referring to in his contribution today. In the legislation before this House, we are seeing changes in the solvency ratios for both life insurance and general insurance. Therefore, we are seeing the ante being upped in terms of prudential guidelines in reference to insurance.

As pointed out yesterday by the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) in his Budget speech, we are also seeing the Government flagging that there are to be changes in superannuation prudential supervision as well. Therefore, the responsible body-the Insurance and Superannuation Commission-which will take the role of supervising and ensuring that the guidelines are adhered to by life insurance companies, general insurance companies, superannuation funds and the like-will have those guidelines in place as a result of the measures we are debating in this package of legislation and in the measures which will come forward in the future.

At the third level, we have this new body called AFIC that has been developed. AFIC is going to be a body responsible for looking after building societies, credit unions and friendly societies. Again it will put in place general guidelines and prudential supervisory regimes but with the proviso, of course, that State governments, which have the responsibility for administering prudential supervision of those particular bodies, will have to pass legislation at the State level to set those guidelines in legislative form. It would be responsible for having a supervisor, whether it be in a Ministry for Consumer Affairs, Ministry for Housing or whatever it might be, responsible for the day-to-day supervision of those forms of financial institutions in this country.

That sounds all well and good. In fact, it is the Treasury and Reserve Bank line that that is what we should have in this country. It is the line that has been put to our inquiry, to which the honourable member for Higgins would rather see these Bills also directed at this point in time for further examination. It is the line seen in the Budget statement which came down yesterday with its reference to changes to superannuation prudential supervision. It is interesting that it would come down at this time because another issue-the honourable member for Higgins touched on this and it is directly related to this-is the plethora of supervisory bodies that have been established. As I have mentioned, there are three bodies that are directly responsible, but then there are a whole range of others that are associated as well, particularly when one starts looking at the fraudulent area: the Cash Transaction Report Agency and all the rest that have been established over time.

As we go down this path in Australia at the moment of financial conglomeration taking place, with banks tying themselves to life and general insurance companies and getting involved with superannuation funds and so on, because at the end of the day we might see some over-arching financial conglomeration being at the base and at the heart of what the Australian finance industry is going to resemble- one has to question whether we in fact need so many of those supervisory bodies.

I throw that up again because it is an issue which our Committee is giving consideration to as we prepare our report on the Australian banking industry for tabling in Parliament in November. Whilst some people might criticise us and suggest we have gone outside our terms of reference and that we are, after all, only supposed to be looking at banking, I can say now that with the growth of superannuation and life insurance there is the need to bring these supervisory and prudential standards into play through legislation today, and as has been targeted by the Treasurer in the statement that he released yesterday as part of the Budget, because the banks and the financial intermediaries in this country are becoming more blurred. Financial conglomeration is a fact of life not only here but also in Europe, the United States, Canada and everywhere else. We have to be prepared for it.

I go to another point, one on which I do agree to some extent with the honourable member for Higgins. It is well and good for us to look now, with the benefit of 20-20 hindsight and of knowledge of what has happened in the past, and to suggest the sorts of things that we need to put in place now. We can all do that. But we must also have a little bit of forward thinking, a little bit of vision. If we are to see this relationship between financial institutions in this country becoming more and more a real part of financial Australia, we have to be sure that the regulators are performing properly, that the regulators have the guidelines in place to meet the needs of and to protect the deposits of those people who choose to put their money into banks, superannuation funds, insurance or whatever it happens to be. We must be satisfied that the Government does have the appropriate mechanisms in place to meet those needs.

I am sorry that the honourable member for Higgins has left the chamber. I am convinced that as far as insurance is concerned, by increasing the requirements associated with the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1991 in respect of solvency and minimum capital requirements and so on, we are meeting some of those needs. By boosting the actual level of solvency required in each of the insurance companies and so on, we are taking the appropriate steps to see that fly-by-nighters will not simply come into the marketplace, rip people off and then disappear, thereby creating the same problem as has been identified with Occidental Life and Regal Life. There must be a legitimate business, it must have legitimate solvency ratios and it must have legitimate capital ratios and capital adequacy before there can be a start. That is appropriate to meet the needs of the 1990s and beyond. This legislation does that.

I return to the concern I have about the whole question of supervision, the whole question of the blurring of financial conglomerates in this country. I come to the point about whether perhaps a megasupervisor is required to look after all those things. That is an issue which our Committee will examine. It is an issue that we have talked about to date. We will come to a conclusion about it and we will possibly make a recommendation to this Parliament about it, based on the evidence we have now.

In reference again to the Opposition's amendment, which seeks to send to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration this whole package of Bills for re-examination, I might say that our Committee has been looking at the banking industry, at financial conglomeration, at the role played by banks in getting into superannuation and life insurance, which these Bills are concerned with, since October last year. We are in the last three months of our inquiry, the last three months of examination before bringing down a report in this Parliament. It is a bit late in the day for those on the Opposition side to now raise their concerns in this Parliament and to say, `Let's stop the legislation going through; let's hive it off to that Committee because it is examining these sorts of issues'. We have been doing it all along.

I might just say to the honourable member for Higgins that the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), who is Deputy Chairman of our Committee and who sits on the Opposition side of the Parliament, has been raising these issues in public hearings. He has been raising these issues with the banks and with superannuation fund managers and a range of other people.

The option the honourable member for Higgins would like-namely, examining these sorts of issues, such as the regulatory and prudential requirements necessary to ensure that life and general insurance funds are operated so as to maximise returns to policy holders and protect their investments and so on-may still happen even after we table this report. One of the recommendations that might come forward, which we are toying with at present and on which we will be gathering evidence next week in the United States and Canada, is the issue of whether, because of the important role played by financial institutions in this country-be they banks, building societies, credit unions, superannuation funds, et cetera-there is now a need, as in the United States and Canadian parliaments, to have a permanent banking and finance committee established.

Had there been such a committee, this package of Bills might, if the Minister so determined, have had the opportunity to examine the implications of what was being proposed. Given the level of expertise now being developed by backbench members of this Parliament who have taken the time and effort to read submissions and all the information that is around on issues such as superannuation, banking, life insurance and their interrelationships and so on, they should be given the opportunity to examine these sorts of issues. That may be something that will come out of our committee inquiry.

It will not be too late-as has been suggested by the honourable member for Higgins-to look at some of the things that are necessary in relation to superannuation as announced by the Treasurer yesterday. They are still under consideration. We are still looking at the way in which things need to be done. It is still possible to achieve that aim, not necessarily now but a little later on, and it is probably desirable that that be the case.

One or two other issues were also raised by the honourable member for Higgins in his presentation this morning on behalf of the Opposition. I refer particularly to the acquisition and takeovers legislation that we are dealing with here in respect of insurance companies. The 15 per cent rule is in place. We have already seen that the Treasurer has had reason in the past to look at that rule very carefully. Again, it is in reference to banks and relationships established between banks and life companies over the last 18 months or so. Honourable members will remember that there was a proposal for a merger between the ANZ Bank and National Mutual. The Treasurer of the day determined that it was not in the national interest for that to proceed, but I notice in recent media speculation that they are starting to talk again, looking at a new arrangement that might be entered into.

We have seen a relationship entered into between Westpac and Chase AMP where AMP insurance is now going to be offered by the Westpac Bank through its 3,000 branches. In response to that, people have said that that is good because they will have the opportunity of going to their local Westpac branches right around Australia to get information on insurance packages being offered by the AMP Society. That is fine as far as it goes, but the point is that that 15 per cent rule we have instituted through the legislation today is appropriate to meet the needs and the circumstances of the changing financial situation of this country.

The public interest and the question of fit and proper person-who is the person who can ensure that the funds are being operated appropriately-was also raised by the honourable member for Higgins. For his benefit, the concern the Government has as to who is a fit and proper person goes to the very heart of what he was arguing at the start of his presentation, that is, the problem about fraud and fraudulent activities. The fit and proper clause that has been included here basically prevents companies from appointing people who have been convicted of offences or dishonest conduct as principal executive officer or director of a life or general insurance company.

That is what a fit and proper person means here. We do not want crooks in the system. We do not want people who have been convicted of being fraudulent in the past. We are taking appropriate measures to see that they do not get their grubby little hands on the levers of the top half of the company and then drive them down and cause problems for people who have invested their hard-earned funds in these sorts of insurance companies. The honourable member should not worry any longer about a fit and proper person and those sorts of people who are likely to come into influential positions within life insurance companies.

I return to where I commenced. Whilst I have a great degree of sympathy-I am pleased that the Opposition has recognised the standing of the Committee which I have the pleasure to chair; my colleague the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), who will follow me in this debate, is a very valued member-I believe that referring this package of legislation to the Committee at this stage would not necessarily achieve the aim that the honourable member for Higgins would like to see. I am saying to him that the issue in general terms is now being examined by the Committee. We are looking at it. There is a real opportunity and a real likelihood that we will be making recommendations about this question of prudential supervision of not only life companies but also superannuation funds, the banks in general in this country and financial operations as well. Again, I say to the honourable member: do not be too excited if the Government does not accept this amendment, although I am always pleased to receive more work for our Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you attracted to the idea?

—I am attracted to the idea. It may well be that at the end of the day we can make a recommendation and that the Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Free) and the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) would agree that it is appropriate that further examination be taken of this particular legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no problem about putting this package of Bills through at the moment but we have to put in place something in the meantime. To that extent, I commend the Treasurer for bringing these Bills into the House for debate today. I think it is a welcome and necessary part of the changing financial circumstances of this country that we take on board the need for further examination and consideration of prudential supervision and that we put in place appropriate standards and guidelines, not only in life insurance, as we are today, but in superannuation, trust funds and certainly in the banking industry. All of that will be identified now. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the amendment moved by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), I observe at the outset that two Bills in this package of six insurance Bills are designed to protect the policyholders of the Occidental Life and the Regal Life insurance companies from the consequences of the collapse of those two companies. Other Bills in the package seek to enhance the prudential standards required of the industry and provide for greater supervision of the industry by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Bill and the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Bill provide for the levying of registered life insurance companies in Australia. The levy is to be based on the total assets of each company and paid out of the assets of the companies' statutory funds. These funds will be placed in a life insurance policyholders protection fund under the auspices of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The fund will be used to cover the losses of Occidental Life and Regal Life. The total amount to be raised this way has been limited to $65m. The levy is said to be a one-off affair that will cover only the loss due to the alleged fraud from the statutory funds of Occidental and Regal Life.

The Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill puts in place mechanisms for screening changes in the ownership and control of life insurance and general insurance companies. Any changes in ownership or control above a 15 per cent threshold will now require the notification of and approval from the responsible Minister. The Minister is to be required to make a determination on any matter within 30 days to allow the change to go ahead or to prohibit the proposed transaction or to place conditions on that transaction.

The Insurance Laws Amendment Bill increases the minimum capital solvency requirements for general and life insurance companies under the existing legislation. The Bill increases the minimum amount of paid up share capital for general insurers from $500,000 to $2m. The amount by which the value of the assets of a company incorporated in Australia must exceed its liabilities is increased from $1m to $2m.

The Australian assets of any company must also exceed its Australian liabilities by $2m under the new measures being increased from the $1m provided for under the existing legislation. The minimum capital requirement for a life company with share capital has increased from $2m to $10m. Companies without share capital must maintain assets of at least $10m. Registered life offices must now also maintain an excess of $5m of assets over liabilities to be held outside statutory funds.

Finally, the Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill and the General Insurance Supervisory Levy Bill provide for increases in the statutory upper limits for the setting of supervisory levies, accompanied by phasing in arrangements.

This package of Bills and the exceptional circumstances that led to their introduction in this place raise two main issues. The first is the question of who, if anyone other than the policyholders themselves, should pay for the bail-out of the policyholders of Occidental Life and Regal Life. The second issue is what regulatory arrangements, if any, should be put in place to prevent this sort of thing happening again and how such arrangements can be made to work.

The question of who should be required to support the bail-out of Occidental and Regal Life is an extremely difficult and complex one. This is because the circumstances in which $65m worth of Occidental and Regal Life policyholders' funds went for an unscheduled walk around a number of financial institutions are so bizarre that it is difficult for anyone outside the Government, if not impossible, to fairly assign full responsibility for these events. It is absolutely extraordinary that Occidental Life and Regal Life should be purchased with their own statutory funds. This is testimony to the elaborate nature of the confidence trick that was perpetrated against some of the parties to these transactions.

The principal participant in this affair, Mr Phillip Carver, somehow caused the Bank of Melbourne to draw $65m from the account of Occidental and Regal in part payment for the purchase of the same two companies from the Battery Group Ltd on behalf of Carver's shelf company, Heath Holdings. These funds were drawn in favour of two banks and were passed on immediately by Battery to those institutions as repayment to them of outstanding loans. When further funds in support of the sale failed to materialise, Battery stopped the sale but not before $65m was safely in the hands of Battery Group's bank creditors. Naturally, the banks feel under no obligation to return these funds.

The net result of these transactions to date is that the life offices are now technically insolvent and a judicial manager has been appointed to preside over them. The Battery Group has posted losses of $132m after writing off funds owing to it as a result of the aborted sale of Occidental and Regal. How these transactions were authorised and which of the parties acted improperly is now the subject of a massive legal wrangle between Occidental and Regal, the Bank of Melbourne, the Battery Group and some 19 other parties to the dispute before the Supreme Court of Victoria.

It seems to have been reluctantly agreed that, in order to maintain confidence in the insurance industry, the policyholders of Occidental Life and Regal Life should be supported by a one-off rescue package. Without such a package, the policyholders of these two companies will each clearly suffer considerable losses.

Under this legislation, it will be the policyholders with other insurance companies who will foot the bill for the aborted sale of these two companies. Needless to say, this is an entirely arbitrary imposition. There is no particular reason why policyholders with other firms should be required to bail-out the policyholders of Occidental Life and Regal Life, other than that they happen to be in the same industry.

The inequity of this arrangement was largely responsible for the failure of the industry itself to put together a voluntary rescue package for the two companies, using its own resources. It may be that there are legal reasons for not doing so but no-one from the Government or industry will give a full explanation, and that is one reason why we would like the inquiry.

However, in the absence of a satisfactory legal settlement, it is difficult to nominate any other party who should be required to foot the bill, assuming that that party, or parties, would still be in a fit financial state to do so. There is a strong argument from some that the taxpayer should foot the bill for this bail-out, on the grounds that the aborted sale was the result of a failure by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to properly supervise the relevant transactions. It is argued that the Government already levies the industry to pay for various supervisory mechanisms and so the industry is entitled to some sort of return from that service, rather than being levied yet again to finance the failure of those mechanisms.

The failure is not so much the fault of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission itself; it is a failure by the Government to provide adequate resources to the Commission to enable it to carry out its assigned tasks. I hope to find the time to address that important subject in more detail in a moment.

The main point to be made is that no matter who pays for the rescue package, it sends out the wrong signals to industry participants. Although this levy is billed as a one-off measure, unlike the permanent scheme that has now been instituted in the United Kingdom, the precedent has been set for government sponsored rescues of business failures such as these.

The problems of Occidental Life and Regal Life have not been confined to the loss of $65m at the hands of a confidence trickster. Both companies were already suffering from poor performance which greatly contributed to the disaster that was to follow. The statutory funds of Occidental Life had low solvency margins and a mismatching of assets and liabilities was evident in its actuarial valuation report well before the aborted sale. There were disproportionately large and risky investments being held by the company's capital guaranteed funds.

Regal's position was propped up by a change in the basis of accounting to the Commission of certain classes of investment account policies. Otherwise, it may well have been in deficit well before the aborted sale took place and that would have been abundantly apparent.

It is hardly surprising that the Battery Group was so keen-and, in the event, overly keen-to sell these two companies. In an interim report from the judicial manager, Mr Richard Grellman, it is estimated that policyholder obligations could exceed assets by somewhere in the range of $96m to $237m for the two companies.

The signal that the bail-out sends to the industry is that poor business practices and even fraudulent transactions will not be subject to the usual market discipline. Instead, the Government has indicated that in this situation policyholders in well-run companies can in future be expected to foot the bill. Indeed, the levy turns some of the victims of a scam into its beneficiaries, while its costs are socialised across the industry. The levy also sends a message to policyholders that they need not exercise any supervision themselves of the firms in which they place their trust since the Government can be expected to rescue them should any difficulties arise.

If sound business practices are to be fostered, it is important that both policyholders and industry participants be subjected to normal market discipline. Whatever the Government's assurances to the contrary, there is no reason to expect that future Labor governments will not do the same thing again in similar circumstances now that an effective precedent has been set. The industry as well as present and potential policyholders should clearly understand that the coalition in government will not be bound by such a precedent.

The Government defends this levy by pointing to the other measures contained in this package of Bills which will improve prudential standards in the industry and subject the industry to greater regulation by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The first thing that needs to be noted about the new prudential standards and supervisory mechanisms is that they would not necessarily prevent another debacle of a similar nature from occurring again in this industry at some time in the future.

Presumably, these regulatory measures will make any future fraud or commercial disaster in the industry less likely to occur. But these regulations are by no means foolproof and so the effectiveness of any of these measures must be carefully weighed against any costs that the regulations impose.

The danger is that too much faith will be placed in the existing regulations, as well as those proposed in these Bills, at the expense of prudent commercial practices. As the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner, Mr Richard Beetham, has said:

When you focus on regulation and supervision of an industry there is a tendency to forget that the primary responsibility for the prudential supervision of an organisation rests with the board of that organisation and the senior management. They are the people who have the primary responsibility.

There has been a tendency to blame the whole of the Occidental and Regal Life debacle on the confidence trickster who perpetrated the sting. In the event, there were many people who were responsible for what happened and who failed to exercise due caution in their commercial and other dealings. Legislation can do little to address bad business practices and we should not try to compensate for people's failings through regulatory frameworks.

There will be several costs associated with this legislation that will work to the detriment of the industry and policyholders. There can be little doubt that in levying efficient industry participants to bail out less efficient companies, these Bills will result in a less efficient industry.

The present provisions of the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill will effectively raise barriers of entry to an already uncompetitive industry. AMP and National Mutual together control 60 per cent of the life insurance market, with a number of smaller firms competing for the remainder of market share.

It is interesting to note that one of the goals of these Bills is to prevent, according to the Minister, `undue concentration of economic power in the Australian life insurance industry'. Yet these measures could well increase such concentration if they reduce the industry's overall competitiveness. This loss of industry competitiveness will also contribute to a less efficient industry.

The takeovers and acquisitions provisions afford the Minister an enormous amount of discretion in relation to any changes in the structure of ownership in the industry. The end result of that discretion obviously depends upon how it is used but that in itself is a problem. The existence of ministerial discretion will become a major source of uncertainty in the commercial decision making of those in the industry. Such uncertainty can result in bad investment decisions and sub-optimal business practices. The discretion afforded the Minister in these Bills should have been heavily circumscribed so as to minimise the degree of uncertainty in the industry.

To the extent that there is a need to raise prudential standards and enhance supervisory mechanisms for the insurance industry, these regulatory measures need to be adequately funded. There is no point in having these regulations and their associated costs if they cannot be adequately enforced. Indeed, the regulations may do even more harm than good if compliance with the regulations effectively becomes optional, thereby generating more uncertainty.

One of the principal difficulties faced by the insurance and superannuation industry is not so much the inadequacy of the regulatory framework as the failure of that framework to be adequately funded and therefore enforced. The main regulatory body is the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. It is widely accepted that this body is grossly underfunded for the task it is expected to perform. We saw this most recently with the delays experienced by the ISC in the mailing out of notices of reasonable benefit determinations for recipients of eligible termination payments, potentially affecting some 500,000 people.

Due to the inadequate resources of the Commission, employers and superannuation funds have not been made fully aware of their obligations to their employees, particularly with regard to the tax file number system. This has led to some 35 per cent of determinations being sent out with invalid or no tax file number information. Under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act, the ISC Commissioner is able to make an interim determination that the whole of an eligible termination is excessive and thus taxable at the individual's marginal rate where incomplete tax file number information is given. Taxpayers have been given 60 days to inform the ISC of their tax file number or the interim determination sent out by the ISC will stand.

This has meant that thousands of lump sum superannuation recipients are at risk of losing favourable tax treatment due to the under-resourcing of the ISC. The Government allocated barely $17m to the ISC in 1989-90, most of which was given over to the administration of our complex occupational superannuation regulations. Under these conditions it is hardly surprising that we should see a failure of regulation in the insurance industry, and while this funding situation continues we can only expect further shortcomings in the future.

The supervisory measures in these Bills will not perform the role expected of them if enforcement of these measures is not adequately resourced. It is disturbing that these Bills, which are designed to bail out Occidental and Regal Life, will be closely followed by regulations to freeze redemptions from unlisted property trusts. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) posed a question that I think is central to this package of insurance Bills: who should pay? I might equally pose the question to him: what would he do?
—I answered that in my speech.
—You were not listening.

—No, I listened. What would the honourable member for Curtin do to deal with this? Would he write nasty letters or make loud noises? How would he deal with all those policyholders with Occidental and Regal Life who will not be covered? There was the stigma of nasty government sponsored rescues and the bad signals that these would send out to the industry. However, in the end, when one is in government or one has to make decisions, one is required to make a choice, and the choice here is between providing protection of policyholders or not: to say to all those people who are holders of policies in Occidental and Regal-and everybody else in the country who has a life policy or a general insurance policy-that there is no certainty in that policy, that one can be subject to fraudulent activity and, indeed, if that is the case, the industry is not then in a position, nor does it think it important enough, to take responsible action to protect people in those circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the view that an ongoing policy of protection for policyholders would send the wrong signals out to the industry. There could be the expectation that the insurance industry was guaranteed by the Government; there could be a removal of incentive for insurance companies to undertake sound practices; and there could be the belief that well managed companies would be paying for those that are poorly managed. It would send out the wrong messages and discourage those companies that have through a lifetime of prudent management established strength and reputations that people rely on.

I support the view that some sort of ongoing protection mechanism is not an appropriate response. What is an appropriate response to what has happened is a once-off situation whereby the burden of the cost is shared, whatever it might be-and unlike the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) I am not certain that it will be $65m; that is the maximum outside figure and depends on a whole lot of litigation and court proceedings presently being undertaken, and on the outcome of the judicial management of these businesses.

It is not certain what that will be, but I think it is an appropriate response in this circumstance for that burden to be shared among all policyholders in that area and for the industry to be levied appropriately. A large number of industry members supported a voluntary levy; it was unfortunate that such a procedure was unable to be established. However, the Opposition has come in here today and has said, `What we need is more uncertainty and to defer this matter, put it off, and all those people who are policyholders with Occidental and Regal can wait and sweat'. That is not an appropriate way to deal with this legislation, and I think that what is being done is responsible in this case.

I believe the honourable member for Higgins gave a thoughtful speech. Like the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), who is the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, I was attracted to the view that the Committee should look at the supervisory role and the prudential role of Australian business. It is increasingly becoming the case that the lines between the superannuation industry, the insurance industry and banking and non-banking financial institutions are becoming blurred. It is appropriate that we have some consistency in the prudential framework for all those areas of business, but that is not a reason for us to defer this package; it is not a reason for us to take appropriate steps at this time which can strengthen the supervision and prudential requirements, provide protection for those policyholders of Occidental and Regal Life, ensure that measures are undertaken that will mean that changes of ownership will be scrutinised by the Government and the effect will not be detrimental on the affairs and conduct of insurance and of the insurance industry in this country.

That is what this package of measures is about and it is an appropriate package because it will do all these things. It does not solve the problem correctly identified by the honourable member for Higgins that we do not have a substantial and consistent framework for prudential management of the whole spectrum-superannuation, general and life insurance, banking and non-banking financial institutions and the financial sector in general. There is a requirement for that to be undertaken and I believe it would be an appropriate reference for the Committee at a later date, but it in no way defers the importance of our passing this package of legislation.

The existing supervision now in place in this country is encompassed by two pieces of legislation. First, there is the Life Insurance Act 1945, which regulates the operations of life insurance companies to protect policyholders. Indeed, the requirements laid down in that legislation are for levels of solvency, for registration of life insurance companies and for the maintenance of statutory funds. Those statutory funds are to be kept separate from the other funds of the business and there are certain restrictions on the use of those statutory funds. In the case of Occidental and Regal, it was those statutory funds which were misused and used in an unauthorised way.

That legislation, the Life Insurance Act 1945, also has a requirement for quarterly and annual returns. The Commissioner has the capacity to investigate and direct and, if he feels it is appropriate, he can elect to have judicial management in particular circumstances. Indeed, for the first time in 46 years-the time in which that legislation has been operating-that has been necessary in this case. That legislation has probably served us fairly well, but with the increasing complexity of business and business affairs it would be absurd to expect that it would not need changing and improving and upgrading.

The other piece of legislation that broadly provides the existing supervision is the Insurance Act 1973. This Act establishes minimal financial standards for general insurers, a minimal amount of paid-up capital and minimum solvency requirements. It provides for continuous supervision and requires annual returns and quarterly returns to be produced. It also provides for formal investigation of the activities of insurance companies and for the Commissioner to direct in various ways the supervision of those companies to be undertaken. Prior to 1973, what was believed to be the appropriate means of supervision was via deposits in the form of approved securities with the Treasury. It was when the Insurance Act 1973 was introduced that the effective solvency monitoring system was established. So we have had an evolution of legislation and, indeed, over a period we have had an improvement of the supervisory role.

This package of six Bills includes two Bills which relate to the supervisory level of general and life insurance companies. Basically, the legislation increases the upper limit of the supervisory levy and it also increases the rate of the supervisory levy. This will provide for increases in the staff and resources and strengthen the activities of the supervisory commission, and it is appropriate that this should be the case.

The honourable member for Curtin said that one of the problems in supervision was that the funding was inadequate. Two of these Bills provide for an increase in the funding. They provide for the supervision to be undertaken with funds that are obtained from levies on insurance companies. I would have thought that the user-pays principle that is inherent in that philosophy would be one the honourable member for Curtin would support. Indeed, if these Bills are to be deferred, as the Opposition is suggesting, it will be impossible for an increasing amount of funds to be applied to the supervisory role of the Commission. So it is appropriate that these two pieces of legislation should pass.

Two other pieces of legislation that relate to the protection of policyholders from Occidental and Regal Life permit regulations to be made to impose levies on life insurance companies. Those levies will provide for a measure of financial protection for those policyholders. We need to understand that the legislation provides for a mechanism of collection and it provides for the circumstances in which the money can be applied. Given that these funds will be supervised by members of the insurance industry, by the Commissioner, and also by the receiver-manager, the judicial manager, it can be seen that there is a great deal of supervision of this legislation and we can be sure that the funds will be applied if and when appropriate.

If it is the case that the position of Occidental and Regal warrants the levy process, the Commissioner has to be satisfied that their financial position is such that it is warranted. Indeed, the continuing investigations that are being undertaken and the court actions that are pending may change the circumstances in respect of Regal and Occidental. The possibility exists for the proposal put by the honourable member for Higgins that these transactions be reversed. It is, I am sure, a possibility, if indeed an outside possibility, given the framework of justice in this country. But if that were to occur, there would be no liability and no necessity for the levy to be applied.

The legislation provides the mechanism for the levy to be applied and it provides for the circumstances in which the levy can be applied. Given those two criteria, it is appropriate that it provides protection and assurance for those people who have policies with those companies. Indeed, it provides protection and assurance for everybody who holds insurance policies in this country, because they understand that there is some fairness and justice in the way in which the Government and, indeed, the industry have reacted to their plight, which is an unintended consequence but a result of unauthorised action by individuals or companies.

As I mentioned earlier, the prospect of an ongoing fund to provide that protection is something that has been considered. It was the sort of thing considered by the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and rejected, for the reasons I mentioned earlier. I endorse the view of the honourable member for Curtin: it sends the wrong signals out to the industry and to the community if there is some understanding that the Government will guarantee the insurance industry. In this case, I believe an appropriate one-off response is one part of the Government's response to the problem. The other part is the increase in the supervisory levy, which will provide for more adequate supervision.

There are two other significant aspects of these six Bills. Firstly, the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill amends the Insurance Act 1973 and the Life Insurance Act 1945, which I have already mentioned. It increases the capital requirements, the solvency requirements, and the frequency of actuarial investigations. The Bill provides for an increase in the capital and solvency requirements of life insurance companies and general insurance companies and it imposes an increased frequency on actuarial supervision of their activities.

The last piece of legislation that makes up this package is the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill, in respect of which a number of comments have been made by honourable members opposite. Again, the honourable member for Higgins made a valid point when he said that there needs to be a consistent framework in respect of company law and acquisition and takeovers legislation in different areas of financial institutions and the financial market. But that does not make this piece of legislation inappropriate; it underlines the requirement for it. Indeed, the whole Occidental-Regal debacle is indicative of the need for such legislation.

This legislation ensures that Australian life and general insurance companies will not be adversely affected in their conduct by changes of ownership or control. The 15 per cent rule which applies in this case is an appropriate way in which such changes of ownership or control can be overseen by the Minister. The legislation also applies one or two other safeguards. It applies the safeguard that unsuitable persons should not be in positions of influence over Australian life and general insurance companies. I do not think anybody in this place would say that that was an inappropriate measure. I am sure it would be supported by honourable members on both sides of the House.

Likewise, it provides for prevention of undue concentration of economic power in the Australian life and general insurance industry and in the Australian financial system generally. Again, that is a consideration which is critical to having a fair marketplace and having a competitive financial structure. If the Government has an important role in regulating business and business activities, I believe its role should be to provide for fair competition and to provide every opportunity for those businesses that want to compete to know that there is a structure which provides for that.

I accept, as the honourable member for Higgins said, that the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill 1991, which undertakes to prevent transactions that would be contrary to the national interest, is indeed a broad brush approach. I suppose `contrary to the national interest' is open to wide interpretation. Perhaps in this environment that form of words provides the necessary discretion to the Minister to scrutinise takeovers and changes in control of insurance companies, because it does adopt a broad brush approach. Perhaps in the present environment that is an appropriate statement to make and it is an appropriate regulatory mechanism for the Government to wish to have. I believe the honourable member for Higgins is correct when he suggests that there is need for a more consistent and wide-ranging approach to these aspects. However, in view of the present circumstances and in view of our experience with Regal and Occidental, appropriate ministerial discretion is necessary and I believe it is a requirement for us to undertake the sort of supervision that is necessary.

These six Bills provide protection and security for Occidental and Regal policyholders. They provide for increasing supervision; they provide for increasing prudential requirements on insurance companies, both life and general; and they provide for measures that will ensure that changes of ownership will not affect the conduct of affairs of insurance companies. Indeed, I believe these Bills constitute an appropriate package for the Government to be bringing forward. It will provide protection and security for people who are concerned about their insurance policies, particularly for those who are affected by this particular debacle. I believe it will provide a measure of supervision and protection which is appropriate at this stage. I agree with the view put by honourable members opposite that we need to further improve that supervision. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate so far demonstrates a considerable degree of cross-party support for what is essentially the proposition put to the House by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello). His amendment would allow these Bills to be looked at appropriately by a committee of the House of Representatives, namely, the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. The primary problem is the lack of prudential and control arrangements within the law governing the superannuation industry.

SPEECH.PARA: In that context I find it surprising, therefore, that the Government still proposes to proceed with this legislation willy-nilly, regardless of the fact that we are essentially addressing two fundamental points: firstly, the lack of prudential and supervisory arrangements; and, secondly, the specific events leading up to and resulting from the Battery company problems in relation to Occidental Life and Regal Life.

There is an almost surrealistic approach to this debate in the House. We are talking about the savings of many thousands of men and women-fellow Australians-who for many decades have been encouraged by all governments to contribute to superannuation and life insurance, specifically because members of this Parliament say it is in Australia's national interest that they should so do. These people, through no fault of their own, have now found themselves in a very difficult situation.

The legislation is an attempt by the Government to protect life insurance and general insurance policyholders who invested what was often their life savings in companies such as Occidental Life and Regal Life. The circumstances surrounding this legislation are extremely complex. There is a major case now before the courts involving the return of some $65m currently held by the Commonwealth Bank and the ANZ Bank, and joining them in the case is also the Bank of Melbourne. The Bank of Melbourne was holding the escrow funds in trust on 28 September 1990, when the Battery Group attempted to sell to Heath Holdings, a shelf company, the assets of the Occidental Life and Regal Life companies.

In summary, the Bank of Melbourne handed $65m of insurance company trust funds to Battery, which in turn used it to pay off part of a debt of $80m to the Commonwealth and ANZ banks. This package, according to the Government, will implement a range of measures which will provide financial support to policyholders and increase the general level of the prudential protection provided to life and general insurance policyholders in the future. The package includes amendments to the Life Insurance Act and the Insurance Act to provide the financial and prudential standards which must be satisfied by life and general insurance companies. These objectives are strongly endorsed by the Opposition. But, as my colleagues the honourable member for Higgins and the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) have said before me, it is a sad reflection that here we are once again closing the stable door after the horse has well and truly bolted.

These provisions include increased minimum capital requirements and additional solvency requirements for general insurance, improved methodology for company investigations and measures to disqualify persons who have been bankrupt or convicted of offences relating to insurance law or dishonest conduct from acting as directors or senior managers of insurance companies. On this point, I reiterate the words of my colleague the honourable member for Curtin when he said that the primary responsibility must always rest with the boards and senior management of companies which get themselves into trouble.
