In so many respects this legislation is symptomatic of the grave crisis in corporate Australia which we saw developing during the late 1980s and which so many hundreds of thousands of Australians, in all States, in all forms of activity, have had to suffer and bear the consequences of.

Unfortunately, too many people failed to exercise due caution, which cost Australians very dearly indeed. The Occidental Life and Regal Life arrangements which are currently being debated are merely symptomatic of that problem, but are in line with so many other crises that we have seen in the corporate sector affecting the savings of many thousands of Australians.

It is in fact a sad reflection on the inadequacy of the prudential and supervisory statutory rules, which have been in place for so long, that it took a crisis of this measure in the insurance industry, based upon what appears to be simply fraud, to galvanise a government to some form of adequate action. The deficiencies in the two Acts, which became evident only during the investigation into Occidental Life and Regal Life, have fortunately been based upon isolated incidents. But we have seen the experience in the United Kingdom and the United States over recent years, and unless there are adequate supervisory arrangements in place all the time and unless the statutory authorities responsible for the administration of those arrangements have adequate resources, there is no way any government can guarantee to the Australian people that their funds will be protected by the law.

In the context of the financial disasters which have befallen Australia during the 1980s, we have seen too many cases of inadequate prudential and supervisory arrangements in the commercial sector. In relation to the banking sector, and now the life insurance and superannuation sectors, the only sensible conclusion is that for too long the Government has allowed these industries to run very close to the wind and it has not provided the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, nor the other regulatory authorities, with sufficient resources to enable them to supervise the industries and to protect Australian investors. No-one, least of all the policyholders of these two companies, should be under any illusion that the situation is fully stabilised.

Before coming into the House this morning, I discussed the current situation with the judicial manager appointed by the Federal Court to supervise the affairs of Occidental and Regal Life. I have been informed that there has been a freeze on policyholders with superannuation or investment policies receiving their full entitlement. Only policyholders who have mature policies, or are retirees in hardship categories specifically noted by the Federal Court, have been receiving their entitlements. Even in these cases, many have not received their full entitlements. Where pay outs are being made to the categories specified by the Federal Court, and dependent upon which statutory fund their investments were placed in, some beneficiaries are receiving 100 per cent of their entitlements; others are receiving as low as 35c in the dollar.

This raises the very serious question of whether the existing Department of Social Security regulations are adequate to take account of people caught in that impossible situation. As I read the income and assets tests and as I understand the way they are being applied, there is a tendency for the Department to simply say to people in those circumstances, `Hard luck, notionally you have assets which take you over the line in terms of access to some specific level of pension'.

However, the reality is that those people have no access to those assets. The hoped for reality is that, depending on the outcome of the cases before the courts and on the basis of the $65m being provided by the remainder of the life insurance industry, these people's circumstances will be improved at least to the extent of 90c in the dollar. But the sad fact is that, for the best part of 12 months or longer, beneficiaries in policies-life insurance or superannuation or whatever they may be-in these two companies in many circumstances have not had access to an adequate pay out on the basis of the contractual arrangements into which they originally entered.

Therefore, I ask the Government to consider seriously whether some assistance can be given to those people-many of whom are my constituents and who have written to me saying that they are retired and in some financial difficulties and asking what can be done to assist them at this stage. If or when the funds are repaid, of course those payments can be repaid and, therefore, there should be no further difficulty.

Therefore, the issue before us is a complex one. The Government members have claimed here today that there is no alternative. The Opposition is making the point that the best that can be said is that it is the worst best circumstance available to us. We have emphasised throughout the debate that the issues which have been raised are extremely complex and sensitive and really go to the fact that the supervisory basis for these arrangements is not adequate.

While this legislation may be seen as a stopgap measure, and nothing more than that, the final outcome surely is that a committee of this House should investigate in full detail the regulatory and prudential requirements necessary to ensure that life and general insurance funds are operated for the maximum return to the policyholders, and that the costs likely to be borne by policyholders in other funds levied under this legislation will not, in the long term, be to the disadvantage of those people.

In an interesting observation, the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) made the point that the alternatives really were whether funds should be provided by the taxpayer or whether funds should be provided by other policyholders. The line is not as simple as that. We are told by the Government that the levies collected will be paid into a protection fund and are to be tax deductible to life offices, and furthermore that these arrangements are being imposed because of special unusual circumstances involving the unauthorised dealing in statutory fund moneys in the first place.

Those two points get to the very heart of this issue. Firstly, the very fact that tax deductibility is provided to life insurance companies providing the $65m on behalf of their policyholders merely demonstrates the fact that to a large degree it is the Australian electorate, through its taxes, which is contributing to this fund. Secondly, the essential legal problem rests on the fact that the system was open enough to allow unauthorised dealings in statutory fund moneys.

The case of Occidental and Regal Life will no doubt go down in Australian legal history as an important test case, but it raises fundamental issues. What is the responsibility of the taxpayer overall to protect the interests of policyholders? What is the fundamental responsibility of the industry towards its own members? Above all, the clear responsibility rests on governments to ensure that the statutory rules in place are adequate and that there is adequate supervision of those rules.

The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) has made a number of important points in relation to this legislation. Firstly, he made the observation that some 60 per cent of superannuation and life insurance business in Australia is effectively controlled by two companies-the AMP and National Mutual. It is no secret that there are many smaller life offices in Australia today which would gladly close up business if they could. This is no suggestion that they are in financial difficulties, but merely an identification of the realities facing the industry-that is, because of decisions made during the 1980s, often involving capital funds, especially real estate and so forth, the industry no longer has the capacity to provide the productivity and the profitability which most people would expect of it, especially for investments over such a long period of time.

This raises the fundamental issue as to whether the Government has been talking up the industry too much over recent years. The former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), came out with his rather grandiose suggestion two years ago that by the turn of the century superannuation specifically would have investments in excess of $600 billion-a vast amount of money in terms of domestic savings in Australia. If we could get anywhere near that figure, clearly there would be some advantages because it would reduce our need to import other people's savings for Australian development projects.

On the other hand, a more realistic interpretation would suggest that that figure could be as low as $400 billion. That bears out the fact that the present level of emphasis on superannuation in relation to the current Government policy is inadequate. The sad fact of the matter is that most people on average weekly earnings-around $30,000 a year or below-are, in many cases, not gaining an adequate return on their long term investments. This fact is being totally ignored by the Government and to a large degree has been exacerbated by the fact that the current superannuation taxation arrangements have militated against most Australians being able to see superannuation as a long term viable and worthwhile financial investment.

The realities are that, at the top end of town, superannuation, because of its tax deductible nature, is still seen as a worthwhile investment. But any examination of the realities of the social security costings and any serious analysis of the likely impact of an ageing population in Australia over the next 20 years or 30 years must lead us to the conclusion that whatever can be done to encourage all Australians to save for their retirement must in the longer term be of benefit to future generations of taxpayers.

The way that the Government has gone about this is to put much greater emphasis on the requirement for employers to fund superannuation, virtually completely. The proposals contained in yesterday's Budget are but another step in that sad direction which has totally ignored the fact that every time that there is an additional impost on employers the ultimate effect is that it can be inflationary; but, more relevant in today's Australian environment, more people will lose their jobs.

Various estimates have been put forward in that regard, some as high as 100,000 people. But one thing is certain: every time we increase the cost of taking on labour, we are effectively encouraging employers to look for alternatives, to look for cheaper, less costly means of achieving their objectives. Invariably, this means that fewer people will be employed-not more.

I think it is a very sad reflection on the Government that once again it has given in to the dictates of the ACTU in this area. It has taken an extraordinarily important area of policy, and it has clothed it in a political sheet which cannot be sustained under current economic circumstances. Therefore, the legislation before the House today is of considerable importance.

It is particularly important because it goes to the heart of the question as to whether or not we are able to put in place in this country a legal regime which will encourage people to feel that their investments in life assurance and superannuation are being adequately protected and maintained. The point must be made that the Regal and Occidental case is a one-off. Fortunately, for at least the last 100 to 150 years, superannuation and life insurance management in Australia has been free of situations such as this.

In Australia we have developed an industry which in many respects is one of the most efficient and effective in the world. When we compare it with circumstances in the United Kingdom or, in particular, the United States where the housing and loan fiascos of recent years have not been limited to fringe banking but have also influenced the investment of life insurance and superannuation companies, we can be thankful that we have had so few cases in the past. But in no respect should this be seen as a defence of the Government which over 8 1/2 years has not seen fit to look in detail to amending the life insurance legislation until now. In the words of its own members, it is doing so in the environment of 1991 because of the cases which are currently before the courts and the fiasco which has been created because of the Battery difficulties. This should not have occurred in the first place.

When the Government established the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and legislation went through this House, members of the Opposition urged the Government to ensure that there would be adequate regulation in place to enable the new Commission to actively carry out its activities.

As the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) has told us this morning, the recent Budget still puts a limit of $17m on the funding of that critical instrument of government policy, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. It is more than that-it is a critical instrument in place to protect the interests of hundreds of thousands of Australian policyholders. They are the people who have been prepared to make the commitment to put aside part of their income so that they will be less of a drain on future generations of Australians. Surely the primary responsibility of this Parliament must be to protect the interests of these people. Sadly, the Government has done too little far too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an interesting debate because it raises the whole function and role of government in supervision and regulation of activities of Australian citizens, areas in their lives that are vital to their future and that, if damaged, cannot be reversed. Generally, one would say that if a fraud is committed by one citizen against another, those two citizens ought to sort it out between themselves in court. That has been a practice in Australia and in business since business institutions began and our courts were established.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, however, we are looking at a circumstance where a fraud, or an assumed fraud, has been committed by an individual, or group of individuals within a financial institution, against people doing business with that institution. An insurance company, or those associated with an insurance company, were responsible for ripping off the deposits of their policyholders. That is a serious circumstance. What is the role of Government in these circumstances? Does the Government have a role at all or is it up to those policyholders to identify those who caused the trouble, bring them to book, and resolve the matter in the courts in the normal way?

In this instance the Government has intervened. The Government has had a responsibility through an organisation called the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The Government said, `This is an area where there needs to be some sort of supervision from government. We are going to plonk a body in there to keep an eye on things'. The Government is giving some assurance to the solidarity and ongoing expectations of those policyholders by saying, `We are concerned, because of previous cases of fraud, so we are going to put an organisation there to keep an eye on the activities of insurance and superannuation companies'.

The Government has given an assurance which has led to an expectation by people that there would be solidarity and security on their investment. If the Government had not acted, its hands would be clean. There would be no role for the Government in these circumstances. But the Government had, before and during the period of this fraud, inserted itself into that situation. Therefore, the Government carries responsibility.

The typical response of this Government in every circumstance such as this is to say, `How were we to know? There was a body supervising this jolly outfit and these organisations, but how were we to know? We are not going to ask taxpayers and we are not going to ask the Commission itself to take responsibility for their actions; we are going to dump the cost of this activity back onto the policyholders'. That is what is occurring here. This legislation allows the Government to wash its hands of responsibility. It would be interesting to have the Government defend the decisions it has made, in light of its own declared responsibility through the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

One could ask: how can a commission of this type be expected to know everything? One could not really expect a government organisation to know everything, especially those things which are illegal and are being kept from it deliberately. The Tax Commissioner does not know everything. How could the Superannuation Commissioner be expected to know everything? The area of government administration needs to be sorted out by way of discussion. A government organisation was in place and there was a responsibility, but the problem was not identified.

The legislation before the House today seeks to give that regulatory organisation more powers and a more comprehensive role in supervising insurance and superannuation organisations on behalf of the Government. In part it also seeks to give to the policyholders of sound companies the responsibility for the loss created in the case of Occidental and Regal Life. Nobody knows how much those sound investors-the choosers of good companies-will pay as a penalty for choosing a good company to superannuate with or to insure with. So those who picked sound companies are penalised in favour of those who happened to pick dud companies. I do not know about the logic of that, but if the industry wanted to pick that and force it on the policyholders, maybe it should have come forward and said so. That is why the Opposition wants to establish a committee to examine these important matters.

A committee of the Parliament should be established. The Government has had time-who knows what has occurred. The Government has not been forthcoming in outlining the details of the effect of such a decision on the policyholders of sound companies. What will be the range of commitment or likely increase in annual premiums to policyholders of those insurances if this goes ahead? Will they be responsible for the full $65m? Will there be a recovery? What does the Government know? The Government says nothing. It provides no information to the Parliament and expects the Parliament to agree to such an arrangement without proper scrutiny. That is why the Opposition would like to see proper scrutiny.

The committee needs to make an important decision on, firstly, the true responsibility of a government organisation raised to supervise an industry and, secondly, on whether the resolution of this factor is best achieved by dumping on those in the industry already holding sound policies the responsibility of funding the failures. Those are the issues that ought to be assessed by a committee of the Parliament. The Government is refusing to do that; in fact, it is acting too little too late. It is notorious for doing that in this area. Going back to the days of the Minister for Housing and Construction and Minister Assisting the Treasurer, Mr Hurford, I remember a matter that he had to fix up. He procrastinated for ages to introduce legislation to solve a problem in the insurance industry.

Here we go again. Keating talked about it for ages and said, `Oh well, the industry will fix it up itself', or `We are going to suck more money out of the industry', or `We will establish a levy or a fund'. He speculated about it for ages but did nothing. It is typical of this Government's legislation. It announces things in press releases and then months later takes some action. In the eyes of the Government, the press release appears to bring about the legality of the situation. Nothing could be further from the truth.

It is interesting that the insurance policyholders protection levy is part of the Budget papers. I do not know whether the Government is going to claim that it is part of the Budget. This legislation is separate from the Budget and should be seen as separate. It provides that certain payments to life offices representing surplus money from the protection fund created by this legislation will be treated as non-fund-accessible income, so there will be a tax factor involved as well. The Government cannot let it go one way or the other; the Government has to tax it whether it is in this fund or not.

I notice that the legislation also provides for the Government considering changes for recording requirements for superannuation funds-changes such as whether the fund has been audited and the details of that audit are being sought, whether abridged financial information has been provided and whether there are arrears of contributions. All of these factors are interesting and very important to the proper prudential management of these significant organisations.

I point out to the House that decisions on superannuation are often made 20 or 30 years before the date of draw down. Any changes that are made in superannuation affect people's lives long before they retire. The 47 changes that this Government has brought to superannuation in the period since 1985 is shameful because there are people out there on the verge of retirement and there are fund managers, operators and brokers with huge books trying to establish the circumstance for individuals as they come into retirement.

The Government has ripped billions of dollars out of the retirees of this nation by the activities that it has raised from time to time in the Budget. The former Treasurer (Mr Keating) is the person who is responsible for getting into the pockets of retirees and those who are about to retire. The certainty has gone; the reliability of superannuation in the eyes of the public has gone. By demand on the companies and businesses of Australia, the Government is imposing more superannuation but the employees do not trust it. Their trust has gone because of the Government's constant fiddling with superannuation. The Government has ripped about $4 billion out of that system in toto, I believe, to prop up the failing economic management that it has provided for this country.

Within the last few days, the Treasury has provided a paper which sets out the Government's attitude to prudential standards. It has made clear that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission would be the primary prudential regulator for the superannuation industry. That is fine, except that the funding process for that supervision is a fraction of what the Government is currently supplying for the Australian Securities Commission. This year, it is applying $114.9m for the ASC and a paltry $17m for the operation of ISC. I know the scope and range of the activities of these two organisations differ, but not to the degree indicated by those figures.

Finally, in this Treasury paper it is interesting to note that the Government itself makes the point that it will not guarantee superannuation benefits to members. As with most investment, the final risk must lie with the investor.

However, the supervisory framework will minimise prudential risk, thereby reducing the risk of fund failure and maintaining public confidence in superannuation savings. It is a case of too little too late. If we do it now, the problem will be over. The attitude of the public is that it does not have the same confidence in the process of superannuation that it used to have. The fault lies in the hands of the Government for the massive number of changes it has made and its `too little too late' attitudes.

One not only has to look at this current situation but at the real administration of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. One only has to look at the requirements in regard to taxation to have real doubts about whether this is the appropriate body to administer insurance and superannuation. There is a requirement, which the Minister knows of, for people to submit to the Australian Tax Office final determinations in regard to the roll over and use of their funds during the last financial year.

Over 100,000 determinations are still being waited for by the taxpayers of Australia. The computers in this outfit, the ISC, are consistently going down, or that is what we are told. Taxpayers are required to provide certain information before they can lodge their tax forms, and now we are into mid-August. Six weeks have passed since the end of the financial year and already many people are out of time as required by the Income Tax Assessment Act. The Government has been pressed to extend the period and has done so.

When will the Insurance and Superannuation Commission deal with the huge backlog, pursuant to its requirements under the Act, and provide information to people submitting information to the Australian Tax Office? The forms are complex. They are devised by people seeking to hide information rather than provide it. The final determination must be clear and complete because, in the process of self-determination in income tax matters, the final responsibility does not rest with the ISC; it rests with the taxpayers.

There are factors in these provisions that the taxpayer could not possibly know, such as: what is a reasonable benefit multiple? A constituent of mine phoned 101 organisations to make sure that 7.0000 was the right factor. Nobody could tell him, including the Superannuation Board, which said, `Ring the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and someone there will tell you'. If a person gets on the phone to ring this outfit-I have done it myself in Sydney-he can wait for half an hour before getting an answer. Last week-not weeks ago-this happened, despite the hot lines, ministerial statements, press releases and all the goings-on. It is a shambles, and the Government ought to do something about it.

There are people who have invested carefully. Labor Party supporters and public servants are coming to me in their retirement and are saying, `We never thought that the Labor Government would actually do this sort of thing to us'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't believe this.

—I am pointing out that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission is hardly the appropriate body, unless it is funded or resourced properly and supplied with proper personnel and the right incentive, to be running things such as the prudential supervision of insurance and superannuation companies in Australia. We have started a process of giving to a body which has not demonstrated its competence the privilege of supervising and continuing to hold in trust those organisations which are responsible for the death benefits of Australians who are insured for life, the fire and general insurance risks of those whose properties or businesses are covered by general insurance, and the savings of people who work long years to prepare for their retirement. This outfit cannot even get its returns back before the end of the financial year so that people can make proper claims in time, and here we are giving it additional responsibilities under this Act, yet no additional resources.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I am making is that the Commission has not demonstrated its bona fides; that ought to be examined. The resolution of this factor, as the Government proposes, and its impact on policyholders, who will be required to pay perhaps $65m towards the cost of the mistakes in Occidental Life and Regal Life, together with the activities of those responsible in Occidental and Regal Life, are matters worthy of committee investigation. They could go to a select committee for quick investigation. The Government could come back here and assure the Opposition that what it is saying is right, that it has made reasonable decisions. It has not provided us with the information necessary to give us that assurance.

I assure the Government that if it keeps going in this way it will not get the assistance or support of the Opposition. It needs to have the confidence of the Australian community in this area. It is an area where the savings of people over one or two decades are involved; it is an area where the protection of their property is involved; and it is in an area where a payout on their death is involved. It is important that every citizen in Australia can be assured of the Government's appropriate actions, can be assured that those actions will not necessarily damage the investment people have made in sound insurance or superannuation funds.

I appeal to the Government to take up the Opposition's challenge in this regard. It should respond positively. What has the Government to lose? It has much to gain. It has the trust and support of people who do not understand what has occurred to gain; it has the trust and support of the Opposition to gain. That, above everything else, is worthy. The Minister should follow that course instead of giggling away there. He knows how serious these matters are. He is giggling because he is embarrassed by the activities of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and the damage it has done to current taxpayers. He should be concerned about whether it can cope with the responsibilities being given to it by the Parliament,

TALK.START.PARA: —He has been handed a stick of gelignite.
—Yes. He is a dangerous man to be given gelignite, that is true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before responding to the various remarks made during this debate, I apologise for showing signs of mirth at the end of the speech by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). At least he injected a genuine flavour of comedy into the debate. I thank the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), and the honourable member for Mitchell for their contributions to the second reading debate, particularly the two Government members, who made such substantial contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address a number of matters raised by Opposition members, and I turn first to the contribution of the honourable member for Higgins, who claimed that Parliament had been asked to punt in the dark on these measures. I point out that these Bills were introduced in June and the details of the proposition have been available for public scrutiny since that time. I respond to his reference to legal remedies being a way out of this impasse by telling him that I am informed that full reports on all developments have been given to Federal police authorities, as one would expect.

On the matter of the availability of the report of Mr Grellman, I am informed that the judicial management report is a court document. It is not appropriate that that kind of document should be required to be tabled in the Parliament; it is available through the court. Any interested parties or, indeed, a member of the public could have access to it.

In response to the concern of the honourable member for Higgins about lack of industry support for these measures, I advise him that the industry shares the Government's concern that further instances of the kind that led to the need for drafting of this legislation should not occur again. The industry recognises the need for legislation to allow for appropriate monitoring of changes to ownership and control of insurance companies.

I also point out to the honourable member that the legislation was developed in consultation with senior industry representatives, with the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, LIFA, and the Insurance Council of Australia. Industry suggestions were sought and they were taken into account in drafting the legislation. The Bills have general industry support. I also point out that, in LIFA's annual report, the Chairman indicated that the industry believed that the legislation would address its concerns. I advise him that, during the implementation process, a committee involving representatives of LIFA and major players in the industry will be involved in that implementation process.

In response to the expression of concern by the honourable member for Higgins about the effect these measures might have on policyholders in other funds, I make the general point that all life insurance policyholders, irrespective of the company in which they have an investment, have an interest in the ongoing stability of the industry. Publicised references to possible action by the Government certainly helped to reduce the negative impact of the developments and helped to shore up investor confidence in the industry.

I turn to the amount that is to be raised by the levy. It has been limited to $65m. It is anticipated that the maximum that could be raised over the duration of the arrangements would amount to less than 0.1 per cent of policyholder assets. The proposed arrangements represent an appropriate balance between the interests of the policyholders in Occidental Life and Regal Life and the interests of policyholders generally.

I inform the honourable member that, with respect to the effect on policyholders in Occidental and Regal, payments to policyholders involving levy support could be up to a maximum of 90 per cent of the total claim under a policy. The actual percentage would depend on a number of factors, including the size of any realised shortfall and the nature of the claim.

The honourable member for Higgins also expressed some concern about concentration of economic power in the public interest test. The definition of concentration of economic power does give the Treasurer broad powers, but I point out that the Bill itself provides for the review of decisions made by the Minister under the Bill. Apart from temporary restraining orders, where a person affected by a reviewable decision is dissatisfied with that decision he may request a reconsideration of the matter by the Minister. Where the Minister subsequently confirms or amends the reviewable decision, an application for review of the Minister's decision can be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The honourable member for Higgins appeared to run out of steam because, with five minutes left in which to speak, he turned to the superannuation industry and had some remarks to make about the prudential supervision of superannuation funds. I point out that there are some quantitative and qualitative differences between the superannuation industry and the insurance industry. The quantitative difference is that there are 58 life companies in this country and around 170 general insurers. There are in the order of 100,000 superannuation funds. With the insurance industry we are dealing with an established industry, but with the superannuation industry, particularly in recent times and I hope also in the future, we are dealing with a developing industry. Supervisory arrangements for the insurance industry have existed since 1945. Supervisory arrangements for the superannuation industry were established in 1987. They are different industries and, consequently, they require their own specialist supervisory knowledge as, indeed, does the banking sector.

The honourable member for Curtin expressed some concern that the legislation was creating a precedent. I point out in response to him that the former Treasurer repeatedly stated that this special one-off arrangement was not to be regarded as a precedent; it was drafted specifically with respect to the problems of Occidental Life and Regal Life.

I turn to the comments of the honourable member for Bradfield. He was concerned about policyholders experiencing difficulties with claims and spoke of delays in the order of 12 months. He expressed concerns about claims not having been met. I point out to him that that is exactly what this levy is for. Yet the Opposition, at the same time as it is complaining about delays and about policyholders experiencing hardship, wants to send this off to a committee. The capacity of the honourable member for Bradfield to look one way while going another is absolutely breathtaking.

The honourable member for Bradfield made a more serious comment about the impact of the assets test. He pointed out that many of his constituents holding policies in these companies may be affected. That is a serious point. Given that they are his constituents, I assume that the honourable member for Bradfield would have done what any of us would have done, that is, made the appropriate representations to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson).

I turn to the comments of the honourable member for Mitchell. He mentioned three matters that I would like to respond to. The first point concerns the Government's supervisory role in the life insurance industry. He said that the Government is responsible, that it has insinuated itself into the process and that it is all the Government's fault.

I point out to the honourable member for Mitchell that a supervisory role has existed in this industry since 1945 and that there has never been a problem before. The problem has been identified; the remedy is before the House. The honourable member's concern about the effect on policyholders in other companies has been dealt with; I gave him the figure of what the levy is estimated to cost policyholders in other companies.

The honourable member expressed concern about the level of funding provided to the ISC as against that provided to the ASC. But they are different bodies. The ASC is a body in the process of establishment, which I am sure he understands. The two bodies perform different functions, but I am advised that there is very good liaison between the two bodies.

I turn now to the substance of the Opposition amendment. The idea of referring this matter to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration is really preposterous. How can the honourable member for Higgins propose a motion to send this legislation off to a parliamentary committee and, at the same time, accuse the Government of dragging its heels on this matter? At the same time that he professes profound sympathy for the investors and says, `I do not for a moment want to hold up the proposals', he wants to send this legislation off to the Martin Committee. The amendment is totally inconsistent with the honourable member's professed concern for the investors and his professed anger with the Government for allegedly dragging its heels.

Given the extensive examination which has already been undertaken by the Government to develop the measures contained in this package, the Government does not believe that it would be appropriate to delay implementation of these much needed measures by referring them to the Martin Committee. The Government's clear preference is to put in place measures which, on the basis of supervisory experience and investigations already undertaken, have been shown to be necessary and appropriate to increase the general level of prudential protection provided to life and general policyholders.

It might be noted that the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner has already put forward a submission to the Martin Committee outlining the role of the Commission and discussing a number of issues which may assist the Committee in its deliberations, as was pointed out by the honourable member for Macarthur during his speech. I would have thought that the Deputy Chairman of the Committee would have advised the honourable member for Higgins of that good news.

The Government, of course, stands ready to look at any suggestions for improvement in the insurance supervisory arrangements which might be put forward by the Committee, the industry or, indeed, any other interested observer. In the meantime, however, the Government sees it as appropriate and highly desirable that the current measures be implemented without undue delay. Accordingly, the Government rejects the Opposition amendment.

That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Costello's amendment) stand part of the question.

(9) Clause 23, page 15, subparagraph (a) (i), lines 28 and 29, omit ``an Australian-registered insurance company'', substitute ``a company''.

The intention of the Bill is to provide the Government with a mechanism for monitoring changes to the ownership and control of life and general insurance companies. The relevant provision does not operate in respect of upstream transactions-for example, dealings in the shares of a holding company of an insurer.

As a consequence it may be possible for a change in the ownership or control of an Australian registered insurer to be effected through the acquisition of shares in a company having a significant shareholding in that insurer and without a requirement for that acquisition to be notified. It was always the intention that upstream acquisitions would be covered in this legislation. The amendments I have moved remedy that. I also present the supplementary explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point for clarification by the Minister in relation to these amendments. As I understand it, the purpose of the amendments that the Government has moved to the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill 1991 is to allow the Australian Minister to effectively supervise share transactions in a foreign company which may, in fact, not even be domiciled in Australia. For example, a foreign insurance company may own an Australian registered insurance company.

SPEECH.PARA: Where there is a proposal to change the shareholding in that company or, indeed, where there is a proposal to issue shares in that company, there would be a responsibility for the Minister to be notified under the trigger proposal provisions of clause 23. I would like the point about whether that is the case clarified at the outset. If it is the case, it seems to me that this is going to be a particularly unwieldy proposition.

Let us suppose that a Swiss based insurance company proposes to issue shares. It owns an Australian registered company and the shares in the Swiss based company are going to be issued, or 15 per cent of them are going to be disposed of. Is it the intention of the legislation to require notification of that share transaction to the Australian Minister? As I understand the legislation, it is. If that is the case, the amendments are seeking effectively to regulate share transactions in foreign companies in foreign jurisdictions, with foreign buyers and foreign sellers.

I note that a clause is to be inserted into clause 19 which effectively allows for the reading down of these provisions. That indicates that the Government itself is very doubtful as to whether the amendments which are being proposed would withstand constitutional challenge. It is already engaging in prop-up measures, as it were, to defend the legislation in the event of a constitutional challenge by effectively severing the provisions which it suspects may not withstand a constitutional challenge. That indicates grave reservations on the part of the Government.

I indicate that the Opposition has some grave reservations as to the constitutionality of these proposals. Of course, if the proposals are struck down it will open up, one would think, a very easy circumvention of this particular provision. This underlines the concerns we have as to the provisions generally. There may, in fact, be better ways of ensuring the constitutional validity of achieving the objective that the Government seeks to achieve than the drafting that has been proposed by way of these amendments. This underlines the concern that we have about how well thought out these amendments are. It underlines the concern we have that further advice and investigation be taken on these particular matters.

The Minister may, in fact, be leading this Parliament into unconstitutional legislation with his amendments. He is providing an escape valve by reason of clause 19, but the escape valve is to effectively jettison the dubious proposals that he is now putting up. He is putting the proposals up with one hand and putting up a mechanism to take them away with the other. With the proposal that he puts up, he is in fact quite possibly leading this Parliament into unconstitutional legislation-a matter that does not fill us with joy and, I am sure, does not fill the Government, in its better moments, with joy.

Knowing the Minister as I do, I am sure that, although he has been given a brief from the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), he has secret doubts about this mechanism. I express my concern about it. I would like the Minister to deal with the question that I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the expression of concern from the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) did not take us all the way to quarter to one. SPEECH.PARA: The Government has no need to make an apology for building in a safeguard in the form of amendment No. 3 as he suggests. Were that not there and had he had advice, I imagine he would be on his feet accusing the Government of being negligent in not having a safeguard there. I have nothing further to add.
