TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can he give us an ironclad guarantee that no more Australians will lose their jobs as a result of the superannuation package he introduced into the Parliament yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat surprised at the position that has been adopted on superannuation by the Opposition. I would have thought that it would have recognised the great merit in this proposal. The reforms to superannuation announced in the Budget are absolutely fundamental to the policies of this Government in regard to retirement income for an ageing population. Under the arrangements that we have made there is provision for continuing wage restraint. I hope it would be noticed by the Leader of the Opposition that in the agreement that I reached with the leadership of the ACTU, together with my colleagues the Minister for Finance, the Treasurer and the Minister for Industrial Relations, it was agreed that in future what happened in regard to superannuation payments by employers would be taken into account in wage negotiations.

ANSWER.PARA: The restraint that has been exercised by the trade union movement since 1983 has been quite remarkable. There has been a 10 per cent reduction in real non-farm unit labour costs since 1983. That has occurred because of the restraint exercised by the trade union movement. As a result of that restraint there has been a massive shift from wages to profits. The facts are quite simple in regard to the level of company profits. When we came to office, company profits, as a share of gross domestic product, were down by about 11 per cent. Even at this stage company profits are still above the long term average of the last 15 years. That is the fact. It has been made possible-as has been recognised, to their credit, by major employer organisations-by the restraint of the trade union movement. We cannot have a 10 per cent reduction in real non-farm unit labour costs without there being a move to profits. It has been the case that the trade unions have been in a situation where they could have, if they had wanted to exercise their muscle, obtain significantly higher increases in nominal wage rates. They declined to do so.

The forecast for average earnings growth in 1991-92 is the lowest for over two decades. This represents a real saving for business. I am here to say, and so is this Government, that the workers of this country are now entitled to share in the benefits of their restraint. That is what it is about. The trade unions have indicated that in future wage negotiations what happens to payments by employers for superannuation will be taken into account. We do not have a situation where we will impose some additional payment in regard to superannuation on what would have been there as a wages outcome. As a result of this process of legislated superannuation, we will have an assurance in this country that all Australian workers will have retirement income security in the next century when an unprecedented number of Australians will be retired.

We have been sensitive in this matter to the needs of small business. A lower contribution level has been set for small business than for large. Of course, we have to remember that the many small firms in this country which are already paying 3 per cent will be unaffected by this measure in 1992-93.

The Treasurer will be talking next month with major employer groups, the trade unions and the industry. I believe that as a result of those discussions we will have an outcome which will be sensible, both in regard to the immediate future and in regard to the longer term interests of this country.

Finally, may I say this in regard to the Leader of the Opposition: he has a very poor record of prediction in regard to what will happen in the economy as a result of what comes out of the accord. I remind the Leader of the Opposition of what he said at the time of accord mark VI. This is what the Leader of the Opposition said on 21 February last year:
Accord mark VI announced today will lead to higher inflation and higher interest rates. It will increase the likelihood of a major collapse of the Australian dollar.

Just look at the predictions of the Leader of the Opposition. He predicted higher inflation. Inflation is not higher-it has fallen from 8 1/2 per cent to 3.4 per cent. So his prediction was wrong on that. He said that interest rates would be higher. In fact, interest rates have fallen by 7 1/2 per cent. He said that the dollar would collapse. The dollar has been totally steady since that time.

The Leader of the Opposition has no idea of what the economic outcomes are of accord negotiations. He was wrong in 1990. He is wrong again this year when he predicts unemployment as a result of what is in fact a far-sighted scheme in regard to providing superannuation for the whole of the Australian working population.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Has the Minister seen reports of some State Premiers suggesting that they will introduce patient charges for public hospital outpatients? Do the Medicare agreements with the States permit the States to charge for outpatient services? What is the Government's response to the Premiers' claim?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Banks for his question, which deals with the possibility of the States imposing outpatient charges as a consequence of the changes that have been made with respect to general practice in the Medicare system. Let me say to the honourable member that the package that has been announced is essentially about general practice. The Government needs to remind the States that, in terms of what they do in this area, they are bound by the Medicare agreement. Having said that, the Government is more than willing to enter into discussions with the States to examine any consequences, or possible consequences, that might flow from the changes that we have already announced.

ANSWER.PARA: It is important that the Premiers and the State health Ministers understand the context and the full details of the package that we have announced. We have in this country a major oversupply of general practitioners. That oversupply is imposing great competitive pressures on general practitioners, at least in our major cities. Secondly, the Government has announced cuts in Medicare rebates for general practice services of $3.50 and will permit doctors who bulk bill to charge up to $3.50.

Thirdly, the competitive pressures that have led to such high rates of bulk billing will continue and will ensure not only that bulk billing continues, but also that many doctors will not necessarily charge the proposed co-payment. Fourthly, the Government, with the medical profession, is committed to addressing the incentives in health insurance which lead to poor quality care and the oversupply of doctors.

In other words, the Government has announced an approach to an underlying issue of oversupply that needs to be linked to an approach in general practice that is open to discussion along with changes that the Government has made in relation to providing a price signal by way of that cut in the rebate and the opportunity that exists for doctors to charge the co-payment. This package is essentially about general practice and we hope it will be pursued in that context.

As we think about general practice, it is important to understand that there are treatments carried out in hospitals and in outpatient areas that could well be carried out within the context of general practice itself; for example, with respect to the treatment of asthma, equipment available within hospitals could easily be located within general practice, providing the opportunity, if there were an adequate capital base, for general practice to play a larger role in the treatment of people with chronic conditions such as asthma.

When we talk about this area, it is important that the States not jump quickly to conclusions that things can be done only one way, that they do not necessarily draw a link which contradicts previous experience where people certainly have not rushed off to outpatient wards and that they understand that we are about dealing with the question of supply but dealing with it in a way that introduces some price signals into general practice and presents a great opportunity, I believe, for the medical profession to think in a visionary way about the future of general practice in this country, restoring some of the status and dignity to general practice and, most of all, providing a better quality service to Australian families.

It is a long time since we have really seen family health care practised in this country. This is an opportunity for us to move in that direction so that we see in terms of general practice not the long queues, the line-ups and the minimal amount of time, but general practice geared to providing quality health care, taking over some of the functions that ought not be provided by hospitals, and providing the linkages to a modern health care system at a community care level.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer and follows the Prime Minister's refusal to give a guarantee about the adverse consequences on unemployment as a result of the Government's plan to introduce a 5 per cent occupational superannuation levy.
—Order! The honourable member will get to his question.

—Has the Treasurer had the Treasury model the unemployment effects of this change? Is it not true that the levy will boost unemployment by at least 45,000 in its transition stage and up to 100,000, as calculated by the economic model of Dr Chris Murphy of the Australian National University, who was formerly senior economic modeller in the Commonwealth Treasury?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few things about superannuation before addressing the question directly.

—There is a lot of hypocrisy about superannuation. All of us in this House are on big fat superannuation packages and people on our income level and in many occupations in this country have tax deductions worth $3.35 billion a year. Seventy per cent of the people in this country have some superannuation, so let us not get too hypocritical about all the impacts of superannuation. Well over one-third-35 per cent-of people have over 5 per cent superannuation now.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us just put some of these things into some sort of perspective. There are five people in employment now for every person over 65 years of age; in 20 years time there will be only three. Eleven per cent of our population is now over 65 and in 20 years time it will be 18 per cent. This superannuation scheme is the start of a scheme for the twenty-first century and we really do have to do something about it.

There is another plus side to this superannuation. It is about the mobilisation of savings; it is about putting to one side, once and for all, the savings task that needs to be taken on by the Australian population. There has been some non-compliance in this area. It escapes the Opposition that, right through the business cycle since 1986, there was award superannuation as part of the productivity-wages package; 3 per cent was awarded right through the award system, and there was non-compliance. It was not the time through the boom; it was not the time when the economies were coming out of recovery. It will never be the time, because the Opposition only has two solutions to every economic problem: cut wages and cut government spending. All that Opposition members can ever think of is almost a pavlovian response. Every time we try to reform and change the basic characteristics of this economy for the better and for the future, we get the same stupid response.

There is one point which everyone seems to be missing as well: we do not necessarily have to assume that superannuation is going to be an add-on to wages. Why? Because we are moving into a whole new devolved wages system whereby industry groups are moving to productivity and enterprise bargaining. The trade union movement, the people on award wages who have not been getting the 3 per cent they were awarded way back in 1987, do not want to increase unemployment and are prepared to lock themselves into the low inflation dividend that this economy has a chance of achieving and of getting some of the fundamentals right. It is against that background that there is very little need indeed to get into spurious modelling exercises to serve Opposition members' fantasies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. Will the Minister advise the House of the impact on the higher education system of the Budget decisions announced yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question, and I would like to point to some of the things that we are doing in the higher education area. In aggregate terms, we are providing funding of $3.92 billion for higher education and $1.52 billion for student education assistance and income support in this financial year, which are increases of 10.1 per cent and 20.3 per cent respectively. Under normal circumstances, as some honourable members would be aware, the higher education system receives its funding on a rolling triennial basis, which would imply that funding for calendar years 1992 and 1993 would be now locked in.

ANSWER.PARA: However, as has been given some attention in the media, we have had a surge in the level of demand for places in higher education institutions. Partly as a consequence of that, partly as a consequence of labour market circumstances and partly as a consequence of a degree of institutional mismanagement, we have had to confront a significant problem of overenrolment in the system. There have been calls on us to address these issues and in response to them the Government has decided to make some additional significant injections of funds into the system over and above existing triennial commitments. We are looking at an increase in capital funding by $53m in 1992 and an additional $70m over four years in base operating grant assistance to enable institutions to deal with enrolment growth.

There are a range of other decisions which I will just briefly mention: $26m over three years for research over and above existing triennial commitments, which are running in excess of $200m already; a significant increase in the number of HECS exemption scholarships to 17,000; a pilot program for advanced engineering centres; and a pilot program for shared funding of higher education places between industry and government. In total, that comes to a package of $76m in the current financial year, which is on top of the funding of $119m that the Government had agreed shortly before the Budget to provide to fund substantial increases in academic salaries. We are talking about a totality of some $200m of new funds over and above existing commitments being injected into the system.

There is one point on which I would like to take issue with some of the media. There has been a lot of reference to the slight increase in the level of HECS contribution, which comes out when we take out the normal indexation adjustment in that at $144 a year. That raises $5m in 1991-92 and $12m in a full year. That has to be set against a net injection of funds of some $200m over and above existing commitments into the system. So some of the press reports that have talked about that slight increase in HECS revenue funding all these other measures are simply absurd.

I would also point out that these measures have been extremely well received by the system. We have had a few arguments with the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee over the last few months about some of these issues of overcrowding and academic staff shortages.
Let me quote from what the AVCC had to say about these Budget decisions in its press release yesterday:
The Federal Government is to be commended for recognising, and acting upon, the difficulties facing higher education in Australia . . .

We particularly welcome the move to bring forward the capital funding program, which will allow much needed buildings to be constructed quickly. Additionally, the reinstatement of the renovation component will mean refurbishment of existing buildings.
We are pleased the Government has guaranteed flexibility in the way these funds can be spent-they will be targeted at areas of most need.

The Government has also begun to address the very serious concerns about future academic staffing by providing an additional 2,000 Higher Education Contribution Scheme exempt scholarships for postgraduates. This will help retain our best graduates and steer them toward an academic career . . .
The $26 million boost to the Australian Research Council Grants, over three years, will provide a significant boost to higher education and ultimately the Australian economy.

It goes on to comment on the changes that we have also introduced in the student income support area, which have greatly improved the targeting, equity and flexibility of student income support. It goes on to say:
who is the Chair of the AVCC-
said the AVCC was pleased with the improvements to the Austudy scheme which should ensure more students will benefit. The new arrangements were consistent with AVCC recommendations.
Other parts of the higher education constituency have also praised those elements in the program. In particular, the students have welcomed the changes to Austudy.

That is the broad response to what we have done. It has been extremely well received. In conclusion, there is a stark contrast between the reception from the system for this package of measures, which have been hailed as being well targeted, well constructed and timely, and the response to the National Press Club speech by the honourable member for Goldstein a couple of weeks ago, supposedly setting out the Opposition's blueprint for higher education.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the response?

—There was almost universal comment on the vagueness, lack of specificity, failure to tackle the difficult questions associated with the sort of solutions he had been talking about; he was squirming and prevaricating when pressed on questions about whether he intends to introduce up-front fees; he was squirming and prevaricating about whether the proposed goods and services tax would apply to education services. There was a total failure to confront any of the significant issues. Even those who were critical of the Government in the last few months were scathing in their condemnation and derision heaped upon the contribution by the honourable member for Goldstein.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer him to the Budget forecast of a peak in unemployment of 10.75 per cent in the 1991-92 financial year. What is the Treasurer's estimate of the actual peak number of unemployed in 1991-92?
—The number is somewhere near 900,000, as I understand it.

—I address my question to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister inform the House what the Government is doing to assist families, particularly in the face of the difficult economic times now being experienced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Prospect for her question. From my visits into her electorate-and this is not merely a formal acknowledgment-I can say quite sincerely that I know from my own experience how important these issues are to her.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1987 this Government delivered a major breakthrough, which was recognised as such, in reform to assist low income families by introducing the family allowance supplement. As the honourable member appreciates, as a result of that historic breakthrough, recognised in this country and abroad as a very significant reform, we have massively increased in real terms support for low income families. It is important to understand that this Budget builds on those foundational achievements.

We have made the family support system simpler; we have made it more consistent. We have increased assistance to low to moderate income families. We have provided stronger incentives to people to seek jobs, and we have, very importantly, delivered greater assistance to the primary carer, who is in the majority of cases, of course, the mother.

In the process we have delivered assistance to those families which have exercised the most restraint over the past eight years, and we have further improved the social wage. As I think the honourable member will appreciate, the major measures are these: an increase in the FAS income test threshold from 1 April of next year to $19,300-that means 109,000 low to moderate income families will gain an average of $12 a week-and combination of the family allowance and family allowance supplement into a two-step payment from 1 January 1993 at a cost of over $100m in 1993-94.

That decision will significantly improve FAS take-up and, as a result, an additional 34,700 low income families will receive an average gain of $55 per week-a massively important change for those people who are in need and who deserve as much assistance as this community can give them. Family allowance supplement and additional pension and benefit will be integrated. These payments are currently, as the House knows, paid separately to low income working families, pensioners and beneficiaries. Their integration will encourage and assist pensioners and beneficiaries to move into the work force.

As part of the integration process, guardians' allowance will be paid to sole parents receiving FAS. This will provide an additional $13.90 a week to 22,000 sole parent families. The additional pensioner or benefit component will now be paid, as I have said, to the primary care giver, directing a greater proportion of income support to the person taking the major responsibility for children-generally the mother.

The families package is another illustration of this Government delivering a Labor Budget. As I have said, we continue to deliver on the Labor equation. In these times, the intrinsic worth, merit, decency and equity of these decisions should be recognised and contrasted with the proposals of an Opposition which talks about slashing $3 billion off government expenditure. Who would suffer from those cuts? It would be the poor and the needy. That is the difference between this Government and the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to his forecast for the CPI to increase through the year by 3 3/4 per cent. Would the Treasurer explain to the House how this is consistent with a wage growth of 6 1/2 per cent through the year, or did he base the CPI forecast on the 5 per cent wage figure that he agreed with the ACTU?

—The average wage forecast through the year and at the end point is calculated on the basis of assumptions about what will happen in the labour market. There is some room for disagreement in what the outcome will be; but, basically, we have an agreed aggregate wage outcome factored into the Budget figuring. We do not want to say that 5 per cent wages equals 5 per cent CPI. The Opposition seems to be making some rather silly connections with the figures. One of the things about the accord that the Opposition needs to understand--
—Opposition members can just give us a tick for the outcomes. They should look at the outcomes.
—Would you like a copy of the question?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!
—Opposition members should judge us by the outcomes: we always succeed.

—I ask the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services whether he can inform the House as to the beneficiaries of the better cities program. What initiatives are proposed, and what process will be employed to undertake the allocation of funds for the program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very conscious of the fact that the honourable member's electorate is one of the fringe areas in terms of Australian cities. From the point of view of residents, the question of the cost of infrastructure and the provision of services is not an academic question; it has an urgency about it.

ANSWER.PARA: The objectives of the better cities program are to reduce the costs of infrastructure-that would be of benefit to industry and, obviously, governments and households; to reduce the cost of housing and provide a better choice of housing style and location; to improve access to work and services; to seek to reduce pollution and congestion; and better transport systems.

We approach those objectives on the basis of a number of initiatives the Government has under way. We have the national housing strategy, which is the most comprehensive review of housing since 1944. Under my predecessor we experimented very successfully in the Green Street joint venture, and with State and local government and the housing industry we are beginning to demonstrate different approaches and new ideas in smart housing. We have developed the Australian model code for residential development, setting new standards for housing regulation. We have developed and are carrying out an urban public transport program of great significance for fringe areas. We have identified and begun a process of leasing Commonwealth land within urban areas.

A program of this kind cannot succeed in any way other than on the basis of a partnership between three levels of government. So the agreement at the Special Premiers Conference regarding the need for urban consolidation and for a more efficient and equitable approach to the provision and financing of urban infrastructure and in coordination and planning is a very significant agreement, as is the agreement of industry with levels of government to seek reform and efficiency in the housing industry.

In carrying forward this very significant agenda, we need to pursue a process that will be complex and time consuming, and one that will involve various levels of government. We will be able to build on the foundations I have mentioned, and I believe that by November we will be in a position to finalise agreement with the States on areas for development under the better cities program. We will be acting on the recommendations of the Indicative Planning Council regarding the release of urban land and the redevelopment of existing land. We will be able to work on the basis of the national housing strategy in approaching a more efficient supply of land and housing. We will work with State, local government and industry participants to achieve further advances in industry efficiency.

Out of the national housing strategy we will soon see a major document on efficiency in the housing industry. I believe that that document will be a blueprint for significant reform where the Government, together with the private sector, will be able to charter an emphasis on efficiency so that quality housing can be produced at an affordable price.

We live in the country which, of all countries, has the greatest interest in reform of our cities. One cannot carry out that reform on a single level of government. One needs to approach it on the basis of partnership. One needs to involve other levels of government and the private sector. Because something is complex or difficult, or because it would take some years to achieve, is no reason not to start.

If there is a difference between this Government and the Opposition it is that we have been prepared in terms of Government policy to tackle problems that involve complexity, significant reform and other levels of government. It is one thing to parrot platitudes about so-called micro-economic reform; it is another to produce a national freight corporation; it is another to produce a national electricity supply network; it is another to produce significant waterfront reform; it is another to produce significant reform in the structure of our cities.

The Government has made a clear commitment, which it approaches on the basis of partnership with the States. The States will have no faith in those opposite, but I think they understand from this Government that we will be able to carry through a process of reform that will make a great difference to the quality of life in Australian cities and will help to achieve, on the basis of both new and existing infrastructure, very significant reforms in the efficiency of Australian cities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to the Forward Estimates for government expenditure which are based on a wages assumption that, as stated in his Budget, public sector wages and salaries are assumed to grow in line with award wages with productivity related increases being granted in the early part of the Forward Estimates period. Would the Treasurer inform the House of the wage assumptions that were used for the Estimates? Will he explain to the House how he was able to do this calculation when, as he has admitted in Question Time today, the Government does not have a wages policy?

—There seems to be an assumption that somehow a 6 1/2 per cent through-the-year figure and a 4 1/2 to 5 per cent year average figure are in opposition. The reality is that the 2.5 per cent awarded in the last financial year will not flow through until this year. It is a question of timing that centres on the differences between the 4 1/2 per cent and the 6 1/2 per cent. As we are heading into a more devolved wages system centring on workplace bargaining based on achieved productivity, it is a lot harder to calculate exactly what the aggregate wage outcome is going to be. We believe that the estimate is likely to come in at around 4 1/2 per cent. That is for the bottom range of the Estimates, but the estimate is 4 1/2 per cent. All figures in the Budget are based on that figure.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. He will be aware that much of the public comment and, in some cases, criticism of yesterday's Budget centres on the issue of unemployment. It is an issue that is of interest and concern to all members of this Government. What is the likely effect of the new initiatives on the unemployed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset-as the honourable gentleman knows, I have said this on many occasions, both personally and behalf of this Government-that we deeply regret the fact that we had to take the decisions that were taken and the pain that has undoubtedly been caused for many Australians in that process. As the honourable gentleman knows, we were faced with a situation where-given the lack of symmetry between growth in expenditure and growth in production-if we in this country had not made the decisions that we did to slow down the economy, then the world would have imposed a far more painful adjustment on us.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no question other than that unemployment is a tragedy. The fact is that real jobs cannot be created tomorrow; they cannot be created overnight; they cannot be created, as I think the honourable gentleman appreciates and agrees, by artificial pump priming, nor may I say in respect of those opposite can jobs be created by a process of massive slashing of government expenditures. That is a recipe for further disaster in this country. Mr Speaker, as you would appreciate, the policies that we have followed have significantly reduced inflation and the current account deficit. We believe that this provides the only basis for sustainable growth in the creation of new jobs.

I think the point of the question by the honourable member and his interest comes from the transition to recovery. This Budget again demonstrates the commitment of this Government to social justice and a structural adjustment through a further transition and expansion in labour market programs. We are not simply saying, `Here is something that had to be done to slow the economy down'; we are undertaking massive changes and improvements in relevant labour market programs to deal with the problem of the unemployed and to put them in a better position to take advantage of the recovery that will undoubtedly come.

The key Budget measures, together with the substantial package that was announced in the March 1991 statement, provide for an increase in expenditure on labour market programs from $399m in 1990-91 to an estimated $598m in this financial year of 1991-92-in other words, almost exactly a 50 per cent increase in expenditure on labour market programs.

There will be an expansion of the Jobskills program introduced in the March statement to provide training and work experience to 9,000 long term unemployed people. The training and skills program, TASK, will assist firms to retain employees in danger of retrenchment and provide them with industry related or basic workplace skills at a cost of some $15m in this financial year.

I know that the honourable gentleman will be pleased to understand that in addition to that about $420m has been allocated to TAFE, including $40m in 1991-92 for extra TAFE places. A further $180m has been allocated to entry level in skills training, including $12m for measures to keep apprentices and trainees in employment. Those measures, as I know the honourable gentleman will appreciate, are designed to strengthen the skills of job seekers and workers, and thereby hasten their return to employment, and to ensure that skill shortages do not emerge in the recovery. From past experience we know the tragedy of coming out of a recession where employers have got rid of their apprentices that there has not been the skills base to take advantage of that recovery. That is what happened in 1982-83, and by these measures we are ensuring that will not happen again under this Government.

For those in extreme financial crisis, the Government has allocated an additional $3m for emergency relief over each of the next two financial years. We have also reduced waiting periods for rent assistance for the unemployed.

In contrast to that relevant, compassionate and constructive series of measures which this Government is undertaking to deal with this problem, we are confronted with the hypocrisy of the Opposition which is portraying itself as having some concern for the less fortunate in the community. Mr Speaker, let me put this confected concern in its right perspective. It was, after all, this Leader of the Opposition who said on 19 October 1989:
Clearly, most of the long term unemployed will be expected to accept jobs that they would otherwise find unacceptable or live by their own means.

In other words, get out on the street and beg. That is the policy; that is the concept; that is the lack of concern of the Leader of the Opposition. What the Opposition would do in respect of the long term unemployed would be to cut off the unemployment benefit after nine months-just throw them onto the street. That is the concern of honourable members opposite. That is the revelation of the hypocrisy of honourable gentlemen opposite when they stand up in this place and pretend to be concerned about the unemployed in this country. The Opposition's policies are a prescription for a massive increase in unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Standing order 145 refers to relevance, and the question by the honourable member for Capricornia referred to the likely effects of the new initiatives on unemployment. It was a very specific question and the Prime Minister is doing what all the other Ministers have done; he has tried to take snipes at the Opposition. I would ask that he get back to the question.

—Order! I might remind the honourable member for Isaacs that one should not use a spurious point of order as a mechanism to attack somebody else. The Prime Minister was asked a question; the Prime Minister is answering the question.

—I simply conclude by making this point: the policies of those opposite are an inevitable prescription for a massive increase in unemployment. Not only would they massively increase unemployment in this country but also, having done that, they would throw the unemployed onto the street.

—I refer the Treasurer to the forecast 1991-92 Budget deficit of $4.7 billion. I ask the Treasurer: is it not true that, after taking into account $625m in asset sales, a $2.3 billion transfer of maturing debt to the States, $1.1 billion of net payments from government business enterprise superannuation and $1.9 billion in additional profit transfers from the Reserve Bank and the Commonwealth Bank, the actual deficit is $10.7 billion in 1991-92?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Technically there are about seven ways of defining Budget deficits, but we have been adopting consistent processes. Let us take them one by one.
—Your guess is as good as mine.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has asked his question. He should listen to the answer in silence.

—On asset sales we have factored in a rather conservative figure, given the behaviour of the Opposition last year when it knocked off the sale of the Pipeline Authority, even though it was Opposition policy to sell it. That is what happened in the Senate. We have put in conservative figures this year. It is mainly represented by asset sales with respect to the airlines industry.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the Commonwealth Bank, there was no payment in 1990-91. That was deferred because of the upcoming float, which was very successful. In terms of the Reserve Bank, that figure is from 1990-91; it is not 1991-92. In terms of State debt, last year $1 billion was put onto the surplus; this year $2 billion will go onto the deficit. That will be a continuing process because we now have the States being responsible for their own debt. When we get into better or different arrangements between the Commonwealth Government and the State governments, those opposite will see these figures change.

The implication in the honourable gentleman's question is really that we should be cutting a lot more out of this Budget. All we know about where he would cut is that he would cut foreign aid and the ABC. If that is the case, I hope he has checked with Senator Robert Hill and Mr David Hill because, if the Opposition cuts both of them out, the hills will be alive with the sound of Hills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Will the Minister inform the House of specific measures in the Budget that will assist farm families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Against the overall Budget context, I think there are some important initiatives that relate not just to farm families but to the rural sector generally. They are proposals that reflect initiatives that I said, on assuming this portfolio, I wanted to pursue. The overall Budget context will lock in the low inflation result we have achieved to date to ensure that those benefits, in terms of lower costs, flow on to the farmers.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me come to some of the areas that I think are important. So far as social justice is concerned, we need to understand that in the area of assets tests and family support this Government has come to grips with the problem of people who are asset rich but income poor. For two years it has developed a program that will do this. This initiative will mean that for each family whose income is below the level of $13,078, plus $624 for each child-somewhere around $14,000-and who meets the liquid assets test, the asset test on family allowance will be waived. Not only will they get access to the $10 per kid that is associated with the family allowance but, in addition, they will get access to the family allowance supplement.

For those who do not understand the difference, the family allowance produces $10 per week; the family allowance supplement produces amounts between $26.50 and $38.65 a week. The Government has raised the asset test threshold to $600,000 to enable people at the income level I have described to get not just the family allowance but the family allowance supplement as well.

That is what we have done in terms of family support mechanisms-and the Deputy Leader of the National Party had the gall to say yesterday in the matter of public importance that we had done nothing for them. I hope that part of the record is set straight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said--
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the National Party will resume his seat.

—The second thing I have heard them say is that we have done nothing for farm families in terms of extending the Austudy payments and payments for children in isolated circumstances. The fact is that this Government has extended and simplified access to those payments. It has wiped the asset test, where it currently exists at $695,000-special treatment for the farm sector-but it has wiped it in circumstances in which people qualify for the hardship provisions under social security and in circumstances in which they are receiving income support under part C of RAS.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition should not give us this rubbish about no extension of Austudy payments and of meeting the concern. In addition to this package--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Deputy Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.

—I will come to the unemployment question too because there is an important package of initiatives for farm families-if the honourable member cares to read the detail of the Budget-in relation to economic development in rural and provincial areas. It is a package of three proposals, costing $4.3m per annum, that develops agricultural and related business activities, particularly those that are export oriented and those that develop value adding activities. The honourable member should look at the detail of it. In addition, we have provided $500,000 to ABARE to extend its survey analysis to enable us to identify where the particular--

—The honourable member cannot do that because the NFF came to us direct. It is rubbish to suggest that we can do it now. He should talk to the NFF if he does not believe it. The NFF said to us, `On the basis of the information that is available to us, we simply cannot identify the crisis areas and target the need'. We have provided $500,000-the NFF will put in $100,000; that is how serious it is about this-to make sure that we have that information.

ANSWER.PARA: The final part of the package which I draw the honourable member's attention to is a series of measures and additional expenditures that aim at more effective resource management of the land through additional moneys, through the landcare groups, through soil conservation and through water management. I simply make the point that if those on the other side are prepared to look at the detail rather than just whinge they will see that there are important opportunities in this Budget for people in the rural sector. We have looked after them; those opposite have done nothing to advance constructive solutions on their side.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do?
—Order! If the Deputy Leader of the National Party interjects again, I will deal with him.

—My question is again directed to the Treasurer and relates to the 5 per cent occupational superannuation levy. I refer the Treasurer to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 16 August 1991 which said that Treasury has calculated that this policy will boost the inflation rate by two percentage points. I ask the Treasurer: what compensation package is to be introduced to offset this large CPI effect on pensioners and other low income earners?
—This is a nonsense question and it does not even deserve an answer.
—Can the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories tell the House what new initiatives are in this year's Budget for the environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I can see the enthusiasm of the Opposition on this important issue of the environment. Unlike the Opposition, the Government regards the environment as an incredibly high priority. That was reflected in the Budget brought down yesterday afternoon, which sees a substantial increase in funding for money into the environment and builds on the work already done in the environment area over the last eight Budgets.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the key things we have done is create an environment protection agency which will provide the foundations and the structure to implement the recommendations of the ecological sustainable development process. The establishment of the environment protection agency adds a new emphasis to the environment portfolio. It puts an emphasis on the urban areas where most Australians live and work; it puts an emphasis on clean air and water; it puts an emphasis on trying to obtain more information in relation to these areas of urban pollution; it puts a new emphasis on state of the environment reporting; and it puts a new emphasis on a national approach to the waste minimisation industry and the issue of waste minimisation and recycling. It is long overdue. I think the Opposition should congratulate the Government on this very important initiative because most Australians will be.
The second area is that of endangered species. We have doubled our money into this very important area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—This shows how little they appreciate this very important area. Luckily, most Australians do.
—Who did you vote for?
—The honourable member for Gippsland!

—In that area we have doubled our money to $5m. The emphasis will be on implementing a national strategy. But, very importantly, there will be a substantial recovery program once the species that are endangered are identified.

ANSWER.PARA: Due to the representations of the honourable member for the Northern Territory, we are putting $2m into mimosa control in the areas surrounding Kakadu. Very importantly, in our continued program of developing areas of world heritage around Australia, $16.5m over three years will go into the area of Fraser Island. Additional money will also go to the Great Barrier Marine Park Authority for additional research. I know that the relevant members are particularly delighted about that.

I think another emphasis is very important. We have been dealing with the natural environment over the last eight years. We have now put an emphasis on cleaning up the waste area. But the other area that I think is incredibly important is the marine conservation area. We have put money into the development of marine conservation with marine parks being jointly developed with the State governments around Australia. In that area we are fulfilling responsibility to the environment, not just in regard to land but also in regard to marine areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to direct a question to you concerning the application of standing order 91 and the Budget debate televising arrangements. Is it a fact that standing order 91 makes special provision for the Leader of the Opposition, or a member deputed by the Leader of the Opposition, speaking in response to Government Bills and that in respect of the main Appropriation Bill for the year the special provision is for unlimited time? Is it also a fact that the practice of the House is where the first speaker in response is an Opposition member who is not the Opposition Leader or a shadow Minister deputed by the Leader, the special provisions are applied to the Leader of the Opposition or deputed member when he or she participates in the debate?

QUESTION.PARA: Secondly, can you confirm that the conditions governing the televising of proceedings require a fair and balanced presentation of proceedings and that this has always been a condition of access to our proceedings? Would this, in your view, indicate that any agency or group which chose to televise or broadcast `live' proceedings connected with the 1991-92 Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) would also, in the interest of fairness, be expected to televise or broadcast live the response to the Budget by the Leader of the Opposition?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a quick look at standing order 91 which, for the information of honourable members, covers two and a bit pages of the Standing Orders. Standing order 91 does provide under the line `Second reading of a bill' that for the main Appropriation Bill for the year the mover, who in this case was the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), can speak for an unspecified time; and that the Leader of the Opposition or one member deputed by him can speak for an unspecified time. From my recollection, this is usually the amount of time that the Treasurer took to deliver his statement. So, under that standing order, the Leader of the Opposition would get that time whenever he made his speech.

INTERJECT.PARA: I am not aware of any provision-though someone may be able to point out to me some precedent-that requires the Leader of the Opposition to lead. If someone other than the Leader of the Opposition rises when that Bill is brought in, I would call that member.

As far as televising goes, a number of statements in the rules for the taking of excerpts and the feed for televising the House relate to fairness, and those rules imply that there should be balance in what happens. In the past when the Budget debate or other important matters have been televised, the channels that have taken one side live have taken the other side live. My own view, which might not be the view of others and might not even be the view of the House, is that if a news organisation took one side live in any of those debates, either now or in the future, in fairness it probably should take the other side.

As to the other parts of the honourable member's question, I can only say there is no compulsion that I can impose on news media; it is up to them to do or take what they wish to do or take. I would not think that matter comes within the ambit of the guidelines I have laid down for the televising of Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, my question is directed to you. Given the current crisis in the Soviet Union, would you give consideration to reconnecting the CNN news service feed to Parliament House?

—I thank the honourable member for Stirling for that question. A number of members have raised this issue with me. The President and I have been negotiating with CNN and looking at our own resources and ways we could get the CNN feed into the building. Honourable members will recall that we had it during the Gulf crisis. That was by an arrangement with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The cost for us to get the feed in on a permanent basis is about $120,000 to $150,000 per annum, so it is not a cheap service.
—Is the honourable member for Kooyong offering to pay for it?
—You are being paid something like that and you aren't doing much of a job. Why don't you give the money away?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —On my estimation the taxpayers probably get better value from me than they do from the honourable member for Kooyong. I am sure that if the honourable member for Kooyong agreed to have a vote on that right now I would win; I can assure him I would win. I am quite happy for him to move the proposition right now.

INTERJECT.PARA: As far as the CNN news is concerned, I have spoken to the Sound and Vision Office and we think that for about $10,000 we can have it put on for this month. If we can get it put on, I think that is a worthwhile expenditure to keep us up to date with what is happening in the Soviet Union. If we can get it connected, we will do our best to have it connected today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, further to the question directed to you by the honourable member for Hume, should news or television companies which transmitted the Treasurer's speech live not transmit the response from the Leader of the Opposition? On the basis of a demonstrated lack of fair play, would that preclude them from transmitting further affairs from the Parliament in the future?
—No, it would not.

—Mr Speaker, I ask you a question that comes within your responsibility. Could you advise the Parliament of the cost of the settlement apparently negotiated with members of the catering staff of this place? Is that sum to be allocated from the existing vote to Parliament or are the funds to be sought from a supplementary estimate?

—As I mentioned to the House earlier this morning-I do not think the right honourable member for New England was here then-there has been a settlement proposition put between the Trades and Labour Council of the Australian Capital Territory, the President and me. —I think all honourable members might be interested.
