DEBATE.TITLE: DISCUSSION OF MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government's economic strategy to give Australians any real hope of improved living standards, employment opportunities and an end to the worst recession in 60 years.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time today, we saw a bumbling, trembling and ill-informed performance from the reluctant new Treasurer (Mr Kerin). I must say that I feel sorry for him. He has inherited Australian industry as a smoking ruin; he has inherited this desolate landscape at a time when the Government is hopelessly divided over the leadership. It is a Government that cannot even agree on who should lead it let alone agree on an economic strategy that will lead Australia out of the worst recession we have had for 60 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer is a reasonable bloke-a fair dinkum bloke, I think, by most standards. His frankness is a refreshing change from the hyperbole that his predecessor constantly inflicted upon us. But quite frankly, an honest attempt is just not good enough. This Budget has left Australia marking time when it has no time to lose. When the Treasurer rose to his feet yesterday to deliver his first Budget, the people of this country were looking to him not only for relief from this terrible recession but also for a clearly defined course for our future, but he failed them. They were looking to him in the most basic terms for a pointer on where the exit door is to this recession, and he did not raise a finger. They were looking for a strategy that would promote investment, and he told them that investment would fall. They were looking for something that would create jobs, and he told them that the dole queues would grow.

When the economic data is screaming a message at us that calls for fundamental reform, the Government's only response has been a Budget that promises more of the same. This Budget does not help Australia out of the hospital bed of recession; it beds the economy down for a long term coma. To the new Treasurer I say genuinely that he does his country a disservice. This is a good country. We have good people, we have tremendous natural resources and we have a stable political system. This country can have a good future. But it has been badly managed and it desperately requires some fundamental changes that will give us some hope and vision for the future.

In any Budget there are some measures that are better than others. In this Budget there were some measures which I think were reasonable-measures designed to help people who have suffered the burden of this recession. Benefits in the family allowance area will provide some people with some relief. In the Medicare area-perhaps the biggest decision for the Government-I think the Government has generally moved in the right direction.

But when we weigh up the good and the bad, not surprisingly the Budget has been widely condemned. We have only to look at a few of the headlines in the Sydney Morning Herald, such as `Why Kerin's Budget Fails'; or to listen to Bob Carr, the leader of the Labor Opposition in New South Wales, who says that there is precious little hope for the unemployed in this document and it is indefensible in Labor terms. Merle Mitchell of ACOSS I thought put it well when she said:
The Budget confirms that unemployment will get even worse in the coming months. The Government's response to this massive social and economic problem is woefully inadequate.
It sums up the general response, the condemnation from so many quarters of the Australian community based on their judgment of this Budget.

I want to pick up just three or four key issues in the Budget which I think highlight some of the problems which we face in this nation and which point the way to some of the solutions that I think we need to be adopting as a matter of urgency. The basic failure of this Budget is that the 831,000 Australians who are out of work today have been given no better chance of obtaining a job tomorrow and, even worse, their children have been given no better chance of gaining employment in the future.

I substantiate that claim in two ways: firstly, by looking at the Government's own figures; and, secondly, by looking at the implications, the consequences, of this new superannuation levy or tax. I also substantiate it, not in a statistical sense, but on the basis of what people are telling me every day of the week about what is happening in their businesses and the likelihood of putting off staff in the months ahead. I do not believe that Labor backbenchers are getting any message other than the message that is clear, anecdotally, to us.

The first point is to look at the unemployment numbers simply on the basis of the Government's own projections. We have run these figures and the superannuation figures through the parliamentary statistics group. If one looks first at the Government's projected figures, and uses its participation rates for the year ahead, one will see unemployment rise, not to the 900,000 that the Treasurer very glibly brushed aside during Question Time today but, based on the level of 10.75 per cent, something like 920,000 to 948,000 unemployed.

I hand to the Treasurer a table which we had prepared in the Parliamentary Library. We believe that, even on the Treasurer's own projections, unemployment will go through that 10.75 figure and rise to at least 11 per cent.

The second aspect of the unemployment issue is that the new superannuation tax will unquestionably add further to this increase in unemployment. We have done our work carefully so that we have a substantial proposition to put to the Treasurer. We have done the work on the basis of using Dr Chris Murphy's model, which has been made available to the Parliamentary Library. Dr Murphy is highly regarded. He used to be the chief modeller or forecaster in the Treasury, so he has a good background in the Treasurer's own Department. Furthermore, he is now a respected academic at the ANU. Interestingly, the work that he did at Treasury, of course, has been carried on, and in that sense the work that has been made available to the Treasurer has as its derivative the work originally done by Dr Murphy. My belief is that the results that we have are very close to those the Treasurer himself has had.

When the press reports came out last week about the likely shape of the Treasurer's superannuation policy, we put the 5 per cent across the board just to see the implications. It came up with an absolutely staggering figure: that with one decision, by one stroke of the pen, by one dirty deal done one night with the ACTU, the Treasurer would add to the unemployment queues in this country something like 101,000 people by the year 1993-94. Furthermore, there will be an inflation impact, on that assumption, of somewhere between 2 and 4.8 per cent. I recoiled at that figure. It seemed staggering that the Government should proceed down that track.

Yesterday when the figures were revealed we saw that the Government had introduced a transition period. I have no doubt that one of the Treasurer's advisers said, `You can't introduce a policy that deliberately increases unemployment by 100,000, and you ought to have some transition arrangement for small business', which the Treasurer has done and which was announced yesterday.

We also put that through the model to see the implications. A very interesting result was obtained. On our calculations-and they are pretty conservative-that transitional effect and measure will see an addition to the unemployment figures of somewhere between 42,700 and 45,200. So in the transitional period, the figure is up towards 45,000, but over the longer term, because the Treasurer's measure is only transitional, the 100,000 is still a very relevant figure.

What made me fairly certain about the accuracy of our projections was that we took out the inflationary impact on that transitional measure. It is interesting that our result was 2.1 per cent, because we know, as a result of a leak in the Sydney Morning Herald, that the advice the Treasurer has received from Treasury was a figure of 2 per cent. Our figures are very close; clearly we are working on the same basis.

Here is the ironical twist in this Budget: we all know that tax reform is one of the many keys that need to be employed to turn this economy around and that it will provide more jobs, higher investment and higher living standards in due course. The only issue really on tax reform is: who has the guts to publicly advocate something that is in this country's long term interest?

Our hypocritical Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is now opposed to tax reform, because he has made exaggerated claims about the one-off CPI effect of such a measure. Yet here he is adopting such a measure in this Budget, with a transitional effect of at least 2.1 per cent. Why the hypocrisy? Very simply, the difference between us and those opposite is that in our tax reform package we will compensate people through offsetting pension increases and lower personal tax as a result of the policy decisions that we have taken.

The Government has the gall to attack us for that when it is now introducing a policy change without one skerrick of compensation for the low income earners and disadvantaged who will be affected by this change. That is outrageous. That is gross hypocrisy, and I look forward to the Government's response on it.

That is not the end of the matter. The Medicare charges are directed to problems of over-servicing, and I think that is a step in the right direction. But there is no gap insurance to offset that and, certainly, no offsetting for the CPI effect. The Government is deliberately putting people out of work, slugging low income earners and the disadvantaged and offering no offsetting changes that would provide people with opportunities or help. It is no wonder that in a moment of frankness last week, when asked about the future of this economy, this Treasurer said, `Your guess is as good as mine'.

The second point I want to make briefly about this Budget concerns the impact of fiscal policy and the developments we have seen in respect of fiscal policy. One cannot, in any sense, understate the importance of this. We need to get interest rates down in this country. High real interest rates are the instrument this Government has used to bring on the recession. If we are to get interest rates down, one of the things that is an absolute imperative for this economy is to boost our national savings. What have we seen in recent years as a result of the impact of Government policy on savings? We have seen a massive deterioration in the contribution of the Commonwealth to the national savings effort.

In recent times we have seen a massive increase in the public sector borrowing requirement. We had a surplus a couple of years ago of 1.6 per cent of GDP in 1988-89; now, in 1991-92, it is 4.3 per cent, on the Government's own rubbery figures, and that is a huge turnaround of a dimension we have not really seen in this country for many years. It is Whitlamesque, to put it in a broader historical context.
In terms of national savings, the Treasurer ought to read the national accounts from the last quarter, because they say:
A feature of the preliminary 1990-91 estimates is the large decline in national saving, from $24.2 billion in 1989-90 to $9.3 billion 1990-91.
The rub for the Government's policy is where the accounts state:
Household saving fell by about $3.4 billion. However, more significant falls were in the general government surplus on current account.

The Government has been pulling money out of national savings. In fact, the Government has not only got its hand in the pool of national savings; it has got its arm in right up to its armpits. This means higher interest rates for people who are paying mortgages and people who are trying to build up businesses.

A third feature of the Budget which I thought was worth commenting upon concerned the changes to the pension payment system in Veterans' Affairs. It has been the subject of a lot of controversy within Labor ranks-so much so that, if there was any question as to whether it was a good policy or not, one would be convinced by the fact that Senator Richardson is so opposed to it that he has been leaking his correspondence on the issue. He says about this decision to contract out a service:

It has effectively prevented us from countering the Opposition's plans to contract out welfare services. The telling points we were able to make about pensioners having to queue up in the foyers of major accountancy firms to have their pensions processed cannot be used any longer.

It is a telling point, and a relevant point. Of the savings that are available-of which there are many in Commonwealth expenditures-a big area of savings is to contract out more services. We accept the Government's acquiescence in the point that we made last year and that was so strongly made by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) as he responded to the criticisms of the Government on that basic point. That is one of the savings that could have been achieved if the Government had gone further.

I conclude by saying that there are many things in this Budget, but there are many things not in this Budget. What we did not have was some vision, some sense of incentive, some sense of hope for the Australian people. The Government could have undertaken major tax reform or given some incentive back to the system. It could have removed the tax on investment, which would have provided jobs and underpinned a long term recovery. It could have taken the tax off exports, if it were prepared to be bolder in tax reform. It could have moved further in industrial relations. It could have moved further by announcing a decent program of micro-economic reform that would build the productivity of this nation. It could have moved further in privatisation. Frankly, the Treasurer's first Budget is not good enough. It is a major disappointment. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) referred to leadership in the Australian Labor Party. I assure him that we will not repeat the example of the Liberal Party of Australia with the Howard-Peacock twostep, where they used to swap leaders at whim. From what I hear about leadership, the space we have to watch is not my side of the House but the one opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: One point picked up by the honourable gentleman related to a statement I made the other day at a press conference. I happily admit that the words could have been better chosen. The question was: `So, Mr Kerin, do you think we are going to bumble along the bottom for a while?'. This was the third question in this vein about the turning point in the recession, as we come out of the recession into recovery. My answer was: `Well, basically your guess is as good as mine. I will be making the most accurate assessment I can of that in the Budget statements next week'. That is what I did yesterday.

If anyone seriously thinks that any Treasurer, any economic forecaster, any economist can pick exactly when an economy will turn or is turning-when there are leading indicators and lagging indicators; when any exogenous shock, some external shock from overseas, can affect an economy; when we never know what price we will get for wheat or what the Europeans or the Americans will do-he is pulling someone's leg.

I well recall 1984, when we pulled this economy out of the Fraser-induced recession, where they had not only 10 per cent unemployment but also 12 per cent inflation. Mr Fraser lost his nerve and increased outlays in his last Budget by 7 per cent. There was panic from Howard and panic from Fraser. That is what those opposite did. I recall when we had to pull the economy out of recession then. In 1984 we were wondering when the economy would turn.

With hindsight, it had turned six months previously-at some time early in 1984. That is what I was getting at. There is enough evidence to say that the economy is turning and will certainly turn through the rest of the financial year. I was at pains to point out in my Budget Speech yesterday that the signs are tentative, they may remain so for some time, and the recovery will be slow.

The national account figures for the June quarter-and those are the figures that are most subject to revision-showed that recovery would be slower than some people had expected. They showed that the climb was much less in the second half of 1990-91 than in the first half of the financial year just past. Surveys of business and consumer confidence also show a bottoming out. The rate of housing loans and approvals has risen. The full effects of the eight interest rate cuts we have put in place since January 1990 still have not been felt. Exports are up and imports are down. We are getting on top of our current account deficit problem. Inflation is low, very low, and will continue to be, due to the cooperation of the trade union movement, the ACTU, award labour, through the accord. The Budget is, above all else, fiscally responsible.

Much of the debate about this Budget is whether we should have spent more money or cut more. The people opposite can only ever think of one thing-that we should cut and cut and cut the Budget and cut wages. It does not matter whether the economy is booming, whether we are doing very well overseas. It does not matter what sort of economic parameters we have in place, what the settings are, what the behaviour of the economy is. The only answer the people opposite ever have is to cut. There is not a word about what this Government has gone through in managing the economy against the external shocks.

We had to pull this economy out of recession; we had to cope with that massive terms of trade downturn in 1985 and 1986; we had to cope through the 1987 stock market crash; we had to cope with the boom again in 1988 and 1989; and now we have another terms of trade decline. Through all that period of massive assets price boom in the late eighties-through that period of corporate excesses and other excesses by people in the economy other than award labour-there was not a word from the Opposition. It was always the white shoe brigade who were inviolate. The conservative forces in this country were even backing Joh for Canberra in 1987. That is how bereft of ideas, ideals and views of Australia they were.

We also went through that enormous assets price boom. We were importing too much and we were getting more and more into debt to people overseas. The Commonwealth Government debt, of course, is quite low-the public debt is reasonably low. The private debt in this country is quite immense.

The terms of economic management at this time are such that we really do have to be very fiscally responsible. Some people, including the Opposition, are saying we should cut a lot more, as well as put on a big new tax, which is the Opposition's cure-all. The other thing is that others are saying we should spend a lot more money on job creation programs. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who has just sat down, said that nothing in the Budget will give an extra job today. Nothing he said would give an extra job today-even if the Opposition had cut all that out of the Budget. The effects of this Budget will be effects six months down the track. That is why it is a matter of judgment.

There is a turnaround in terms of the amount of money we are spending of $6.63 billion over the 30 June outcome of last financial year. The Budget surplus came in at about $1.9 billion. With a $4.7 billion deficit in this Budget, there is $6.63 billion feeding into this economy. We all know, of course, that employment is the last indicator to turn. Therefore, that is a matter of judgment, too-whether or not we need to pump up the economy now, which may be pro-cyclical if, indeed, the economy is turning around, as we believe it is. We understand that the avenues for investment at present are low due to the massive asset price boom that we have just gone through, because the effects of that have to wash through the system. One only has to talk to people in the financial sector to understand the level of non-performing loans.

The Opposition quite cheerfully ignores the fact that the financial sector has massive problems due to that massive assets price boom through the 1980s. It somehow ignores the fact that we have royal commissions looking into the activities of two of our banks at present. We have taken the decision not to pump prime beyond that amount. That is really about shock absorbing the recession. We believe that we will come out of it.

There is investment going into the mining industry because the prospects are good. The farm sector is very flat because of the terrible prices overseas. There is not going to be any investment in non-dwelling construction. The central business districts of the cities are full of office blocks unsold, which are all the result of the asset price boom. So there is no sense in us putting in figures or thinking that if we give massive investment allowances, depreciation allowances or massive company tax cuts this is going to suddenly turn the economy around and, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said, give us jobs tomorrow.

We have to act fiscally responsibly. There has never been a Budget that has been greeted well. If we had cut more or spent more, we would have been regarded as fiscally irresponsible. What we set out to do, as was quite clear in terms of this Government's Budget strategy, was to take into account the cyclical effects of the recession, to compensate people for those effects and to allow the economy to gradually turn around, with domestic demand factors driving the recovery-acknowledging that it would be slow.

If I could paraphrase what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is saying, it is really that the only people who can get some comfort out of unemployment and the economic recession are the perverse, the uncaring and, indeed, the Opposition. The shadow Treasurer's contribution to this MPI was pretty uninspiring, as we have now come to expect of him, and can be summed up in the phrase `the sour grapes of Reith'.

Let me quote from the terms of this MPI and concentrate on what he would do and what would `give Australians real hope of improved living standards and employment opportunities'. Let me remind the House of some of the brilliant changes that the shadow Treasurer thinks would improve living standards and create jobs. First of all he thinks he will slash outlays. He wants to terminate government advertising. Brilliant! Presumably this is the mushroom-led approach to economic recovery. He will sell the whole of Qantas, Australian Airlines and the AIDC. Brilliant-the `nation of little shareholders' approach to employment opportunities. Then he will cut or abolish the ABC. I do not know where the employment opportunities are in that. That is rather brilliant too. That goes along with the `if times are tough, murder your aunty' approach to recovery. Then of course he will introduce a consumption tax. Brilliant! Times are tough, so it is a `look after your own class and beggar the rest' approach to recovery.

What is all this nonsense about compensation? The Opposition still has not answered the charge by the Australian Taxpayers Association that, to be compensated for a consumption tax at 15 per cent, an income earner on $23,000 would require a 63 per cent tax cut. This whole question of imposing a consumption tax on the Australian people and cutting government spending as some magic solution to provide jobs is absolute vapid nonsense. It will not provide any jobs. How will taxing the poor people more and cutting government spending give more jobs?

We heard all this nonsense over the years of not wanting to crowd out the private sector, so what did we do? We brought in four record Budget surpluses, the first time that has been achieved since 1953. We brought in more reform. But no, that was never enough-all we had to do was cut wages, cut government spending. They are the only things that honourable gentlemen opposite know. Just think of this consumption tax. Honourable members opposite are now running around the country saying that, after all, there is a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will abolish wholesale sales tax.

—Yes, but wholesale sales tax is not the same as a retail tax. Of the goods bought from supermarket shelves, 70 per cent are not covered by the wholesale sales tax. It is as if honourable members opposite think somehow that a wholesale tax equates to a consumption tax. They are taken at a different stage. The difference between the two depends on the retail mark-up, or the percentage retail margin used. It is nonsense for those opposite to run around telling this to people. There is no need to run any scare campaign. They are setting up this straw man about our supposedly running a scare campaign on the consumption tax. When honourable members opposite have the guts to tell the people what it is really all about, the people will not be scared; they will be terrified by what those opposite are saying.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an absolute nonsense to talk about compensation. There is simply no way people can be compensated if a consumption tax at the level of 15 per cent is put on. There is simply no way; the figures do not add up. Here we have a major political party saying to the Australian people in a recession that they will impose a consumption tax, that they will cut government spending and that somehow this will create jobs.

This Budget is a responsible Budget. It does take people into account. It is a responsible Budget in terms of its fiscal integrity and in terms of its fiscal responsibility. This Budget provides support for low income families through this depression, especially those with kids, and that is why the families package has been put together. Outlays on assistance to families with children have increased from $3,208m in 1983-84 to an estimated $6.106 billion in 1991-92. As ever and as with all our social reforms, payments have been targeted to those most in need. That is where the compensation comes from in our budgetary approach, not by this imposition of a tax right across the board which means that people cannot possibly be compensated.

Between March 1983 and January 1991, for low income families, support for children under 13 increased in real terms by 54 per cent and for teenage children by 125 per cent. That is our approach. We are looking after people and we are putting the economy on track. We have still been able to initiate medium term reforms of great significance in health services, in cities, for the environment and, most significantly, in superannuation.

For a Labor government, the reform job is never finished, and no matter how tight the situation is, we will make sure that we take the necessary steps and the fundamental changes for our economy and for our society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It would seem that the game of puns is catching to those who pass through the Primary Industries portfolio. Today we had two from the ex-Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, now the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), namely, `The hills will be alive with the sound of Hills', and `The sour grapes of Reith'. He will have to do a lot better than that, because in referring to foreign aid, by way of first response, let me say that his Government has increased foreign aid to countries beyond our region-beyond Asia, beyond the south-west Pacific-in a curious priority which does not reflect the coalition's priority or what intelligent people would want of an Australian foreign aid program. Our priorities on that particular aspect are correct. They will stand up to scrutiny and point the way forward for Australia to relate more to its region.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Treasurer's contribution, I do not dispute-nor does the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith)-that international factors have impacted on the Australian economy by degrees. But the truth of the matter is that the Australian economy went into recession ahead of the world recession. The truth of the matter is that many parts of the Australian economy are in a much deeper recession than those in similar OECD countries around the world. The very sad truth of the matter is that it is more than likely that we will come out of this recession after most OECD economies will have fired up. So we went in first, we went in deeper in terms of economic recessions, and we are going to be the last one out. We will suffer awful agony as a consequence, with so many people jobless, so many small business operators driven to the wall and so many farmers forced off their farms.

I address two other comments in the Treasurer's totally inadequate defence of a totally inadequate Budget-the Kerin-Keating Budget-which really does nothing for the jobless. He said, `All the coalition would do is put a new tax on'. He is referring to the fair goods and services tax in our tax reform package, which is all about more jobs and less taxation overall. His real crime is an intellectual one of some magnitude, because he knows in his heart that the correct course of action is the one that we are advocating-the abolition of sales tax, the abolition of indirect taxes on our hard pressed export industries, the boosting of the productive sector, and the tilting of the taxation system back in favour of the productive sector so that we will generate jobs, generate employment, and generate economic activity to turn this country around. So he has much to answer for.

The Treasurer is at variance with the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the ex-Treasurer-failed Treasurer Keating. Remember that man? Both of them in 1985 were out in the community trumpeting the goods and services tax of option C. What is more important, the Prime Minister said at that time in categorical terms that it is possible to properly compensate or offset in relation to the introduction of option C, a GST. So let us have more honesty from this Treasurer on this particular subject as we welcome him into the debating arena on the question of tax reform.

Clearly his Budget has failed on the question of tax reform. It maintains a $9 billion sales tax impost on Australians and Australian export industries in part. The total revenue collection remains at over $9 billion, with many millions of dollars on transport, freight and transport equipment, adding greatly to the cost overhead and overburden of so many people living in regional and remote Australia who are trying to survive in this recession we did not have to have.

Finally, the Treasurer referred to mining investment and how this was somehow magically picking up. I will deal with that more fully tomorrow. I simply say that mining investment in Australia is very fragile indeed. Even if the Government had the confidence to proceed and it seeks permission to go through all the processes, such as happened at Coronation Hill, it will create yet another umpire. The umpire reports and says that there will be no damage to the environment for proceeding with the renewed mining of Coronation Hill. It has already had 25,000 tonnes of ore taken out. It is easy to walk into the existing mined area of Coronation Hill. It would fit in an area which is smaller than the land that Parliament House occupies. I did so with Senator Grant Tambling 10 days ago.

Yet the Government stepped in and said, `Because of the prospect of Bula and a range of other factors, we are going to deny this economic activity boost to the top end of the Northern Territory. We are going to deny jobs to the people who would have been provided for by way of the increased economic activity flowing from Coronation Hill'. The Government said no; it vetoed Coronation Hill. What confidence did that give to the mining industry? Clearly, this Budget is totally inadequate. It is steady as she sinks. It is a return to the Whitlam-Uren type budgeting we saw in the early 1970s.

Where is the vision in this Budget? There is none. Where is the fundamental industrial relations reform in this Budget? There is none. Where are the responsible policy settings that pave the way for lower interest rates? There are none. The public sector borrowing requirement will increase massively, thus paving the way for interest rates to remain higher than the OECD average. Above all, where is the leadership required from Canberra, from this Government, in this Budget? Again, there is simply none. The crumbs we get were in part highlighted by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) in Question Time today, but that ought to be seen in perspective. Firstly, the Government is admitting that it was wrong last year with Keating's assets test proposal on family allowance. Secondly, it has driven the rural economy into such a deep recession that it has now had to come back with another package in relation to the assets test, the family allowance supplement and related matters.

The economic agony of Australia is set to continue under Labor as a consequence of this inadequate Budget. This is the only conclusion we can make from the Budget delivered by the Treasurer yesterday. The Government has simply given up its right to lead this country. It is more of the same-as the band strikes up the Australian ship of state steadily sinks. If honourable members think the Oceanos went down quickly, that is nothing compared to the economy. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) and I happened to be on board the Oceanos a few weeks ago but we got off before it went to South Africa and Davy Jones's locker.

Seriously, we all remember the last eight Budgets which were such a key component of our current economic plight. We remember in particular the 1988 Budget which was going to bring home the bacon. Some bacon! The Government should tell that to the jobless. Three years later the Government is proudly defending its Budget. After eight years of Labor we have a five-fold increase in foreign debt because of the Australia Inc. situation, which is equivalent to $8,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia.

I might add, to be fair, that there are a couple of positive measures in the Budget, but they are few and far between. Clearly, the point of direction on the National Rail Freight Corporation is one of those measures. Overall, it is a totally inadequate document, one which does not stack up for Australia or the jobless who hold little hope, little prospect, of returning to full time employment under the settings laid down by this Budget.

In many ways we can talk of Placido budgets, but we can also talk of placebo budgets. For those not in the medical profession, a placebo is a little sugar tablet which a doctor might prescribe but which does nothing for the patient. It is given to humour a patient rather than cure the ills. Treasurer Kerin has delivered a placebo Budget, a nothing Budget, a Budget which misses the point of the economic circumstance of so many Australians and leaves so many Australians facing absolute economic agony as a consequence.

The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), the coalition and I are committed to an economic reform agenda which stacks up for Australia, abolishes sales tax, lowers fuel taxation on business input fuel, mining, farming, fishing and tourism to tilt the taxation system of this country back towards the productive sector, but which also looks after the family. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) is not in the chamber. Had he been here I suspect that the level of the contribution from the Opposition would have been more significant than what we have seen today in this MPI debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Reith interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Flinders.

—The Opposition has floundered around in this MPI debate between a discussion on a response to the Budget and a discussion on the matter that it listed on the Notice Paper. This Government's record of enhancing the living standards of Australian citizens and Australian families is second to none.
—It is a disaster.
—I warn the member for Flinders.

—Over the life of this Government a number of initiatives have been introduced, invariably over the opposition of members opposite, which have all contributed to an enhanced quality of life for average Australians. In terms of economic management and the quality of life for Australians in an economic sense, there are three important criteria, of which the Budget is one.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget sets out the important fiscal policy measures of the Government. Monetary policy is clearly important, as is wages policy. The debate today focused heavily on the Budget and fiscal policy although there has been some comment about monetary policy which I also wish to address.

Mention has been made of interest rates and inflation in this country. It is worth recalling that interest rates have fallen by 7 1/2 per cent in the last year or so. Inflation is down to its lowest level in a generation. Home loans, often regarded as the important yardstick for the building industry, are now down to 13 per cent, a rate lower than the previously fixed home loan interest rates. Long term rates are now at a 10-year low.

The Government has also introduced a series of programs and schemes to assist those who are less well off, particularly acknowledging the difficulties of those who are unemployed. I am sure that there is no-one in this place on either side of the Parliament who takes any comfort whatsoever in the large numbers of unemployed in Australia at present. However, members on this side of the House have ensured that they are able to maintain a quality of living which would not be available to them under the policies of the Opposition. We have introduced various training schemes and expanded those in statements since the 1990 Budget and in the Budget delivered yesterday. Skillshare, Jobstart, Jobtrain and various other training programs are all designed not only to provide a standard of living for those out of work but to give them the opportunity to acquire skills which will enable them to enter the work force.

Notwithstanding the increase in unemployment which has occurred in recent months, it is true that the Government has created in excess of one million jobs since it came to office. In addition to taking those measures, the Government has also provided various forms of assistance for families outside the employment network. They include a family allowance supplement, the child-care fee relief, Medicare and Austudy.

It is worth contrasting the initiatives and the record of this Government with the sorts of policies and practices that those opposite have espoused. We have claims from the Opposition that we need to do something to increase employment. It has put on the record various prescriptions which go nowhere down the track to achieving that goal, a goal which everyone in this place would accept as fair and reasonable.
In fact, in February of this year the shadow Treasurer went on the record as calling on the Government to reduce its expenditure by $3 billion. The Australian of 19 February 1991 said:

Mr Reith's clarification of the Opposition's stance on fiscal policy-that it would both increase taxes and cut spending during a recession-means there is now a growing gulf between the positions of the Government and the Coalition on the role of government spending during a recession.

That is quite true. There is a growing gulf. It is not just a gulf between the Opposition and the Government on that point-it is a gulf between the Opposition and all economic commentators on that point.

The Opposition's proposition that the Government should slash $3 billion from its expenditure in the financial year just ended demonstrates the lack of understanding and possibly compassion on the part of those opposite for the plight of those who would inevitably be thrown out of work. In fact, the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research carried out a study on what might happen if there was a cut in the last financial year, not of the $3 billion proposed by the shadow Treasurer but of $2.1 billion which, at the time, was the cut proposed by the Business Council of Australia. Using its estimates on a $2.1 billion reduction in recurrent expenditure, the Institute said that there would be an increase in unemployment of 60,000 people in 1992 and 80,000 people in 1993.

Bear in mind that that is based on a cut of $2.1 billion. The Opposition has in fact urged the Government to make a cut of $3 billion. If we make a simple adjustment to that and assume that there is some degree of proportionality, the Opposition's proposal to cut government expenditure in the last financial year would have led to an increase in unemployment of 90,000 people in 1992 and in excess of 100,000 in 1993. They are in fact the estimates of the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research. Not only would unemployment have risen; there would have been a decline in GDP of the order of $5 billion in 1992 and a decline exceeding $6 billion in 1993.

There can be no doubt that the proposition that the Government reduce expenditure in times of economic difficulty runs counter to all of the accepted conventions of economic analysis. Yet the Opposition has stuck firm to that position, not only in February but in recent times. It will be instructive to listen to Opposition members when they respond to the Budget in a couple of days time and set out once more their plan to reduce government expenditure. I hope that on this occasion they will be a little more precise than they were last financial year when they ducked and dived and avoided any commitment as to which area they might cut. Hopefully, on this occasion, they will be a little bit more specific.

But it is not just in the area of government expenditure that the Opposition has gone off the rails. At every opportunity throughout 1990 and into the first part of this year the Opposition has criticised the Government when interest rates have in fact fallen. In January of last year, when interest rates were reduced, the now Leader of the Opposition attacked the Government. He wanted to know what the urgency was. On 23 January he said:
Mr Keating is pushing the pace of interest rate reductions simply to suit his electoral timetable.

The now Leader of the Opposition opposed the reduction in interest rates in January of 1990. Not to be outdone, in November of last year the current shadow Treasurer also opposed the reduction in interest rates at that time. He said in November of last year:
Well, I in the end come to the view, yes, if we were loosening off on monetary policy without fiscal policy changes, then you would end up with higher interest rates.
He then went on to interpret that gobbledegook by saying:
In other words, I would not take the rates off.

That is what was said in November last year by the current shadow Treasurer when interest rates were in fact falling. He opposed the reduction of interest rates last year. But he now has the hide to come in here and attack the Government because, in his view, interest rates have not in fact fallen as fast as he would like. But the record shows that last year when they were falling the Opposition opposed it.

Let us turn for a minute to industry policy. One would expect the Opposition to come up with some plans that might generate employment in this area, given the nature of the matter of public importance which it has proposed today. The Bulletin of 18 June this year included an article on the vehicle industry-a major manufacturing industry that has been the cause of some concern to many of us for some years. Under the headline `Libs pull the wheels off the car plan' the article explained the concern amongst Australia's vehicle manufacturers for the sorts of policies that those opposite promulgate. The article said:

Australia's car-makers are running scared of a coalition victory in the next federal election. Causing the concern is an unreported speech to the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries (FCAI) by the shadow minister for industry and commerce, Ian McLachlan, which bluntly warned of savage cuts in car industry protection after 1996 if a Lib-National Party government were elected in 1993.

The article goes on to explain this matter in more detail-I do not have time to do that-the fears of the vehicle industry for loss of jobs if in fact those opposite were to have the opportunity to introduce their policy.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the matter of public importance before us is a frivolous one. Worse than that, it is one which is embedded in hypocrisy. The Opposition's record in fiscal matters, in monetary matters and in wages policy belies its crocodile tears about seeking to enhance the quality of life and employment of Australians. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—The cover story on last Sunday's Sunday program was on the issue of tax reform. Flowing from that program, Mr Laurie Oakes in his article in today's Bulletin purports to quote an extract from an interview with me. Mr Oakes misrepresented me by not only selectively quoting me but also quoting me out of context, as is quite clear from the record of the interview.

SPEECH.PARA: I made the simple point that, on the question of tax policy, political parties should state their policy in advance of an election. That should be their policy and remain their policy. The tax policy implemented in any parliamentary term in the future should likewise be declared prior to the next ensuing election so that the public is not ambushed and is not subject to taxation by stealth, as it has been under this Labor Government, which has massively increased income taxes and sales tax without ever having the honesty to first seek a mandate from the electorate.

I am glad that Mr Oakes referred to my comment that being frank will encourage some people to misrepresent what one says. I must say that it is ironic that he should be so quick to first fulfil my prediction.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the routine of business for the sitting tomorrow being as follows, unless otherwise ordered:
1. Presentation of petitions.
2. Presentation of, and statements on, reports from parliamentary committees and delegations.
3. Orders of the day for the resumption of debate on motions moved in connection with committee and delegation reports (commencing no later than 10 a.m., debate concluding no later than 11 a.m.).
4. Private Members' business (commencing no later than 11 a.m., debate concluding no later than 12.30 p.m.).
5. Grievance debate.
6. Members' statements (at approximately 1.45 p.m.).
7. Questions without notice (at 2 p.m.).
8. Order of the day for the resumption of debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1991-92 (at approximately 3 p.m.).
9. Presentation of papers.
10. Ministerial statements, by leave.
11. Matter of public importance.
12. Notices and orders of the day, government business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the Opposition is totally opposed to this motion. This is a ludicrous attempt to change the order of the proceedings of this Parliament to try to force me to deliver our Budget reply at three o'clock tomorrow afternoon rather than, as has been a tradition in this place, at 7.30 or 8 p.m.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, for almost four decades there has been a long standing practice and convention in this Parliament that the Budget is delivered on the evening of the first Tuesday of the second parliamentary term of the year and the Leader of the Opposition responds on the Thursday evening. But on this occasion, the Government has decided to change the time at which the Budget is delivered to three o'clock in the afternoon, as was done yesterday afternoon. The purpose of this motion is simply to try to force my hand and have me deliver my speech at three o'clock in the afternoon. One would have to ask oneself why the Government would go to so much trouble to break with four decades of tradition.
Opposition members- They're scared!

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members say, the answer is obviously that the Government is running scared. It is running scared because it does not want to have to be publicly accountable for the miserable mismanagement of this economy that it has subjected the people of Australia to over the last eight years.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, if one listened to the Budget yesterday and read the press assessments of that Budget today, one can see why the Government wimped out. That Budget was a total disaster-a total wimp out. No wonder the Government tried to bury it at three o'clock in the afternoon when nobody would be watching.

The other reason is, of course, that the Government has decided as a matter of strategy to make the Opposition's life as difficult as possible. This is quite predictable behaviour by a group of blokes who are so far behind in the polls. It is predictable behaviour in the sense that they will take any step or measure to try to make our life as difficult as possible going into the next election.

I think it is particularly interesting and important to note that the Government will stop at absolutely nothing to make the Opposition's life impossible. We have just had Buffoon Bolkus in the Senate for a period of months arguing the case for an advertisement ban and the disclosure of political campaign donations, both of which moves were designed to make our life difficult. It has been interesting to me in the past several weeks how rapidly Buffoon Bolkus has been being backing off--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition does not assist his contribution by using that term.
—I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. Would you prefer the term `Buffoon Senator Bolkus'?
—Order! I would prefer that the Leader of the Opposition withdrew that comment.
—I am reporting an empirical fact.
—Order! I would prefer that the Leader of the Opposition withdrew.
—You lack Peacock's eloquence.
—I thank the Leader of the House. The fact is that the Government will go to any length--
—Order! I have asked the Leader of the Opposition to withdraw the term by which he referred to Senator Bolkus and which the Chair finds objectionable.

—Which is the term-`Buffoon Bolkus'? I withdraw that and refer to him as Senator Bolkus. He has gone to any length, including an attempt to ban free speech in this country, in order to prevent the Opposition from getting its message out to the people of Australia. That is what this is all about; this is simply an attempt to force us into using a time of day for the presentation of the reply to the Budget which the Government believes will make it difficult for us to get any sort of significant coverage. In particular, the Government wants to deny us the major prime television audience time, which would be associated with the delivery at the conventional time of 7.30 p.m. or 8 p.m.

SPEECH.PARA: That is simply an indication of how desperate this Government has become. It is running scared and it is deeply divided by the poisonous leadership battles and confrontations that have totally preoccupied the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the point of advanced stages of paranoia. It was even described by the ex-Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), almost in those terms. The Prime Minister sits here day after day in the Parliament and at Question Time is visibly nervous and shaken. Honourable members will have noticed how in the last couple of days since Parliament returned the Prime Minister has answered all his questions by looking at his colleagues. He is no longer prepared to turn his back on his colleagues and face the music on this side. The Prime Minister has taken to answering questions with his back to the Opposition so that no-one on the Government side actually gets up.

Have honourable members noticed how enthralled Government members have been? Have they noticed how the Prime Minister turns around and says, `I am spending all this money on family assistance', and members of the Government all sit there as though they were half asleep? That is what the Prime Minister has been reduced to. He is totally preoccupied and totally unable to run this country. We have no better evidence of that than a Budget that has absolutely nothing to do with the basic problems of this country; it does nothing for jobs. In fact, the only answer the Treasurer managed today in seven or eight questions when he was completely clean bowled by the shadow Treasurer was to whisper that maybe unemployment would go about 900,000. Louder-900,000! Actually, the number is 950,000 on the Treasury numbers. When one adds the 100,000 that will come from the superannuation deal, one is looking at over one million people unemployed on the Government's own numbers. Honourable members know how the Government has been fudging them over the past eight years. We are looking at two million Australian people who cannot work as much as they want to in this country.

The Budget had nothing to do with the fundamental problem of unemployment and job insecurity in this country. It did nothing for investment, for structural reform or for labour market reform. Indeed the Government did not even have a wages policy; the Treasurer stood up here today with three different wage numbers and was unable to tell us which one actually related to what and how they passed through the inflation rate. This is the bloke who is supposed to be running the country. He was up on his feet here today absolutely out of control, babbling on about this number and that number through the year and at the end of the year and before the year and the start of the year. It was ridiculous stuff; he was totally lost and out of control. That is what this Government has been reduced to-a group of people who are prepared to continue to try to hang onto power at any cost, and a Prime Minister who is prepared to subvert the whole Budget process to a series of deals designed to shore up his leadership and his job at the expense of the jobs of those two million Australians out there who either will be recorded as unemployed or are unable to get as much work as they want in this country. The simple fact is that they have no hope of getting their jobs back in this country until the Prime Minister loses his.

The Prime Minister is about making the Opposition's life as difficult as possible when it comes to taking our case to the people of Australia and in putting our argument to the people of Australia in the form in which we want to put it and in the most effective way we want to put it. So the Government is stopping us at every turn. The Government changed the postage allowance illegally in the last election campaign so it could direct mail en masse to its key concern marginal seats; it wants to impose the ad ban and attempt to force disclosure of political campaign donations-in part to hide its past donations from Western Australia and in part to make the Opposition's life difficult-and now we have this really cheap and shallow attempt by one of the aspirants for the job. He cannot actually decide which way to go when he listens to me talk these days; he does not know whether he wants Hawke knocked off or not.

Honourable members will recall that the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) was the pea. Just after the last election campaign all those articles and soft profile pieces appeared about how the Leader of the House was going to take over from the old fellow when he moved on. He was being groomed for the job, but he made an absolute mess of his portfolio and an absolute mess of the running of this Parliament. Then the penny dropped that the Leader of the House was not worth the effort anyway because he is sitting in one of the most marginal seats in Western Australia; the Government could not possibly have him having a run.

Even the other Minister at the table, the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) is starting to smile; he figures he has an outside chance. If we could get him onto his feet, he would agree with me. He is such a modest and measured fellow, he would agree with me. Yes, he does; he is nodding. He reckons he has an outside chance. That is what has happened over on the other side. It is not just the Leader of the House who sees himself as the pea; the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean)-the guy with the R.M. Williams boots, who went out and got the gear, the checked sports coat and the tie, who went down to Deniliquin or somewhere and talked to farmers and who comes in here with cow pats on his shoes just so that we know he is legitimate-is another aspirant.

In fact the whole of the front bench members of the Government see themselves as aspirants. With this motion the Government is trying simply to make the Opposition's life as difficult as possible and make it impossible for us to get our argument across in the most effective way. As I said, the Government will stop at nothing to subvert what has been a four-decade convention and tradition in this Parliament that the Budget Speech is delivered on the evening of the first Tuesday of the second parliamentary session and the Leader of the Opposition's response is delivered on the following Thursday evening at the same time. If it takes banning free speech or cheating on postage or doing any one of a host of other things to hide the fact that the Government is fundamentally and poisonously divided, the Government will do it. The Opposition totally rejects this notion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was really and genuinely pathetic. This is the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) being semi-tough; this is the Leader of the Opposition trying to come into this place and do some sort of rough facsimile of the sort of confected horror that we used to be subjected to by the former Leader of the Opposition, who at least had the capacity to carry it off with a bit of style and elegance. He was not like some sort of Shore Grammar debating technique circa 1967 or whenever it was, which is what we managed to get from the Leader of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of postage allowances, with the old Charlie sitting there sadly in the background, I must give the Leader of the Opposition some points at least on the count of sheer gall in coming in here and talking about postage allowances vis-a-vis the last election campaign and performances in that regard. The only honourable member who apparently seriously used it to a very substantial extent came from the other side of the House. However, to come in here and raise it as an argument against the Government was completely absurd.

We on this side of the House do have some respect for tradition. In fact, there has been a whole number of ways in which the Budget debate has been conducted over the years. The fact of the matter is that it has not always been at 7.30 and it has not always been televised, as the Opposition well knows. Indeed, it was generally at 8 o'clock and the reply was a couple of days later at 8 o'clock. But the one common feature always has been that the time of the response delivered by the Opposition in this House is the same as the time the Speech was delivered-be it 7.30 or 8 o'clock. If the Speech was delivered at 7.30, it was responded to by the Opposition at 7.30; when it was 8 o'clock, it was responded to at 8 o'clock by the Opposition. It has been presented this time at 3 o'clock; the Opposition will now have its turn at 3 o'clock.

I stand to be corrected on this, but I do not think even that particular pattern has been automatically conformed to. I seem to recollect that on one occasion when Mr Hayden was Leader of the Opposition he chose, as a particular Opposition tactic, to respond immediately to the Budget. I may be incorrect, but I think that did occur. So he breached the pattern on that occasion, and I am sure we could have accommodated the Opposition if it had decided to run on, immediately after the Treasurer had delivered the Budget, at 3.30 yesterday. But the fact of the matter is, as far as the Government is concerned, that time is made available at the same time of the day two days on for the Opposition to give a reply.

I have picked up a rumour around the place, the substance of which involves concerns by the Manager of Opposition Business about whether or not television stations could run responses or would be obliged to run responses and that the ABC was disinclined to run the Opposition's response at 7.30 or 8 o'clock on the Thursday night but would be prepared to run it at 3 o'clock. I might say, if that is the case, that it was not as a result of any initiative by this Government that the ABC took that particular attitude. Anyone who knows anything about the relationship of the Government and the ABC knows that it is 100 per cent contra-suggestible to suggestions by Ministers. So, on the whole, Ministers do not bother to make suggestions, and I am in no different position from my predecessors in that regard.

So, if that is true, of course it makes this particular exercise by the Leader of the Opposition 100 per cent bogus. If that is true-and by the way in which the Opposition spokesman conducted himself in here when putting questions to the Speaker it appears to be the case-the Opposition was not going to get on the box at 7.30 or 8 o'clock anyhow, in which case the only time it has an opportunity to get its response across--

TALK.START.PARA: —Will it? Heil Hitler! You do not know that.

—The Manager of Opposition Business managed to bell the cat by the way in which he asked questions of the Speaker, which did rather seem to confirm that particular rumour that was circulating around the place; otherwise it is very difficult to establish why he should have bothered to raise those questions in the way in which he did. He can tell me: did the ABC refuse to broadcast the Opposition at 7.30? Did it give the Opposition that response? No answer. The Opposition outsmarted itself on that point by raising it with the Speaker. So the fact of the matter is, the Opposition will have no public response at 7.30 or 8 o'clock; it does have the opportunity to give a public response at 3 o'clock. So this is a performance here that is totally confected. It has absolutely no substance because the Opposition was not going to be able to give that performance.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not have a worry about its response to our Budget. We do not have a worry because we are waiting anxiously for it to answer a few questions. We want to know what it is going to do about higher education in this country. Our Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) had a few things to say about the vagueness of the propositions that the Opposition has put forward. We want to know what it intends to do about health in this country. We are very happy to hear its answers on those particular suggestions, in a Budget context or anything else. We want to know what it intends to do about consumption tax and taxation policy generally, because we think that when in this place it adopts the attitude it does to the poor and needy in this country it is perpetrating a monumental hypocrisy concerning what it intends to impose on them via a consumption tax. So we have absolutely no problems with listening to what the Opposition wants to say about that.

Further, because the point was made by the Leader of the Opposition on unemployment, we want to know what level of unemployment there would be if the Opposition were going to seek as a permanent objective an inflation rate of nil, which is what it was talking about when there was discussion in this place on inflation rates a couple of years ago. The Opposition must want to see levels of unemployment way beyond what they are at the moment, because the sorts of measures that it would have to put in place to achieve those levels of inflation would be draconian indeed. So fundamentally we do not worry about responses from the Opposition. We do not worry about the Opposition in any sense embarrassing us before our constituency, because we know that there is that thorough leavening and underpinning of hypocrisy in everything it says. But it is not subtle hypocrisy, I am afraid; it is hypocrisy that is relatively easy to expose.

The Leader of the Opposition was kind enough to have some concern about my constituency and whether or not I would manage to hold it next time. It is always a struggle in the old Swan, I have to say. But it is going to be a heck of a lot less of a struggle when I go around the areas of Bentley and Queen's Park and Belmont and Rivervale and have a chat with members of my constituency about the fact that they will be provided with, via a consumption tax, the means for continued good living by the people who managed that good living in the 1980s at my constituents' personal expense.

They will have a view about who will support the poor and needy when they have an opportunity to hear that. They will want an opportunity to hear what might be done and hear about the chances of their children securing a higher education, following the sorts of suggestions that have emanated thus far from the Opposition. No doubt they will be very pleased to hear some answers in that regard. They will also be pleased to hear what is intended on their behalf when it comes to health policy and whether or not they will be able to continue to be in receipt of a universal service. Above all, because many of them are pensioners, they will be very pleased to get an understanding of how it is intended that $3 billion will be cut from the social security budget. That is something that will be of some interest and concern to them.

So we do not actually have a problem with the Opposition's presentation in this matter, but we would like to hear some answers to those questions. We strongly suspect the answers to those questions in any particular detail will not, in fact, be forthcoming in a couple of days time; nevertheless, it would be good to be able to hear them. I think, given the amount of time the Opposition has had to work on these policies, an absolute minimum requirement as far as this House is concerned and as far as the public is concerned is for the Opposition to have put up or shut up on a couple of these issues by now. After all, the Opposition has had about 18 months to work on them, and I think that we are really entitled to hear a few answers to those particular questions in this Budget reply. I strongly suspect that we will not.

As far as equity in this House is concerned, the Opposition is getting an opportunity to respond at exactly the same time as the Government chose to deliver its Budget. The Opposition's response, if it is given at that time, I understand will be broadcast on national television. I am not sure, but there have been rumours-and I take those rumours to be somewhat confirmed by that otherwise totally inexplicable intervention by the Manager of Opposition Business in questioning the Speaker earlier on-that the Opposition in fact was not going to get time on national television to present its response to the Budget at 7.30 or 8 o'clock. If that were to be the situation, of course it would render this whole exercise here an exercise that, if it has any merit at all, has some merit in its training value-training the Leader of the Opposition to be a parliamentarian.
The Opposition would be able to have its array of judges sit there behind the Leader of the Opposition, pass judgment on him and take him outside. They will say, `Well, John'--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —`Perhaps you should give a bit more inflection there, or perhaps button your coat, lean and speak closely into the microphone-or perhaps you could learn something from the putative Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who has developed a better technique of slapping the dispatch box than just about anybody else in this chamber; that putative Deputy Leader who unfortunately is not here to advise you on technique because, as well as from the honourable member for Kooyong, you would get some excellent advice from him on how the Leader of the Opposition ought to conduct himself in Parliament'.

SPEECH.PARA: One is sort of left to wonder why in fact he is not here. He has been conspicuously absent this last day. I do not know whether his particular run at the Opposition's current Deputy was said to be successful or unsuccessful at its last party meeting. No doubt he will have another opportunity to run at the current Deputy sometime later, using the argument that most of the Opposition members believe that they have really just got to get Johnny up as Deputy in order to improve the Opposition's parliamentary performance.

Let me tell honourable members opposite: they do actually need to get John Howard up as their economic spokesman and Deputy Leader in order to put on some sort of performance in this place. In case they think they do not need to get him up here to do that, I point out that the Leader of the Opposition gave ample evidence of that need here today. So the rest of the Opposition members who are sort of sitting there ticking it over in their minds need not worry too much about abandoning their only Victorian leader; they should go for parliamentary performance when they are in the position of their Leader strongly needing that sort of support. They should ignore the fact that perhaps there will be a sentiment out there in the public that he is just worming himself into the right position at the right moment to terminate the current Leader of the Opposition when they find that some of their totally unsaleable policies need to be sold.

I appreciate the fact that honourable members opposite managed to listen to this in silence for about 30 seconds, as they recognise the arguments that they are using amongst themselves at this precise moment. Of course, some Opposition members-for reasons that we cannot quite fathom, but perhaps there is logic in them-harvest some view of a potential last minute advancement for the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan). The honourable member for Barker has not yet tested himself in this place, but the would-be new deputy leader of the Opposition has tested himself, and we have to concede that he is not a bad parliamentary performer.

The upshot of all this is that the Opposition has to go back and reflect on this session, recognising that it has not done terribly well out of this debate, have a chat to Johnny about it, see if he has got any useful suggestions as to what it might do, hope that those suggestions do not immediately involve the current removal of the Deputy Leader and that he will be slightly more constructive. But I would not count on it.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Beazley's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.
