SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The way in which the Australian National University Bill has been brought back into the House is further evidence of the contempt with which the Government is treating the Parliament and the Opposition. My office was not advised that this Bill was coming back. It is not on the blue business sheet. No effort whatever was made to consult with the Opposition in relation to these amendments. The matter has been handled either incompetently or with a total contempt for this Chamber and the role of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The way this Bill has been handled throughout its time in this House is very interesting. When the Bill was first introduced into the House, the second reading debate was guillotined. The opportunity for the Opposition to draw attention to the very damaging consequences of the Government's policies for the Australian National University was cut off.

The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) has now reintroduced the Bill into the House without notification to the Opposition. Yet the Minister took the time, in his second reading speech, to make an extensive defence not just of the measures in this legislation, but of the Government's policies toward the Australian National University. So far the Government has provided no opportunity for the Opposition to comment in this House on these policies. The Minister is, regrettably, totally out of touch with the implications of his policies for the National University and for higher education in this country. He listens to a small clique of mates who applaud what he says and he chooses to ignore the voice--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the AVCC.

—I am talking about the Minister's union mates. He chooses to ignore the great bulk of those who have views of and interests in the development of higher education in this country and who are making their voices known with increasing loudness and clamour because of the impact of this Government's policies on the higher education system. The Australian this morning, in the higher education supplement, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has decided to make a stand on the future of the Australian National University and push ahead with revised funding arrangements foreshadowed last March which could see the demise of the ANU as a national research institution.

Those are not the words of the Opposition; those are the words of the Australian. The Minister made comment in Question Time today that there had been general criticism of the Opposition's position on higher education. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that every editorial that was produced at the time the Opposition's policy was released endorsed the thrust of the coalition's policies. The Courier-Mail spoke of the union's response-the response of the Minister's mates. It said:

That response rather sourly demonstrates that however lofty a union's intellectual base, its reaction to perceived threats to so-called rights and privileges is unashamedly Neanderthal. Dr Kemp advances the reasonable view that universities might be better off managing employment conditions in the way they choose. This would include allowing them to top up public funding with corporate sponsorship.
The editorial of the Australian stated:

. . . Dr Kemp is correct to suggest a supple academy sits uneasily with the present rigidities of industrial relations. Good scholars deserve more money, bad scholars less. It is also unhealthy, as he implies, for universities to be wholly dependent on government.
The Sydney Morning Herald stated:

Where Dr Kemp has a strong point is his claim that the universities must be able to offer places to fee-paying Australian students who have missed out because of a mark requirement. At its national conference in Hobart, the ALP voted down this proposal. But there is more ideology than logic in its position.

The Minister is in the position where the President of the Australian Higher Education Industrial Association has come out, in a private letter leaked by the unions to the Government, endorsing the thrust of the Opposition's higher education policy. Yesterday no less a person than Professor Karmel, former Chairman of the Australian Universities Commission and a former Vice-Chancellor of Flinders University and the Australian National University, endorsed the strategy put forward by the Opposition in leading the debate for rescue of higher education from the terrible condition into which it has deteriorated under this Government and which this Minister has done nothing whatever about. Of course the AVCC is delighted to receive additional funding, but the Budget addresses none of the fundamental problems, with the east European style management system that the Minister and the senior Minister under whom he works have foisted on the system.

In relation to the Australian National University, in response to an article of mine the Minister stated in an article in the Canberra Times that the national university was close to his position. Does he still support that or was it another inaccurate statement about the relationship between the Government and the university system? It is reported in the same Australian article this morning, in the comment of the Vice-Chancellor of the Australian National University, that the university is very far from the Government's position. The article states:
But comments by ANU administrators suggest the gap-
that is, between the Government and the university-
still exists. The director of the ANU's Institute of Advanced Studies, Professor Max Neutze, said the university would continue to protest against the Government's interference with its autonomy.
Professor Neutze, a man who is very highly respected throughout higher education, had this to say about the Minister:
Mr Baldwin's letter was `a bit opaque' and lacked clarity . . . We are still very concerned about the extent of ARC involvement.

He said that it was important to make sure the university did not get into a position where changes could not be undone. What does he mean by that-`where changes could not be undone'? He means that when the Government changes, as it surely will, there will be a significant change in higher education policy in this country. World class institutions will not be under attack, will not be undermined, will be able to manage their own affairs in a way that is not possible under the system which is being administered by this Minister.
Professor Barry Rolfe, who is leading a grassroots revolt of academics throughout higher education and who will be campaigning against the Labor Party in the next election, said:
What can he (Mr Baldwin) do (if the ANU rejected his decision)? Turn the money off?

Professor Rolfe is referring to the fact that the Minister, all macho, said in his initial March statement that the schools of the Institute of Advanced Studies would be reviewed and that, if the performance of any school was not satisfactory, its funding would be cut off. He later realised that he had shot off at the mouth a little, because he could not cut off its funding. The statement was incorrect. He still does not understand that it is a matter for the Australian National University to allocate its funds internally.

I assumed from the way the Minister later approached this issue that he had been advised that this was the case, and that is what is being referred to here. The Minister has no power to carry out that threat; he himself has said that it is up to the Australian National University to allocate its funds. As many people from the Australian National University have said to me since they have read the Minister's article, it is plain that the Minister does not understand the impact of this policy on the national university. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) has totally failed to address himself to the content of the legislation. He raised a number of general issues to do with the Australian National University. The first question to ask about the Opposition spokesperson's approach to this matter concerns the chronology of his response.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this year we had a report by Professor Chubb on the future of the Institute and higher education provision in the ACT, and he made a number of comments. On 27 March I announced my decisions on higher education in the ACT. I was surprised that there was an extraordinary silence on the Opposition side. We heard nothing from Opposition members. I expected fulminations the next day from the honourable member for Goldstein, saying that this would represent the end of civilisation as we know it. Strangely enough, I did not hear a single coherent comment from the honourable member for Goldstein until he decided to publish an article in the Canberra Times, I think in late in June.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was the debate guillotined, when you prevented me making a statement? You deliberately cut off the Opposition's opportunity well before that article.

—The honourable member for Goldstein has issued press releases. He is caught here, because whichever way the parliamentary debate went, he had ample opportunity to comment in the public domain. The occasion of one of his speeches is normally an occasion for him to issue a press release about some issue, but apparently he was not able to issue a press release on this or to have anything to say on the public record until late June, on a statement that I made on 27 March. Is that not interesting?
—You have got it wrong.

—This is the man who talks about the desirability of the introduction of a higher degree of competition into the higher education system. Yet here we have a situation where one institution, amongst the dozens of institutions in this country, has had $130m allocated to it without any systematic process of performance evaluation and review. Is the honourable member saying that that state of affairs ought to continue? If that is what he is saying, he should spell it out and justify it. He does not do that and he never has. As I was saying, I think the honourable member for Goldstein knows that the line he is taking now is rubbish and is incompatible with any notion that higher education institutions should be subject in their funding to some sort of competitive process.
—We have stated our position. You aren't prepared to talk with the university.

—What is the honourable member's position? He has not stated a position on what the funding basis for the Institute of Advanced Studies should be. He has not said anything of the kind. He has not addressed the basis on which he would fund a stand-alone research institute such as the IAS. He waits for two months, sees the advertisements in the Australian, and sees a bit of a campaign being run. Believing that there are a few political points to be scored, that he might be able to get onto a bandwagon, he decides to come out and take this position. But his position lacks integrity, and he knows that full well. He knows that what he is saying about this has no rational basis.
—Are you saying there is no integrity in defending the Australian National University's autonomy?
—I listened in silence to the honourable member's contribution and I expect that I also will be heard in silence.
-The Chair will attempt to ensure that you do, Minister.

—Good. It is interesting that the honourable member for Goldstein went to other more general higher education issues. What authorities did he cite to support his position? He quoted the editorial from the Australian; he quoted the Higher Education Supplement. Let us consider its reputation for objectivity. I have been in this Ministry since April of last year. I could probably count on the fingers of one hand, and certainly on the fingers of two hands, the number of occasions on which my office has been contacted for comment on things. There has been no attempt by the HES to get the Government point of view on the issues about which it has been writing. Time and again we have seen totally distorted and biased accounts of things.

SPEECH.PARA: To give an example, I will take the Institute of Advanced Study and ANU issue. A journalist from the Australian wrote quite an extensive piece which was based on material from an academic from the faculties of the ANU who had spent some time as a research fellow funded by the NHMRC within the institute and which strongly supported the broad thrust of government policy on what we are seeking to do there. What happens to it? Where does it put it? Does it put it in a higher education supplement so that it might provide some sort of balance to the line it has been taking consistently week in, week out? No, it put in a page buried in the middle of the computer pages. This is the sort of journalistic integrity that one has to deal with in that publication.

I attach no weight whatsoever to anything that is said in either the higher education supplement or in an editorial in the Australian newspaper on these sorts of issues. Time and again, there is no semblance of an attempt to get an objective and reasonable account of these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —You totally dismiss his views.

—You totally dismiss the comments of the Australian Vice-Chancellor's Committee, which is the body which represents the vice-chancellors of all the higher education institutions in the country. The Australian Vice-Chancellor's Committee has warmly endorsed and supported the measures that the Government announced in the Budget context yesterday and it dismissed the Opposition's National Press Club speech as being marked by superficiality, vagueness and a failure to address the whole range of practical issues that the sort of policy approach that the Opposition espouses throws up. The Opposition can be terribly selective and pick this one or that one that it claims supports its position, but I would have thought it would attach more weight to the representative body representing higher education institutions in this country. For what it is worth, I could find an editorial in this or that newspaper.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the specific terms of this legislation appear to be non-controversial. As usual, the Opposition spokesman takes the opportunity of one of these relatively non-controversial amendments to get up and grandstand. His position on the Institute of Advanced Studies is devoid of integrity. The Government is saying that when it makes $130m available annually to an institution, there ought to be some proper process of public accountability and review so that the Government can receive advice on what the appropriate distribution of the higher education research dollar is between such an institution and the rest of the higher education research system as a whole. Is the Opposition saying that is unreasonable?

The ANU says that it accepts that that is a reasonable proposition. The point of difference is that it continues to maintain that there ought not to be meaningful external involvement in the review process itself. We do not accept that. We proposed to the ANU that the review processes be done on a five-yearly basis and that they be done using performance criteria that would be developed jointly by the Australian Research Council and the ANU. The review panels of individual schools and centres would be comprised of a membership which would have to be agreed between the ANU and the Australian Research Council.

I cannot see how the Opposition can reasonably object to such a process. In fact, there is no logical, coherent or remotely intellectually respectable basis on which to disagree with such a process. The Opposition knows that. It waited two months before it made any public utterance on this issue after the release of my statement on March 27, yet the Opposition talks about the guillotining of the Bill as if that is some sort of excuse. Why could the Opposition not issue a press release or call a press conference? Why could it not do an interview on the radio? The Opposition made no statement on the Government statement after March 27 until it saw a cynical, sleazy piece of political opportunism. It saw that there was a bit of political hay to be made and it jumped on the bandwagon. Its position is without integrity and without credibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) is again clearly demonstrating that he simply does not understand these issues; he is poorly briefed on the matter and is inaccurate in what he says. The Opposition fully accepts, as does the Australian National University, that it is appropriate to review the performance of a body such as the Institute of Advanced Studies. The Minister says that the National University is totally opposed to any external involvement in the review. As he knows, that is a distortion of the National University's position on the matter. From the start, the National University has objected to the way in which the Government has entrusted the review process to the Australian Research Council. The University has made a powerful case as to why this will interfere with and prevent the University's autonomous management of the Institute of Advanced Studies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has no objection whatever. Indeed, it is correct to assert that it is quite appropriate for the Government to review the performance of a body such as the Institute of Advanced Studies. Throughout we have asked for-and I must say the Australian National University has asked for-a review process which will assure the university, the public and the Government that not only has justice been done, but also that it will be seen to have been done. It has objected to the fact that it is to be reviewed by a body which itself-and this is no reflection on the individuals on the ARC-actually would benefit from the funds that might be taken away from the Institute of Advanced Studies.

As for the Minister's pathetic suggestions that the Opposition failed to comment on his March statement, let me draw the Minister's attention to a press release which I issued on 29 April after fully consulting with the Australian National University on the implications of the Minister's statement condemning the actions of the Minister announced in that statement. The Minister is wrong on both counts. He is wrong because he simply does not understand the issues involved; he is badly briefed on the issues involved. None of the charges that he makes against the Opposition holds the slightest amount of water. He is presiding over a system which is coming to an end. That is increasingly recognised throughout higher education.

It is recognised that the east European style attempt to centrally manage higher education in this country is collapsing. It is collapsing because of the overcrowding, which is a result of the Government's regulations, as the AVCC has said. I understand that because it said that the Minister was very cross with it and that it faced some difficulties in access to the Government for a period of time. But I feel sure that is remedied by its response to the Budget, which I am sure is a very sincere response. As I said, the Minister is presiding over a system which is coming to an end. Throughout higher education, it is recognised that it cannot survive; it cannot cope with the problems of the system; it is creating enormous pressures within the system for uniformity; it is interfering with institutional management. Vice-chancellor after vice-chancellor is being attacked on his own campus because the Minister's system forces an increasing centralisation of power within the institutions themselves. That is the inevitable consequence of every centralised system, and that is happening within Australian universities. It is creating division within the institutions.

Of course, that is further exacerbated by the centralised industrial relations framework, which the Minister and his Government have imposed on the universities. That tells the university community that it is divided into employers and employees, and the traditional tactics, with which the Minister is so familiar, such as industrial confrontation, are the appropriate tactics with which to decide issues in higher education. It is a system which has centralised power, divided institutions and demoralised staff. Until it is changed, we will not get out of higher education in this country the quality and excellence of which it is capable and we will not be able to provide places within higher education for those who are qualified and knocking on the doors, but whom the Government says at the moment the universities may not admit on any terms.

The Government does not mind telling the universities that they can admit students from overseas for full fees. It is not prepared to allow Australian students the same opportunities. It is a system which is constantly open to the suspicion of political influence, and that suspicion, throughout higher education, is rife.

The statement by Professor Karmel reported in the Australian Financial Review yesterday is of great significance because no-one in Australia has a longer association with policy making in higher education at the highest levels than Professor Karmel. Professor Karmel has been involved in higher education policy for several decades. He has come to the view that the present system is intolerable and unworkable and that it has to be changed in the direction which the coalition has been advocating.

It will be interesting to hear the Minister's future comments on enterprise bargaining in view of the comments of Paul Hickey in Darwin. We have not heard any statements by the Minister endorsing enterprise bargaining on the public platform in higher education. His senior official, a Deputy Secretary of his Department, endorsed very strongly that direction of change, so I assume it is the Minister's direction of change, although his union mates apparently do not think so.

Our policy of devolution in industrial relations within higher education, our policy of deregulating the institutional profiles, our policy of funding institutions through the students rather than through the DEET bureaucracy, and our policy of giving much greater emphasis to accountability to the users of higher education rather than to the Minister's officials here in Canberra will revive higher education in this country. It will create world class institutions and, once more, it will give institutions such as the ANU the freedom to pursue an educational mission which at present is being damaged and destroyed in a totally negligent and destructive way by the policies of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose one could go on ad infinitum--
—Are you going to apologise?
—Are you talking about the apparent delay in the Opposition spokesperson's comment?
—You misrepresented his position.

—This press release is interesting. It is the first time I have seen it. I had my office carefully scrutinise all printed materials and all references which had anything to do with the ANU to see whether there was something emanating from the Opposition spokesperson, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp). I would be very interested to see if there is a single media reference to this. The press release is dated 29 April; the statement I made was on 27 March. In other words, it took those opposite more than a month to wake up to the fact that this terrible action--
—Not to wake up, to consult.

—One would have to put it together with the sack of the great library of Alexandria in the fourth century AD in terms of the seriousness of the attack on the process of the acquisition of knowledge. It took over a month for the honourable gentleman to wake up to the fact that this shocking thing had occurred. Let us take at face value the press release put out by the honourable member. He must have hidden it under a rug in his office somewhere as nobody in the outside world seems to know anything about it. Even if he did that, he is saying it took more than a month for him to wake up to the fact that this huge public storm and controversy was happening.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to reiterate three final, fundamental points. The first point is that the Opposition spokesperson said that we wanted to entrust the review process to the ARC. Let us be clear what the ARC is. It is a body established by legislation to provide the Government with advice on any higher education research schemes. Contrary to what the honourable member for Goldstein apparently seems to believe, the ARC does not conduct research in its own right. It is an advisory body to government on any higher education research scheme referred to it by the Government. That is the first point.

The second point is that, looking at the structure of the Australian Research Council, nobody could reasonably question the integrity and the appropriateness of the background of the body of people who make it up. One occasionally sees attempts to label the ARC as an extension of the bureaucracy. I do not question the integrity of the bureaucracy either. The fact is that the ARC is, very clearly, a highly representative body and a highly appropriate body to be providing the Government with advice on higher education research matters.

The third point is the actual review process, which we propose. If the Opposition spokesperson paid attention he might learn the contents of the decision we have taken. In this process the reviews of individual schools and centres would be done collaboratively by the Australian Research Council and the Australian National University applying criteria which would be developed collaboratively with those two entities and with review panels, the composition of which would have to be agreed by the Australian National University and the Australian Research Council. In other words, the ANU would have an effective veto right over the composition of panels reviewing parts of its own schools and centres within itself.

The honourable member suggests that there is something inappropriate about that process. If that is not appropriate, he might describe an appropriate process which includes the need to achieve external accountability, which he says is necessary. What body would provide that advice to government if not the ARC? Will we create a special new entity to review the Australian National University? Let us hear in precise terms what the Opposition proposes by way of an alternative to what the Government is proposing in this area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill provides for amendment to increase the maximum allowable honey levy on honey produced and sold in Australia. The Bill is one of three similar Bills, each dealing with a different way of selling honey, which provide for an increase in the maximum allowable levies or export charges on honey to 0.75c per kilogram. The levies and export charge are imposed to provide the basis for funding the Honeybee Research and Development Council.

Under the present legislation the maximum allowable levy for research and development is 0.50c per kilogram, which is the same as the current operative rate. The operative rate is determined by regulation on advice of the Federal Council of Australian Apiarists' Associations, which is the national representative beekeeper organisation, or the Honeybee Research and Development Council. The Federal Council of Australian Apiarists' Associations has advised that it wishes to increase the operative rate to 0.52c per kilogram from 1 January 1992 as part of its program of progressively increasing the producer contribution to research and development.

To allow for this increase and any further increases the Federal Council of Australian Apiarists' Associations has requested the raising of the maximum rate to 0.75c per kilogram. Increasing the maximum rate by 50 per cent will give industry the flexibility to increase its contributions to research and development over an extended period without the need for frequent amendments to the legislation.

The Government commends the industry's foresight and support of the need for increased research and development. The Australian honey industry is currently contributing about 0.4 per cent of its gross value of production to research and development. Research and development is a major factor underlying this country's future growth. The Government is committed to continued matching of industry levies for funding of research and development up to 0.5 per cent of gross value of production. This has continued to encourage rural industries to increase their contributions to research and clearly the honey industry recognises the advantage of this commitment in moving towards the 0.5 per cent target.

No additional budgetary outlays will result from the amendment itself. However, this amendment would enable the Government to agree to an industry request for an operative rate increase above the current maximum which would then generate additional matching budgetary outlays. I commend the Bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Honey Levy (No. 2) Amendment Bill provides for amendment to increase the maximum allowable honey levy on honey produced in Australia and used in the production of other goods. The Bill provides for an increase in the maximum allowable levy to 0.75c per kilogram. The levy is imposed to provide the basis for funding the Honeybee Research and Development Council. I have already outlined the background to this amendment in my second reading speech on the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1991.

No additional budgetary outlays will result from the amendment itself. However, this amendment would enable the Government to agree to an industry request for an operative rate increase above the current maximum, which would then generate additional matching budgetary outlays. I commend the Bill to honourable members, and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Honey Export Charge Amendment Bill provides for amendment to increase the maximum allowable honey export charge on honey exported, but not levied under other legislation. The export charge is imposed to provide the basis for funding the Honeybee Research and Development Council. I have already outlined the background to this amendment in my second reading speech on the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill.

No additional budgetary outlays will result from the amendment itself. However, this amendment would enable the Government to agree to an industry request for an operative rate increase above the current maximum, which would then generate additional matching budgetary outlays.
I commend the Bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Mr Crean:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill corrects deficiencies in four Bills-three wool Bills and one horticultural Bill. By correcting the deficiencies, it will allow levies which were collected from growers before 1 July to be transferred to the new authorities which came into operation after 1 July. It also covers one other deficiency in the wool legislation; it will ensure that the Government pays to the wool industry its share-half, or a dollar for dollar contribution-for research and development.

SPEECH.PARA: This is unnecessary legislation. It should not have been needed, and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has acknowledged that. I am not having a go at the Minister or, for that matter, the Department, but I believe it is a bad scene. It is really a reflection on the quality of the legislation presented to us in Parliament when something that should be automatic in legislation-that is, the transition provisions to pick up from the old structure to the new structure, which is in some cases the major part of that legislation-is not automatically in the legislation. There should be a check list that ensures that that is automatic in any procedure before the draft legislation has the final approval to come into the House. Therefore, it is a reflection on the quality of work being done by the parliamentary draftsmen. The wool Bills were certainly late, but there has been no pressure on the horticulture Bill. That Bill went through in March this year.

In addition to the legislation being unnecessary, it creates uncertainty for the industries. There is the concern about loss of income and interest forgone to the industry and there is the worry of greater cost. With the wool industry we are talking about a significant figure. A figure of about $90m was held up. I understand that $30m of that amount was able to be transferred, so we are talking about $60m. With the horticulture industry, the amount is $95,000, still a significant figure. A different type of levy is imposed on the horticulture industry but the principle remains the same: it is important that the levies that are collected are automatically transferred and utilised by the industry.
In his second reading speech, the Minister indicated that the industries will not lose because of this; that is very important. In that speech the Minister said:

The Government considers that the statutory authorities, and through them the woolgrowers, should not have to bear the additional expense caused by the drafting omission. Therefore the Government will pay interest for the period of the delay in the wool tax payments. The Bill provides that the Minister will determine the interest rate to apply and I envisage that the rate will be based on that which the Commonwealth earns on investment of its surplus funds.

The Bill also proposes that interest will be payable by the Commonwealth on the delay in payment to the wool statutory authorities of wool tax money received by the Commonwealth immediately before 30 June 1991 but not paid out until after that date, while the legal questions were being resolved.

There is still a potential inequity in the sense that interest forgone on money invested is at a lower interest rate than money borrowed if the party that was the loser, that is, the Wool Corporation or the Realisation Commission, had to borrow additional money to make up for the money which did not come through.

My understanding is that that is not the case in this situation and therefore one assumes that the interest obtained by the Commonwealth, or at least the payment which will be made by the Commonwealth at that interest rate, will be equal to what the industry lost because it was not able to make use of that money. I guess that does not arise in this case; that is the assurance I have from the Minister on this case, and my understanding from the industry is the same.

This particular piece of legislation is not the only issue relating to wool before Parliament at present. There are the regulations that flow from the wool debate and the wool legislation in the dying stages of the last session of Parliament. The coalition parties more than ever believe, because of the way the opening of the wool auctions have gone since we were here in June, that its policy of a maximum of 10 per cent total tax to be paid by woolgrowers-to cover the repayment of the debt incurred by the old Wool Corporation, promotion, and research and development-is adequate.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very conservative figure.

—Very conservative. It is our intention to move for the disallowance of the regulation which the Government has proposed for 12 per cent, which follows on the final agreement or understanding in that wool legislation that, whereas the tax level remains at a maximum of 15 per cent, the operative level for this year, which will be set by regulation, will be at 12 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I am giving notice that it is our intention to move for that disallowance. We believe that if one looks at the projection figures for production for this coming season-which are falling-there will be an ability for the price to remain firm above all the projections that were made a couple of months ago; there will be an ability to sell significant amounts from the stock-pile later in the season; and 10 per cent, when considering the financial problems concerning woolgrowers is, more than ever, a realistic and adequate figure.

With regard to promotion, there was certainly some double-dealing by the Government in the dying hours of the debate. It removed the legislative figure of 3 1/2 per cent for promotion and replaced it completely by regulation. There was no notice or recognition of that given in the dying stages of the debate. Therefore, the level of wool promotion, which is a very significant part of the recovery of wool as a desired world fibre, is at the whim of the Government. I believe that is an unsatisfactory basis for what is a very significant industry promotion activity. We are talking of about $180m a year based on the reduced IWS budget for this coming year.

I am concerned-I know that some of those who will speak after me are concerned-about having an adequate financial base for promotion and the figure of 2 1/2 per cent that is to be allocated by the Government through regulation. We will not be attempting to alter that because with no legislative basis behind the regulation it is very difficult to have an actual allocation for promotion on a stable and secure basis.

I also believe that there is a case to be made for some outside evaluation of wool promotion-we are talking about a large amount of money-and its effectiveness, particularly in these times of financial difficulty for woolgrowers. I believe that that would be of value. That is for the industry to determine, unless the Government decides to step in with some form of Industry Commission inquiry or something like that. That is the position of the coalition concerning the regulations before the Parliament at present.

The Wool Realisation Commission, which is part of the legislation we are debating, has sold about 100,000 bales from the stockpile worth about $65m since 1 July. Its policy is to offer wool on days when there is no auction sale at a premium above the closing price for that category of wool for the last selling day of the previous season, or the closing price of the last sale, whichever is the highest. It publishes figures, and it has a reasonable accountability in that regard.

I believe it is sensible for the Wool Realisation Commission to make available wool if it is in short supply or if it is close to the mills and is needed quickly, or where that wool has been part processed. Some of that wool was available in the latter part of the last wool selling season.

I question-it is a personal view-the wisdom of the Wool Realisation Commission offering so much wool early in the season; that is, between 1 July and the start of the auction system, in the latter part of July. The bulk of the wool is to be available this season before Christmas and again that adds to potential market uncertainty in this new environment for wool, at a time when as much confidence as possible is needed by the industry to maintain as high an opening price as possible in setting that tone, and also for the benefit of the woolgrowers who were already suffering a dramatic reduction in their wool income.

That sale has certainly more than covered the $20m repayment that is required under the Government's repayment schedule. That and all the other factors at work in the wool industry at present, as I said before, confirm more than ever the correctness of our strategy through this whole debate and this most difficult time for the wool industry.

The final point I want to make concerns the role of the Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics during this debate. I do not enter into the argument that the wool exporters or some others have proffered about the role of ABARE in the reduction in the price of wool since the wool selling season opened. ABARE had made a projection that it considered the average price for wool this season would be 475c a kilogram. It has a requirement to do that sort of thing, so I do not enter into that argument.

It worries me that ABARE is supposed to be an objective and politically neutral organisation. It exists to establish to the best of its ability the facts of the situation for a whole range of rural and resource industries. I believe it was less than objective and less than neutral during the wool tax debate. It brings to my mind the question of its role. As we were told during the wool debate, ABARE said that a levy lower than 15 per cent would reduce the price of wool in the market and therefore lower the return to growers. That was used against the coalition argument that 10 per cent was adequate. Four days after that, the debate concluded with an agreed levy of 12 per cent.

While originally we were being told that one of the reasons why we should not drop from 15 per cent to 12 per cent was that ABARE had said that would actually lower the return to woolgrowers, the Bureau said that lowering the levy would increase the return to woolgrowers. This would mean $600 to the average woolgrower, $300 to a broadacre farmer and $300 to a sheep-beef producer. In these days of negative incomes for many woolgrowers, those are worthwhile amounts.

The point I want to make is that ABARE needs to be careful. It should want to maintain its role as an independent organisation whose projections and calculations are seen to have integrity, but its role during that wool tax debate indicated otherwise. It would be wise in the future for it not to allow its standards to slip in the way they did then. We support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments to the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) are related to the Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991, the Primary Industries and Energy (R&) Act 1989 and the Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Act 1991. The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) basically covered the intricacies of the amendments and the need for them. Put simply, the Attorney-General's Department has advised that the wording of the existing legislation is such that it is not possible to appropriate and transfer to the wool statutory authorities wool tax imposed on wool sold prior to 1 July 1991 but received by the Commonwealth after that date. The situation has to be rectified and, consequently, these amendments are being put through.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the defect in the legislation, since early July the wool statutory authorities have not had access to the flow of wool tax funds which they should have had. They would therefore have incurred additional expense, either through interest forgone or through additional interest costs on borrowed funds.

The Government considers that the statutory authorities and, through them, the woolgrowers, should not have to bear-and I think this is important to note-the additional expense caused by the omissions. Therefore, the Government will pay interest for the period of the delay in the wool tax payments.

The Bill provides that the Minister will determine the interest rate to apply. I envisage that the rate will be based on that which the Commonwealth earns on the investment of its surplus funds. The Bill also proposes that interest will be payable by the Commonwealth on the delay in payment to the wool statutory authorities of wool tax money received by the Commonwealth immediately before 30 June 1991 but not paid out until after that date while the legal question was being resolved.

There is also an amendment to carry over into the new legislation for wool research and development, provisions to reflect the existing Commonwealth policy of matching research and development funds raised by primary industries up to a ceiling of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production of the amount of the levy collected.

The Dried Fruits Export Charges Act 1924, which was repealed on 1 July 1991, provided the funds for the former Dried Fruits Corporation. A problem arose in making payments to the new board of funds raised under the Act but collected by the Commonwealth after the date of repeal.

As I have said, this is a small amendment to correct some mistakes. I think it is important to recognise that we are all human. It is understandable, bearing in mind the workload on this House and the amount of legislation that needs to be dealt with, that in a not perfect world mistakes will be made. It is necessary to correct them. I think it is important to recognise that the amount of effort and work that goes on in this House is not often recognised outside of this chamber. In this respect, I am speaking about not only parliamentary staff but also politicians from both sides of the House.

As a result of modern technology, we are seen to be in five places at once. People want us to be back in our electorate as well as down here in Canberra. We are going to have to grapple with the question of whether we spend more time down here in Parliament and how that relates to the needs and requirements of our constituencies. Over the next few years, this question is going to create partisan debate. How are we to meet the requirements of our constituency both at home and in this Parliament?

I believe that the Government has taken a lead by introducing a package of measures to assist the wool industry in this country through these tough times. It has not been easy. But wool is now showing some positive signs of fighting back. That is good. Of course, it is very important that the industry should do so.

During the course of the last two years, the Government has striven to address the critical situation facing Australian woolgrowers. The Government's aim is that this will lead to the recovery of the Australian wool industry. The Government has suspended the operation of the reserve price scheme; extended the period of Commonwealth guarantee on approved Australian Wool Corporation borrowings beyond 1 July 1992; implemented the wool industry supplementary payments scheme; and enabled the Minister to issue to the AWC guidelines in relation to reducing the AWC's indebtedness. The AWC has indicated its willingness to work with the Government to implement this recovery plan. No-one expects an immediate recovery. The reduction of the stockpile and the AWC debt to manageable levels could take several years. The Government is committed to seeing the difficult process through.

In a recent press release from the National Farmers Federation, Mr Graham Blight, the NFF President, urged woolgrowers `to put industry and political trauma behind them and concentrate on rebuilding their industry'. He went on to say that the Wool Council of Australia had achieved a responsible result from negotiations with the Government on wool industry legislation. He welcomed new structures to manage the industry and announced that the challenge before the industry now is to make the new arrangements work smoothly and build confidence in the marketplace. That is of fundamental importance. He said:
The wool industry is an integral and valuable part of the rural sector, and now that this debate has ended, we must focus on rebuilding the industry for the benefit of all Australians.

I fully endorse those remarks. There has been a promising upswing in the market this year. The ratio of wool to synthetic prices has fallen. This is stimulating demand and, I believe, enabling more product to be sold. Lower prices should result in overproduction being reduced more quickly. Certainly, all of us in this chamber will hope that this will be the case.

We need now to get some enthusiasm and vision into the wool industry to give growers confidence to press on. There is no doubt that things will recover. The rural sector is tough and it will get back on its feet. If wool is to survive and prosper, it must be competitive. It must be able to compete with all of the substitutes in today's world.

The Government is fully prepared to take action to ensure the survival of this great industry. Although the outlook is daunting, the industry has the financial strength to trade through its difficulties. It has a sound long term future. By working together and facing the need for tough decisions-at the farm and family level, at industry levels and at State and national levels-we can ensure that that future is realised.

One of the things that causes me and, I am sure, all members of the House concern, is the way in which events in Russia will impact on our trade. Only time will tell what will happen. We must hope that sanity will prevail in that country and that we are able to maintain our market share. That might sound a bit selfish. But I think it is about time we were a little selfish because every other country is. We certainly cannot afford to lose any access to the markets that we have built up in Russia.

In closing, I would like to give my support to ABARE. I do not want to say this in a derogatory way, but I do not agree with the remarks that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), made about ABARE. He does have a right make those comments. However, I would like to compliment ABARE for the work that it has done in these tough times. The Bureau has been under a lot of pressure and I think it has done an outstanding job. We do need to work together as a team. Certainly, constructive criticism-whether it be in respect of the Government or people in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy-is welcome. I support the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is one of the first public indications of the conflict between the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) and the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke). This Bill has been introduced to correct errors that were made by the Government. It is not a matter of the Government not having time to look at legislation. The fundamental reason for introducing this Bill is that in two instances the Government did not realise that on the termination of legislation all the powers and obligations in respect of funds accrued under that legislation end. When one introduces new legislation, one has to provide transitionary arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the Australian Labor Party and the present Treasurer (Mr Kerin)-the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy-have been and are under great pressure, given the extent to which they find themselves unable to work out their future leadership problems. But my concern is not about that-whoever is leader, I cannot see Labor leading Australia out of the very considerable economic difficulties which even the new Treasurer today called a depression. To my mind, the situation sadly is not only exacerbated by the Budget that was introduced yesterday. Because of the measure we are now debating and because of the implications for the rural sector generally, the situation is also going to be a lot worse before it gets better.

I do not think many people understand the extent to which wool incomes and wheat incomes-two of the primary sources of income in rural Australia-are going to continue to contract. Farmers will find when they get their annual income this year that their expectations are going to be significantly underrealised.

Lest it be thought that wool is the only source of income of people running sheep, let me explain to the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) that wool grows on sheep and sheep need to be sold. Old sheep that are not sold eat grass in paddocks that young sheep should be on. While a great deal is being done within the industry to try to identify ways in which we can breed sheep to produce wool that is saleable, if old sheep cannot be sold there is going to be an enormous problem in this country. There has been a reduction in flock numbers. This has been contributed to by a slaughter scheme, which I opposed and still oppose. Prices received for sheep now being sold in an effort to reduce flock numbers or cull in accordance with age or for other reasons have been reduced to such an extent that people in the wool industry are going to have a very lean time.

In my electorate of New England it is almost impossible to sell old ewes. Wethers that last year were able to bring from $15 to $20 are now flat out bringing $2 to $3, and a real crisis is developing because this year's wool income will be so much below the price received last year. Without going back into it all, we should remember that the crisis in the wool industry is largely the result of decisions taken by this Labor Government. There were any number of alternatives to the arbitrary reduction of the 870c reserve price.

I do not want to go over that debate, but I put before the House, the industry and the Wool Council the fact that, had that 870c been preserved on fleece wools, none of the present disaster, in my view, would have occurred. We could have got rid of a lot of the rest of the wool and taken it from the reserve price scheme, but the present Treasurer arbitrarily intervened and reduced the price to 700c; he then suspended sales and the market collapsed. Much of the flow-on effect, without any doubt, dates back to the way in which he interfered, and as a result of the collapse of the reserve price scheme we have this legislation.

The new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has told the House that the legislation was introduced in haste and passed after too short an examination. There are several aspects to that. First, there was no need for the legislation to be introduced in that way and there was certainly no need for the hurried consideration it had in this Parliament. Sure, it terminated on 30 June, but the Parliament did not rise on 30 June. There were any number of other opportunities for us to return.

Secondly, if the Minister believes his rhetoric, there has been the device, which the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) recommended long since, of reintroducing legislation committees. Had we had a legislation committee we could have looked at the detail of the legislation, seen the areas where it might have failed, and I suspect we might have picked this up. In legislation committees there is a Minister who is responsible for the legislation, his officials and, if you like, a few parliamentary counsel and a few representatives of the Attorney-General's Department. We go through the legislation clause by clause and examine the implications of difficult pieces of legislation.

I know that as a Minister it tends to be a bit disruptive of one's time-far be it from a Minister to deign to come into the Parliament to hear the views of mere parliamentarians!-but, sadly, this legislation indicates the time wasted when they do not get it right. I think it is an absolute disgrace for the Government not to be able to get it right in a matter of this order. It is not just one Bill; it is a series of Bills. It is no use pretending that it was difficult, as the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), suggested, because we are all terribly busy people and we really did not have the time. I can tell him that the woolgrowers out in the community are not interested in how busy he is. The point is that he is being paid; half of them are not. Half of them are in a loss situation.

Honourable members opposite should talk to some of the children who have been forced to withdraw from school. Government members have spoken about the extent to which the Government has dealt with the problems in rural Australia, but I can tell the Minister at the table, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, that if he goes out into some of the areas in my electorate he will see children whose parents are not able to keep them at school, who will find this year that they are going back to the dark pre-World War II days of our grandfathers, when many children did not get more than a primary education.

That is the sort of thing the Labor Government has done. Honourable members opposite might be proud that the Government is trying to introduce deregulatory programs and policies. I can tell them that a lot of farmers are going broke and do not know what will happen to them, a lot of towns are closing, a lot of shops are vacant and businesses no longer operate. There are people on the dole and 26 per cent of young people are unemployed. They are looking at the Labor Government and asking, `Is this a Labor Government? Is this the Government that represents us?'. I can tell the Minister that it might have been all right in the Storeman and Packers Union and the ACTU, but on this side of the House we think that people are more important than some of the philosophies and isms and ologies the Government has been pursuing. When the people in the cities start to suffer because the income in the country goes down and the consumption that has remained gradually falls away, the Government will notice the result of what is a depression getting even worse.

As far as the decisions of this new Minister are concerned, there are a number of other problems. I was delighted to hear my colleague the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), who is the shadow Minister for primary industries and energy, refer to the arbitrary and nonsensical decision by the Minister to reduce promotion. When things are tough and we want to sell things, we have to get out into the marketplace and look at our product. If the Minister had done his reading he would know that there had been a significant move within the Australian Wool Corporation, as it was previously constituted, to place some greater emphasis on wools in the middle micron range. They are largely the wools represented in the stockpile and they have not been selling well. Those middle wools, as they were called, are wools that the AWC had intended to embark on an extensive campaign to promote.

I know there are different arguments about the quality of the efforts of the International Wool Secretariat and the promotion campaign by the AWC, but in my view it is only by promoting wool and letting those who at the moment are buying other fibres understand the merits and qualities of the natural breathing fibre of wool that we have any chance at all of re-establishing one of our major primary industries. I know the Minister has been running around the country talking about added value and the extent to which we can process to a greater degree in Australia. We have all been on about that for years and all of us support it, but we must look at the realities: if we cannot sell overseas the raw wool produced on the farms and if we try to sell processed or even scoured wool, we will run into all sorts of tariff and non-tariff impediments.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think we are trying to get reduced at the GATT?

—My friend, Australia has been at that GATT round for about 40 years. I have heard nothing new in the Uruguay Round that I did not hear in the Kennedy Round. It is like the concern we all have at the events in the Soviet Union or Yugoslavia. Of course we have concerns. We have concerns about what happens in the G7. We have real worries, but we have very little influence. It was a nonsense to send the Minister to Europe to try to persuade the Europeans to drop protection. I can tell the Minister that over the years far better men than he, from John McEwen onwards, have been there repeatedly. We have not been able to get the message through because the difficulties there are not a matter of rhetoric. They are matters of land ownership, of generation after generation of tenant farmers. The European protection is not there for economic reasons but for social reasons, because of the link with the tenant peasant farmer whose great-great grandfather or even great-great-great grandfather was first given the right to farm that bit of dirt. Our problem is that we have to put in place an advocacy which is not occasional but which is constant.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was first appointed Minister for Overseas Trade Representations so that we could get a continued presence in Brussels. The Government had a whole lot of Ministers who hardly ever visited there. When the former Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Lionel Bowen, for whom I have a great deal of personal respect, was Minister for Trade I do not think he visited Japan for the first 12 months of his appointment. The Government should take a leaf out of New Zealand's book. Look at marketing: New Zealand did not arbitrarily reduce the promotion funds from 4 per cent to 3 per cent, as this Government did four days after this levy went through and without telling a soul. New Zealand did not and does not act-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not right.

—I am sorry, it might have been five days; but this Government arbitrarily reduced it. Nobody knew, and the Government did not tell the Parliament. From the Government's point of view, it is all a matter of trying to get the money. The Government has not understood that, because the Australian Wool Corporation and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission have been selling more wool from the stockpile, the funds are already better. We all know that the volume of wool being produced this year as a result of seasonal conditions will be significantly lower than it was. The projections from ABARE, from the Minister's Department and from the Wool Council show that the position will be significantly better. There is little doubt, as my colleague the honourable member for Murray said, that with a 10 per cent levy we can adequately fund the needs of each of these bodies for research, for promotion and for the servicing of the stockpile. We could have done it with a 4 per cent allocation, certainly for the next 12 months, to the Australian Wool Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me pick up two things from that. The first is the parallel with New Zealand that I suggested. Looking at what New Zealand has done in Europe, we have to respect the way in which New Zealand has maintained a foot in the door there. New Zealand is still selling dairy products in Europe; it is still selling lamb there. New Zealand has done a brilliant job in marketing. I do not think I have ever heard of a better marketing exercise than New Zealand persuading the rest of the world that Chinese gooseberries are Kiwi fruit. It is brilliant, and New Zealand has done it effectively and constantly.

New Zealand has succeeded by persisting. It is not an occasional on and off effort. We go for a trip to Europe, knock on a few doors and say, `How are you, Bill, Joe, Harry, Klaus'-whoever it happens to be-and think that that is what it is all about. It is not. New Zealand does it constantly and we have to do it constantly and we have to do it better. Above all, we should not reduce funding if we want to do our promotion better. We have to maintain our funding, maintain the opportunity to have a presence there and understand not just the concerns of the producer in Australia but the concerns of the European consumers.

That is what it is all about. The whole nonsense of the GATT program is not just that it disrupts international trade. The producers are not subsidising anybody; it is the consumers in European and other countries that are doing the subsidising because they are paying a lot more than they should. If the efficient Australian producing industry were able to have free access for its agricultural produce, the prices to consumers around the world would decline, the volume of sales would increase, and I believe we would all be a lot better off.

So I have no argument with the Minister about the purport of the Cairns Group or our GATT negotiations or the significance of the talks he is about to have in Europe. I do have very real concerns that we have not been sufficiently effective over the last eight years in maintaining pressure. While we are trying to maintain that pressure, it would be a jolly good thing if we went to the Middle East as well, because one of the things that has happened is that the live sheep trade has virtually been lost.

Sure, we have had problems trying to establish the extent to which veterinary standards and veterinary inspection requirements by the European countries are beyond the capacity of us to set before sheep leave Australia. Scabby mouth has been an enormous problem. I am not sure of the answer, but I think we have to find one because I can tell honourable members that, if we could lift by even $10 a head the price received for sheep from Australia, that as much as anything would get many of the rural producers out of the very difficult financial times they are in.

Overall, this Bill was not necessary. The reason that this legislation has finished up before us again is that the Government has been too busy with the internal debate between the honourable member for Blaxland and the honourable member for Wills to get the job done right. There was inadequate time to debate the legislation and inadequate time to scrutinise it. Furthermore, it refers to two industries, not just wool. I am sure the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) is going to refer to the Australian Horticultural Corporation, and perhaps the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) will too, because the legislation as it pertains to that industry similarly has to be adjusted.

I commend the proposals in the legislation. I think that, as the error was made, the Government has done the right thing. But the Government has not done the right thing in those other areas and my concern is that, at a time when the wool industry is suffering, when the agricultural industry is suffering, it has a ripple effect through the rest of the economy.

I do not want Australia to continue to go downhill. I wish that in the Budget yesterday and even in this legislation today we had seen something that was not just going to patch up things and just sort of make do. This does not take us ahead. All we are doing is saying, with a wish and a promise, `We are going to pay a bit of interest on money we should have given you on wool tax that has been collected'-growers' funds I might add. It is not Government money; do not let anybody be fooled. Apart from the $30m-odd that was in the Budget yesterday for wool research and development, it is basically growers' funds we are talking about. Of course, the idea of providing a fifty-fifty subsidy for wool research and development is also something we support. The difficulty with it is that when incomes are down, of course, the amount of levy we raise is down. When the amount of levy is down, it happens to coincide with the time when we need more dough. If we need more money but the rate is set, of course it means that we have to stretch things further.

On the general funding question, I know that there are some assets that can be disposed of, and we have had some debates in this place about the rapidity with which we can sell them. We also have some reserves and, when the Government talks about reducing from 4 per cent to 3 per cent the amount of money available for promotion, what it says is, `Oh yes, but you have reserves that you can turn to' and they are in fact the funds on which the Wool Corporation and the Wool Realisation Commission have been depending in this interregnum until this legislation is passed. But we have to understand that reserves are reserves and, once they are run down, they are no more.

I certainly want to get this levy down, I want to get wool sold, and I want to improve the position of primary producers. I say to the Minister that I do not really think that this legislation is going to advance the cause a great deal. Sure, it patches up; it gets rid of a mistake that has been made but, if it had been properly done in the first place, this legislation would not be necessary now. A mistake has been made and it is being patched up, but it is not going to do anything about really solving the problem.

I commend the appointment of Mr Jackson as Managing Director of the Wool Corporation. I think Mac Drysdale, the new Chairman, has done a first-class job in selecting him. I believe he will be an outstanding figure. I look forward, as a parliamentarian, to working with him in that role.

I express on behalf of my constituents a real concern about the future direction of the wool industry but, before I close, I would like to say that there are a few people out there who are getting off their butts and doing something. I have two such people in my electorate: Bob and Annette Gill. They are a couple of locals who have spent something over a quarter of a million dollars developing a new wool fibre testing facility in a town called Walcha, not far from where I live. They have done that because they intend to encourage flock owners to individually test the micron count of each of the sheep within their flock. That will mean that they will be able to say, if they are describing a fleece as an 18 micron fleece, that every sheep in that flock is going to be 18 micron. It means that the buyer will know what he is getting, and it means that the end product is going to be certain. It is the way we have to go. So we do have people who are out there working hard, and thank goodness we do. I think that at this time the industry has never needed them more because, frankly, the Government gives it little help.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I am a little disappointed, and I can only say to the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) that, were we being broadcast to the woolgrowers of this country, his status would have been reduced to that of the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) because he had little to contribute and was not in any way constructive. There is no doubt that we are in here today because of a piece of bureaucratic incompetence. No-one denies that. But it is really of small importance. The legislation is being corrected without cost to woolgrowers, so there is no need to make a great issue of it. There is no need to suggest that it in any way undermines the slow recovery that we hope is taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address a few of the remarks that were made by the right honourable member for New England while they are fresh in my mind. He blamed the Government for the demise of the wool industry. This is a most absurd notion. I am on record as saying it is my belief that the previous Minister must bear some responsibility. When the Wool Corporation and the Wool Council agreed to put the price of wool to 870c, it was then that the seeds of the demise of the industry were sown. All the foreign indicators at the time were that wool had turned.

Raising wool to that price meant it had to meet headlong the falling price for wool-and that is exactly what happened. I believe that that was apparent when the then Minister went to Roma, and I believe he should have used the reserve power he had to tell the Wool Corporation and the Wool Council that they were nuts, that they were incompetent, and that he was not going to allow it. The fact that he did not do that means that, in a sense, he acquiesced. To that extent, he certainly has to bear some responsibility. Similarly, when the price was moved to 700c in the circumstances it probably was not enough and we should have moved to free the market then. Of course, with hindsight, that is very easy to say.

But the right honourable member for New England puts the blame on the Government although woolgrowers have belatedly realised that it was their wool councillors and the Corporation that sold them out. I can tell people out there in the real woolgrowing land that there is no great angst against this Government for its performance. They realise that this Government did what seemed appropriate at the time. People's criticism is much more correctly levelled at those in the Corporation, and the National Party and the Liberal Party were of course their friends and confidantes.

The right honourable member for New England suggested to us that reducing promotion was a dastardly act. The truth is that we could have wiped promotion out altogether for this year and it would not have made one iota of difference.

If we had our heads screwed on right and had not been emotionally inclined, we would have done just that. What is selling wool now is not quality; it is price. Wool is cheap and that is why it is selling and, when something is selling because it is cheap, it does not need to be promoted. It would have been better to have saved our money for later on. So let us be done with the nonsense that the Government has in any way threatened promotion by reducing the amount. In any case, there is enough fat in the Wool Corporation's promotion account for it to pick up the amount that was lost.

We ought to have a close look at what these geniuses have achieved in promotion. Let us not forget that the International Wool Secretariat was controlled by the Australian Wool Corporation, which had the votes and the numbers to control its operations. If it did not, it stands condemned; if it did, it stands condemned. But the responsibility must be sheeted home to the Australian Wool Corporation because it had the numbers on the board.

What do we get from promotion? We saw the great scheme to push wool into blends-the Fletcher Jones scheme-which was going to save the industry by selling a million bales of wool into America. It was a very expensive program costing some $70m. I think that 2,000 bales were sold, which works out at something over $400 a kilogram for promotion costs. And the right honourable member for New England talks about promotion!

Similarly, one could be equally cynical about research and development. The reality is that in recent times there has been very little of value from Australian research and development. An enormous amount of money has been put into that area. Most of the worthwhile developments, certainly at the fabric end, have come out of the mills of Biella in northern Italy at no cost to the Australian grower. It may be that there was some research and development put into growing more wool. In the event of a record wool clip, it does not seem such a good investment.

The right honourable member for New England also referred to tariffs on wool. To my knowledge there are no tariffs on wool anywhere in the world, nor on scoured wool or tops. There are no tariffs in the user countries. Top making will take place in this country if our customers perceive that it is in their interests. Why are they going to perceive that it is in their interests to do it in Australia? There are several reasons: a considerable saving in freight-they do not have to cart the wool so far in its greasy state; a considerable saving in pollution, which is becoming an increasing problem for Europe and Japan; and, probably most significantly, there are much lower wage rates here than in their own countries. So there is a very good chance that we will see value-adding in this country to the extent of top making. I would be very cautious about going beyond top making because it is at this point that blending occurs. We simply do not have all the wools that are needed by the trade for blending. Our speciality is, of course, Australian wool.

The right honourable member digressed and referred to New Zealand, which gives me the liberty to digress as well. I hope you concur with that, Mr Deputy Speaker. New Zealand is held up as a marvel for Australia. We have to give it to New Zealand-it has been very innovative and aggressive in its marketing.

I was in Guangzhou province in northern China in June, I think it was, where acres and acres of Chinese gooseberries are grown. I said to the one of the Chinese, `What do you call this fruit?' He said, `We call them kiwifruit'. I said, `Why would you do that?' He said, `Because the Japanese do'. So they got onto the market as well; it was a marketing coup.

The reality is that New Zealand is in many ways a much better place than Australia. It kept its relationship with the UK intact when Britain went into the common market, and it is that relationship with the UK that has protected New Zealand dairy produce in Europe. In Australia the government of the day was busy untying itself from the British apron strings, where it grovelled for a century and a half, and quickly attaching itself to the American apron strings, where it now finds itself dangling. It was one of those sad examples of the cultural trends that existed in Australia, and still does, as we now try to tie ourselves to Asia.

In digressing a bit more, I will give the multifunction polis a swipe. The multifunction polis was set up, in essence, because there are people in Australia who believe in the cargo cult. They believe that somebody-in this case the Japanese-is going to come into Australia and give us technology. What a lot of nonsense. It will never happen. We are more likely to concentrate our technology in an area where the Japanese can more easily access it, and we will once again see good Australian technology being siphoned off overseas.

There are many areas in which we are way ahead of the Japanese in technology. The South Australian Government would have been much better if it had said to one of its electronic companies, `Go out and prime bid $470m for the Civil Aviation Authority airport radar contract'. Not one Australian company has been asked to tender. That is an absolute disgrace. If that prime bid had been underwritten, it would have done far more for South Australia and for this nation than by wasting money on multifunction polises.

I also want to talk about the new structure that we have in place. I am not entirely relieved that the right honourable member for New England applauds the appointment of Mr Jackson-ex-ANZ bank, ex-Elder Smiths International Wheat Sales, ex-Nylex, currently BTR. I do not see any great relevance to the wool industry there, and I hope that Mr Jackson has the ability that has been touted for him and he can provide the leadership required.
