It concerns me that under the old Wool Corporation and the old Wool Council we had this crazy notion that wool was somehow a wonder fibre, it was better, it deserved a premium and, by God, we would not sell it without that premium. That was nonsense. It is equally nonsensical to say that wool has no special virtues. It is equally absurd to trade wool just as another commodity, just as a clothing filler. The truth, of course, lies somewhere in between. There is a section of the Australian wool clip that is a unique fibre, and it is that section of the wool clip that we ought to be doing our very utmost to develop and to increase in production, because all the indications are that there is nowhere near enough of that quality wool available in the world.

The right honourable member also commented on the appointment of Mr Drysdale. My own Government tells me that is a wonderful choice. I recall that he was on the previous Wool Council. It is my often expressed view that most of those gentlemen should be in gaol. Let us hope that his performance will improve with his new responsibilities.

The present Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, who I think the rural industry is very lucky to have, has a keen interest in downstream processing. He realises the benefits this provides, not only to woolgrowers, but to the whole country. Concerns were expressed to me today at a meeting I had with members of the Wool Council that downstream processing may require some subsidy from the woolgrower. This is patently absurd. If the wool is bought on the market, how can it possibly require any subsidy from the woolgrower? When they were pushed to explain it, they realised that they were, once again, a victim of their own prejudices.

Given that there are some unique aspects of Australian wool fibre, we ought to have a very hard look at what we are doing with this genetic material. On a couple of occasions we have looked at this issue and decided to continue to allow the sale of Australian merinos. The arguments are basically economic. We are told that Australian merinos have no real benefit; it is an economic advantage that one can run sheep in Australia without having to house them in the winter; and that we are not going to inconvenience ourselves or act in any way that is detrimental to ourselves by allowing foreigners to have it.

Another reason which is advanced by the Wool Council is that we must improve the quality of the wool going to our customer countries. We must do this as some sort of incentive for them to buy our wool. I cannot understand that logic; it eludes me. Even the National Party of Australia would be very hard put to explain that. The reality is that Russia and China want Australian genetic material to upgrade their wool so that they can buy less from us. It is simply economics for them. They want to save their very hard earned currency and-something which is very important to them-their foreign currency. Let there be no mistake about it; they want to upgrade the quality of their wool so that they need to buy less from us.

One must also ask: if Australian merinos are of no benefit to overseas buyers, why is it that overseas buyers have been paying the top prices at the recent stud sales? Are we to presume that they are stupid? Does anyone seriously believe these people are stupid? They buy because they perceive it as an advantage. The advantage is the improvement of their flocks in the areas where Australia excels-that is, in the evenness of fibre diameter, the quality that gives character to the wool, and in the lack of black fibres in the wool.

The only way anyone is going to improve these qualities in the short term is by using Australian genetic material. What is happening overseas? People, particularly in South America, are very keen to get the services of Australian sheep classers. Many Australian sheep classers are going there, culling their flocks and showing them how to do the upgrading. We cannot do much about that, and it will certainly advance them, but why would we make it easier for them by making available to them the genetic basis which is, after all, the reason for our supremacy in this area?

I am told by people in the trade that the average Argentinean or Uruguayan flock has about 500 black fibres per kilogram; the Australian flock has less than 10. This can be clearly seen. I put it to honourable members that, even if there was no real advantage in banning the export of Australian merinos, we should do it now as a sign of unity, as a sign to the world that the free ride is over: no longer is Australia going to carry promotion for the world; no longer are we going to act as the great rich uncle to all the other producers of the world. It would be a sign that Australia really means business, and it would be a sign to the woolgrowers of this country that we, as a government, mean business.

I certainly hope that the Minister is going to give consideration to supporting a ban on the export of merinos. Of course, the studs will scream. Let them scream, in my view. Their fortune has been made out of the Australian wool industry and their long term fortune resides in the Australian wool industry.

In the general area of wool, I think it is important that Australian woolgrowers realise that there has to be an improvement in quality. We have to produce a finer wool with a more even fibre count. In this respect, it is interesting to note that the Australian Wool Testing Authority basically uses a 1940s technology for testing fibre diameter. Available to us is the Melden Laboratories' technology, which not only tells us the diameter of individual fibres, but also gives us an idea of where they are located in the staple. It is a much more advanced technology and virtually gives an instant readout.

I mention this in passing because the monopoly bestowed on the Australian Wool Testing Authority by the Australian Wool Corporation was used to try to break-to send broke-this private testing group. It did break it until the group was rescued by Swiss money. The group is now part of an international Swiss group. I wish Melden's every success because its technology is going to be very vital in advancing the production of better quality wool. I have one final word of warning. One of the briefing notes I have says:

The Corporation is required to adopt the role of a catalyst in facilitating activities in the market including the increased acceptance by the private sector of responsibility for marketing. The full implementation of sale by description is one such area where this could occur.

I see no relationship between the last sentence and the previous part of that paragraph. Sale by description is a very dangerous game. If sale by description was wanted by the trade, it would be in now. I ask honourable members to think about this: how can people enhance the sale of their product when they analyse it exhaustively and make available to their customers in a written format every fault that it contains? Clearly, it is nonsense. History has shown-contrary to an answer given to me recently by the Minister-that sale by description does reduce the market price. There is very little doubt that when the marketing genius Sven Anderssen sold the Russians on sale by description the average return to growers dropped by about 20c.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). He seems pretty confused and ill-informed about the wool industry in Australia. I was quite surprised by some of his comments. He said that there are no tariffs on greasy wool in the world. I have got news for him and I will highlight some of those matters in my speech. He said there is no value in research. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), who is at the table, would know that CSIRO has been at the forefront of research funded by the woolgrowers. It developed sirospun, which reduces processing costs. That increases processing capacity several fold; it is wonderful research. CSIRO has developed an instrument which will identify coloured fibres in wool tops-a result of woolgrower funded research. I think that is wonderful value.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Kalgoorlie says there is no value in promotion. He should ask Toyota, Sony or one of the other large Japanese corporations whether they see any value in promotion. I just point out to him the value of the cool wool promotion. It is a reason that wool is now being sold in tropical climates on a year round basis, rather than being seen as a winter-only fabric. I suggest to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie that in the future before he comes into the chamber talking about the wool industry he ought to get a better understanding of it.

The honourable member said something about sale by description not being on; he said that it lowers the price. During the last 20 years, nine million bales of wool were sold out of the stockpile by description. Not one bale came back into a wool store to be inspected again. The 4.5 million bales that are in the stockpile now are all going to be sold by description. They are located around the world, as well as in Australia. In some cases they are close to the markets; in others, people are getting first stage processing. Those bales are going to be sold on description. Once the first stage of processing is done the wool is all sold on description.

The honourable member is leaving the House; he does not want to hear the truth of the matter. Let me go on with my address. First of all, I declare my interest as a woolgrower. Only two weeks ago, I sold my wool and paid my 12 per cent wool tax. I was thankful it was 12 per cent, and not 15 per cent. There was a little bit extra in it for me because of that; but there could have been a lot more, I would advise the Minister. When I talk about it, I think I have a little understanding because for most of my life I have been a woolgrower-not a person in charge of the Storemen and Packers Union or a union movement, though I do not take that away from the Minister.

Today, the price for wool is 530c per kilogram. That is the indicator. It has fallen since the opening of sales late in July. They are figures which are a long way above those used for our calculations or for those of the Government and ABARE. Those calculations were done on about 450c and 470c a kilogram.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a different indicator.
—Certainly a different indicator. Today's indicator, based on the one prior to 30 June, still represents about 510c on the old scale.
—Get the facts right.

—I have the facts right. The Minister will have his chance to speak later. I want to tell the Minister that 10 per cent was a very conservative figure. It certainly was a sustainable figure, as is being supported by the evidence now. Perhaps we were short of evidence, but we certainly had plenty of assumptions prior to 30 June, and now we are seeing the evidence. The Minister's proposal of 15 per cent was a reckless figure. It is now being supported every day in the wool sales. We already know that the Corporation will be able to meet the Minister's predictions for a debt reduction program. It has sold enough wool to cover that.
—It has not; but I will answer it.
—It is well on the way. Every day we are seeing that it is well on the way.
—Okay; but it has not done it. Get your facts right.

—On our assumptions, the Corporation is well on the way. The Minister has taken additional cash flow away from woolgrowers at a time when they are facing the worst economic crisis of their lives. He knows as well as I do that what we are seeing now is the tip of the iceberg emerging in this recession. I put it to the Minister that, if we had a 10 per cent tax instead of a 12 per cent tax, for every 5,000 sheep the growers would receive an extra $2,500 in their bank accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: During the winter recess I have taken a hands-on approach in representing my constituents. I have been right around the electorate-to Charleville, Goondiwindi, St George and to the dedicated wool areas of Stanthorpe and Texas. I was told that some of the dedicated woolgrowers will soon be walking off. They are hanging in there now, but their first line of defence-and it is a sad one-was that they had brought their children home from school. We are facing the possibility of a whole generation of children being denied a further education-or even a basic education. Some of the kids who are coming home do so to live with their parents because it is cheaper at home than away at a boarding school or a hostel in a town nearby.

The other day I was at the School of the Air in Charleville. In the last eight months it has had a 30 per cent increase in its enrolment, which has increased from 310 to 430. That backs up my statement that kids are being withdrawn from school. They are going home and they are getting a different form of education-and I must say that the people at the School of the Air in Charleville do a wonderful job-but it cannot be of the same quality as they were getting previously. They do not have access to a computer in the schoolroom. They do not have access to all the other facilities that kids in the cities take for granted. They are living up to 300 and 400 kilometres west of Charleville and the nearest town could have a one-teacher school, like the one that I visited last Saturday. It had nine kids in the school. That is what we are seeing. What I have done through the winter recess is get around with a hands-on approach and listen.

The people out there congratulated us on this side of the House on our approach to the wool tax debate. They would love to have had that bit of extra money coming into their bank accounts-it is vital-because at the end of this year if they have to walk off those properties, not only will they be penniless but they will lose the family home as well. They will be homeless and penniless.

I was interested to notice how the Minister arrived at his figure of 12 per cent at the end of the day. Perhaps he had been talking to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. He said that promotion was not worth while: `we will cut promotion by one per cent to make the figure look a little better'. However, I will not be opposing the Minister on the 2 1/2 per cent for promotion. The Corporation certainly has to look at how it will promote from here on; it is a much tougher job. But I do not believe that at a time when prices are lower we should be cutting our promotional effort.

Earlier the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) gave a wonderful speech. He said that the New Zealanders have been great marketers and great promoters. This is a time when we should be spending more on promotion, not less. The only accurate forecast that I could make about ABARE, from the figures it presents continually, is that its figures will always prove to be wrong.

One thing I would like the Minister to address is the multifibre agreement, which comes under the rules of GATT, because I believe it is critical to the debate on free trade and fair trade. The multifibre arrangement, which commenced in 1974, attempts to regulate international trade in textiles and apparel and it comes under the GATT Round of negotiations. It divides all fabrics, fibres and garments into categories. Within each category, agreements are negotiated between the supplier and the importer.

That agreement, which Australia still runs under, flies in the face of so-called free trade. While raw wool producers are desperately striving to compete on world markets, we have a system within the textile industry, covered by the multifibre agreement, which flies in the face of that free trade. It was supposed to expire on 31 July this year, which passed 20-odd days ago. However, it had an extension of time because of the Uruguay Round and to see how the Cairns Group gets on. From what the Europeans are saying about that multifibre agreement, it could take 15 years to phase out. The original intent of the multifibre agreement was to give developing countries access to major markets whilst also regulating their own. As the Minister has said so often in this debate on free trade, especially wheat recently, it means access to free and fair markets.

The honourable member for Kalgoorlie said that he did not think there were any tariffs on wool around the world. I have a table on import tariffs. On taking greasy wool into India there is a 20 per cent tariff plus a 5 per cent levy. To get greasy wool into China, it will cost 15 per cent--

TALK.START.PARA: —I said `scoured wool'.
—Scoured wool, too.
—If it is on greasy wool, it doesn't make any difference, does it?

—The honourable member has had his chance. To get carbonised-scoured-wool into the United States of America it will cost 28.7c a kilogram. To get unscoured wool in it costs 22c a kilogram. To get in scoured wool and wool tops for further processing to add value to make into ready-to-sell products there is a 12 1/2 per cent tariff. So there are tariffs on the import of our wools into other countries.
—Tell us about northern Europe and Japan.

—The honourable member has had his go; he should give me one. I hope-as I think does every member of the Parliament-that we see an outcome from GATT. I would desire nothing further, nor would anyone in this House, than to see success at GATT.

SPEECH.PARA: We should also be looking at the multifibre agreement, because that will give Australia an opportunity to add value to wool. One of the things that the Minister has so often spoken about is adding value to our products. Australia could add value to its wool and cotton if we were able to get access to markets with the made-up product, to these other markets, and not to have to come under the multifibre agreement. So it is an important matter and I hope that the Minister will take it up.

It is almost time for the suspension of the sitting for dinner, so I conclude by saying that it is with great reluctance that I support this Bill providing for a 12 per cent regulation. I would rather have seen this as a Bill which gave a maximum tax of 12 per cent instead of one that gave a regulated tax down to 12 per cent, because I am not sure that we can say to the woolgrowers that the Minister can be trusted not to introduce a 15 per cent tax next year. On behalf of my constituents I express concern about the way that the Minister arrived at that 12 per cent figure. We were right and I believe that the evidence even today suggests that we were right. I am sure that time will prove that our figures were correct.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. Due to a number of comments that have been made by honourable members about the tax rate and its implications, I want to go over the ground that I know we have already covered in this Parliament, but not so as much in this Budget session. The 15 per cent tax was based on certain parameters that had changed by the time the wool legislation package came before Parliament in June. The Industry Committee revised that estimate of shorn wool production in the 1991-92 season downwards from 914 kilotonnes to 881 kilotonnes greasy.

SPEECH.PARA: In light of the performance in the market, ABARE increased its 1991-92 season price forecast from 435 cents per kilogram clean to 475c per kilogram clean. Recalculations based on these changes produced a tax rate of 13 to 13 1/2 per cent as the level which maximised returns to both the taxpayer and the woolgrower. When the Commonwealth grant of $22 1/2m in each of 1991-92 and 1992-93 for interest supplementation on the $200m commercial loan pending asset sales was taken into account, this brought the wool tax back to around 12 to 12 1/2 per cent. Interest and storage charges alone in the stockpile are estimated by the Wool Realisation Commission at $340m in 1991-92. The Commission's 9 per cent share of wool tax is estimated to bring in $248m, so a further $92m is needed just to service the debt, on top of which the debt must be reduced by $20m.

Unless very large quantities of wool are sold from the stockpile and we have a consequent reduction in returns to woolgrowers even further, the total tax below 12 per cent would be extremely risky. In fact, honourable members who have spoken before me have said that originally the Government was taking from the farmer by its proposal for 15 per cent tax. Of course, it was not doing anything like it. What was really happening was that we were looking for the best adjustment in the interest of the industry. This is what some of the speakers have failed to recognise, that whichever way one goes, in the end the industry itself is affected, as well as the income of farmers and their ability to sell. No matter happens, they are being affected.

We are now finding that the market is settling down and by 15 August in just a few weeks it had fallen 57c to be 540c per kilogram. It is too early to judge what will happen in the future, but I understand there was a further drop yesterday of 9c. If things turn out better than the estimates suggest, then the mechanisms are built into the legislation that would enable wool tax rates to come down next year.

There has also been controversy about the apportionment of the wool tax. I am glad all honourable members are supporting the legislation, but their support is not always reflected in what they have had to say nor in what some industry people-but by no means official industry-have had to say. Apportionment of the 12 per cent wool tax for 1991-92 is 9 per cent for debt management, 2 1/2 per cent for promotion and 1/2 per cent for R&. Industry was expecting 8 per cent for debt reduction and 3 1/2 per cent for promotion.

I had discussions, along with other honourable members, with the Wool Council of Australia representative here today, Mr Alan Bowman, who is in the Parliament today and will be tomorrow. He did acknowledge that, taking into account that the Government was giving a commitment for this year, 2 1/2 per cent was adequate. So we have it from the people who should really know-the Wool Council of Australia-that, taking into account that we are looking at a year, 2 1/2 per cent is adequate. What happens after that year is important to the Wool Council; it is important to the industry; and it is important to the Government. It is extremely important that the industry, the Government and all others involved make sure that we have the right data so that a decision can be made based on proper discussion and data at the end of that year. Meanwhile, the Wool Council is saying that it is satisfied.

The Opposition has been critical of the way the Government has moved on this legislation, but the Opposition's record is not all that good. It has never been game to take decisions. It moves into systems too late and reluctantly. Very often, it does not move when it should and it does not move out of them when it should. The economy is fairly fluid; we need to be fluid in our approach. Our approach on the world market involves very careful consideration of the way we go financially and the way we manage our industries. The Opposition would not move into wheat stabilisation when it was needed; it will not adjust that when it is appropriate. It did not move into the wool reserve price plan when it was being called for and when it was quite useful, but it would not support getting rid of it when the whole concept of the reserve price plan changed. It had a poor record on tariffs and, for all the noise about free trade today, it is, on its record, a high tariff coalition.

Protection gave Australia bad habits; the Opposition was part of that. Prices were boosted to meet cost demands and, of course, this meant that Australia was not in the real world. The Opposition has been somewhat critical of the Government's move in GATT, but it is vital to keep moving when making progress, however slight that progress is. We all have to acknowledge, while acknowledging the point made by many in the industry, in Opposition and in Government, that we also need to look at bilateral relationships; we need to look at Asia and other relationships. The legislation result is an actual correction-I suppose you could call it-of previous legislation. It is important that we do it. I welcome the fact that it looks as though all honourable members are going to support the legislation.

Mr COBB (Parkes) (8.08 p.m.) As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) said, this Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 is, to use the words of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) in the second reading speech, `to correct omissions and drafting errors' in the original legislation. The Minister in his speech says:

. . . it is not possible to appropriate and transfer to the wool statutory authorities wool tax imposed on wool sold prior to 1 July 1991 but received by the Commonwealth after that date. Clearly, the situation needs to be rectified and the provisions of this Bill do that.

The Government forgot to provide for the transition period of levies collected before 30 June. I understand there could be something up to the $90m for funds frozen that cannot be paid to the Wool Realisation Commission or the Wool Corporation and the Research and Development Corporation. But I have been informed that the Government has been able to transfer about $30m of this through regulation, but needs legislation to transfer the other $60m.

The same problem apparently has arisen with levies collected after the date of repeal of the old Australian Dried Fruits Corporation, which was replaced by the Australian Dried Fruits Board under the wing of the Australian Horticultural Corporation. Levies collected by the Commonwealth for the ADFC after the date of repeal will be recovered and this money will be paid to the ADFB. In addition to these two corrections, the Commonwealth will also pay compensation for losses incurred due to these late payments. I understand this will be an amount equal to interest received by the Government while the money has been waiting to be transferred. The coalition would certainly support that action being taken.

I wish now to make some comments on the wool tax levels the Government has imposed on the financially strapped woolgrowers of Australia. Initially the Government tried to impose on woolgrowers a 15 per cent tax level after 1 July this year, which coalition members felt was totally unnecessary. We all know that Government members joined with the Democrats after considerable debate and everybody settled at 12 per cent, even though 10 per cent was the figure aimed at by the coalition. We still feel that 10 per cent was the level needed to collect the amount of money necessary to service the situation in the wool industry. Having had the benefit of observing the open market situation that has been operating since 1 July, we believe our calculations are even more justified and that a 10 per cent tax level is not only achievable but has been pitched at a very conservative level.

The Australian Wool Realisation Commission has a very difficult job. I understand it sold 104,000 bales of wool in July this year, quite a large proportion of that being from overseas stores, and has received an amount of about $71m for that. The Wool Realisation Commission debt reduction target set by the Government for 1991-92 is of the small order of $20m. This Commission has a total loan servicing and storage cost of $350m, and to pay for that their share of the tax levy, which is 9 per cent of the 12 per cent tax levy, will return in round figures about $250m. That leaves a shortfall of about $100m, plus the $20m in debt reduction for this year. Having already sold $71m worth of wool from the stockpile, the Commission has to sell only another $50m or $60m worth of wool before 30 June next year to accomplish its target, which it should do comfortably.

I believe the Wool Realisation Commission stockpile selling policy up to this date has been absolutely correct and that David Clarke has done a very good job. I have not met the man, but from what I read he seems to have a very good feel about him. I think he is doing an excellent job.

The outlook as far as wool prices and clearances go at the moment is quite good, and certainly better than expected at the beginning of the year. It is true that the market indicator since 1 July this year has eased back into the 530c to 540c per kilogram range, but in some ways this is not truly indicative. Since 1 July fine wools have come down quite a bit from relatively high levels, whereas coarser wools have not come down by anywhere near as much. I believe one or two of these levels have even gone up since 1 July, so the market indicator is not quite the indicator that some people think it is so far as this price reduction is concerned.

The market indicator at the moment is down just over 25 per cent on what it was when 700c per kilogram was in place. However, if we had continued with that scheme after 1 July this year, the tax provisions that were then in place would have allowed for a tax of up to 50 per cent to be imposed on growers, with quotas on top of that. I do not think that in that sense there is much doubt that under the present scheme the growers are better off. On top of that we are getting a market clearance in excess of 90 to 95 per cent instead of the 40 per cent-odd we were getting before. It is wonderful to see market share for wool being regained; it has a very low share-4 to 5 per cent-of the world textile fibre market.

It is interesting to look at the figures for the first three weeks of this season. The trade bought 284,000 bales in the first three weeks. That is 51 per cent more wool bought by the trade than in the first five weeks of last season. It is sobering, though, to look at the figures because we are offering only 100,000 to 120,000 bales a week at present. The real test will come from about mid-October through to the end of November this year, when we will be offering from 140,000 to over 160,000 bales a week. If the market can get through what could be a fragile period without too much of a reduction, I think we will be well on the way to getting wool back again as the premier and most profitable primary industry in this country.

I wish to make some brief comments on the situation in the Soviet Union and how it will affect wool sales. There has been considerable concern since the coup in the last couple of days about the effect it will have on sales. I believe that this situation should be kept in perspective. The Government extended a $500m line of credit insurance for agricultural products-not just wool but wheat, meat and so on. That was established late last year. Of that credit facility, $421m has already been used, so there is only $79m left to be used. I understand that no repayments are due until December. It might be something to exercise the Government's mind as to what it will do if the turmoil in the Soviet Union is continuing at that time.

Of that $500m facility, $100m available to the wheat industry has already been used. Incidentally, I was very disappointed to see that in the Budget only $35.1m was set aside for the Iraq compensation. Some would argue that that is only about a quarter of what they should receive. But I digress from the purpose of the Bill.

Of the remaining $400m of the credit facility, I understand that $260m has been committed to wool and $60m to mutton. Something less than half of this, $148m in total of this $320m, has already been shipped. There is a considerable portion, $178m-worth, of these commodities that is yet to be shipped, although I am told that this is not affected where there is a contractual obligation to supply. However, if there are difficulties or concerns about shipping it to the USSR, I hope the Government will come to the party. It does concern some people. It is worth noting that the recent revival of wool demand from the USSR had already tapered off before the recent military coup in the Soviet Union. Indeed, the USSR was already a weak buyer on the market and was expected to remain so for some months.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, mentioned that the market indicator yesterday had fallen from 540c to 531c, a 9c drop, and most people were putting that down to the Soviet situation. I do not think it was concern about credit facilities; it was concern about the uncertainties created in world trading patterns, and to that extent that is unavoidable. I do not think we should get overly alarmed about the sanction, if I can call it that, of withdrawing what remains of the credit facility.

I want to pass briefly now to the promotion levy having been dropped from 3 1/2 to 2 1/2 per cent. The Minister has already come in for some comment on this from previous speakers. When the Minister's original intention to have a 15 per cent tax came in at only 12 per cent, he reduced the 3 1/2 per cent promotion levy to 2 1/2 per cent. I think there was a lot of angst in the bush. There was a feeling out there that this had been done in an underhand way. It certainly was not mentioned in debate. There was not even a whisper of it, to my recall. There was no consultation with woolgrowers; there was no consultation that I am aware of with industry leaders; there was certainly no consultation with the Parliament, and many people felt that this was outrageous. It appeared, rightly or wrongly, as though the Minister had done it in a fit of pique rather than for good reasons.

I think the Minister could have mounted an argument-perhaps even a rational argument-in favour of doing so. For example, I am told that there are reserves of $114m and that another $37m of reserves have been found there. If these figures are correct, there are $151m of reserves there. A 2 1/2 per cent levy pulls in about $65m, so in that sense there are about two years of reserves already there. If the Minister had perhaps argued this way, the overwhelming majority may not have agreed with him, but at least they would have been paid the courtesy of some sort of reasoned explanation given to them. However, that was denied to them. I do not think it was too much to ask that people could have been informed of that before it happened--

TALK.START.PARA: —They were.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister says they were, but no-one else seems to have heard of it. This is the problem. If the Minister wants to win the confidence of farmers-which I believe he would want to do-he should fully consult with them in the future because this has left a bit of a sour taste in many ways.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other little niggly things coming in. I know that the annual general meeting is now a requirement of the Wool Council, and apparently that is going to cost $300,000. It sounds an outrageously high figure to me, but if this is the case, no doubt it will be passed back to the growers. I also believe that a $150,000 bill has already been presented to the Australian Wool Corporation for the selection committee costs. That is something that people did not foresee when that came in. It is a bit like taking out a loan at a bank and finding all these little bank charges coming in later on that one has never heard of; it leaves a sour taste. If these things could be spelt out fully at the beginning, people would accept them better.

In conclusion, I hope the Minister will take on board some of these concerns. I hope he will make genuine efforts to come to terms with the very real problems of the wool industry. I know that in recent weeks the Minister has spoken a lot about value adding, et cetera, and I know of his genuine concern in that area. To me, if he does not mind my saying so, it is a little bit reminiscent of the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) running around, as he did, a couple of years ago talking about sunrise industries. These things never seem to come to fruition.

We would all like to see value adding. If the Minister can pull it off, I will be the first to welcome it; but before we get value adding in this country to the extent that we would like to see it, over and above what we have already, we will certainly need a major revamp of the industrial relations system in this country. We will need incentive and reward for effort, voluntary unionism, enterprise bargaining, and things like this. In some ways, the Minister seems to me to have spent most of his life fighting against these things. If he can somehow turn this around and work for the industry in this direction, I guess we will all applaud him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I can assure the last speaker, the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), that it has been my intention and endeavour-in fact, all of my activities-over the 11 weeks that I have been in this portfolio to get to understand the issues of concern to those in farm Australia in particular, as well as the mining sector, and to take into account their concerns and to genuinely consult. I do not think I need to remind the House to any terribly significant extent on this point, but consultation has been my way of life; I have been doing it for 20 years. I do not restrict it to one constituency, and I have not in relation to the new one I have now.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make a couple of points because I think two things ought to be said at the outset. Firstly, I agree with all the comments that this legislation before us is unnecessary. I was particularly peeved, to say the least, to find that we had this technical defect. I do not appreciate it. I accept the criticism that is levelled in this place that the issue should have been picked up earlier. I do not accept that it was as a consequence of the so-called rushed nature of the wool legislation, because the same technical problem has arisen in relation to the horticultural industry, on which there was little controversy and for which there was plenty of time.

I believe it is a significant oversight; it should not happen. We should be aware that if we are establishing new bodies, transitional arrangements are needed and the drafting should take proper account of that. I agree with all honourable members who have criticised the unnecessary circumstances in which this Bill is before the House.

The second point is that in all the debate that has taken place on this piece of legislation, not one speaker opposed it, because all speakers recognise that the legislation itself is designed to get moving as quickly as possible that money which is the entitlement of the three industry structures so that they can have it. In addition, we have undertaken to ensure that there is no financial disadvantage to those bodies. As a consequence of this legislative oversight they will be compensated, and they will be compensated on the basis-as I indicated in my second reading speech-of the earnings that the Government obviously obtained from holding the money rather than its being held by the appropriate structure.

Having said all that, despite the fact there is no disagreement about the legislation that is before us, I must say that it has still generated a fair bit of debate. I think we have been in the House for a couple of hours on these issues--

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a good thing.

—It is not a bad thing. It is a good thing at times to clear the air on some of these issues. This debate provides a more convenient opportunity to do it, I guess, than Question Time or perhaps an MPI or whatever. But there have been a couple of concerns and issues raised by those opposite in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point I think is the assertion that 10 per cent rather than the 12 per cent which we have, and compared with the Government's original proposal of 15 per cent, is the appropriate level of tax. I reject the view that 10 per cent was an appropriate figure. I join with the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) in drawing attention to the NFF press release.

He made the point that the NFF press release welcomed the 12 per cent as a sensible outcome, believed it was workable and that we should stick with it. Therefore, I think this continuing assertion that 12 per cent is workable needs to be seen against the NFF's rational assessment of the outcome. But, more than that, I think it is important to understand that I had carriage of this legislation in something of a wall of fire. I was sworn in on the Tuesday and had to deal with the legislation for the next 48 hours almost non-stop. I think that it is true to say that because circumstances changed from the original drafting of the Bill, I became convinced fairly quickly in the piece that there was room to move below the 15 per cent.

I did not for one moment accept that 10 per cent was the appropriate figure. I put not just my Department to the test but also ABARE, with which I spent a lot of time in going through these figures. A number of circumstances had changed. There was, firstly, the fact that production levels were down, and therefore that had a bearing in terms of the current clip and future operations, as well as the fact that prices were holding reasonably well at that stage, even though the forecasts that ABARE was still giving me suggested an average price of 475c a kilogram on the old scale. I will come to that point in a minute because some comparison has been made that blurs the difference between the new indicator and the old indicator.

Nevertheless, I accepted that there was some room to manoeuvre. I can admit now, because I have admitted it at various meetings of growers that I have attended around the country, and it is no secret, that on the basis of the information I had before me, when I had to be confronted with this-the legislation having been introduced into the House by my predecessor; even though the portfolio had changed, he introduced the legislation-I was prepared in that next 48 hours that I was involved to accept that there was justification for reducing and negotiating the tax down.

As a consequence of that, I had a series of meetings with the National Party and with the Opposition. I spoke to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), I spoke to the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Lloyd), and I spoke of course to the Democrats because that is where the issue was in the Senate. My bottom line was that I was prepared to accept a tax at 13 1/2 per cent and, if pushed, 13 per cent.

There were a number of assertions-and honourable members will recall the debate at the time-as to what we would realise from the asset sales, what the price would be, what the production levels would be and whether we had to pay retrenchment payments for those in the AWC. There are a number of parameters. It is important that I make the point for those who have asserted that ABARE kept them in the dark, and that there was no information exchanged, that in this debate one has to understand that there is the giving of information where it is appropriate in the negotiations, but also the recognition of commercial-in-confidence. After all, there is not much point in making our projections, putting them out in public and signalling to the market-the place where we are trying to sell the damn stuff-what our expectations are. Anyone who thinks those are smart negotiating tactics is a fool. Therefore, one has to understand that the commercial-in-confidence criteria was very appropriate.

Nevertheless, I took the Deputy Leader of the National Party through the figures, I took the Chairman and the Chief Executive Officer of the Wool Council through the figures, I took the Leader of the Opposition through the figures and I took the Democrats through the figures-the ABARE figures. Those figures demonstrated on their analysis the sort of figure that was justified, given what had to be raised simply to service the debt, and given what had to be met in terms of the Cabinet schedule for the reduction of the debt-without which there would not have been the $300m appropriation to help the ailing wool industry, the underwriting of the debt or the credit line to the Soviet Union. None of that would have been there had we not had the debt rescheduling figures in place.

People have to understand the fundamental point: it was not just an issue of the tax being a cost to growers; it was a question of the tax-growers' money-being generated sufficiently to enable, on the one hand, the reduction of the debt and, on the other, the continuing promotion and activities of the new Wool Corporation Board and of research and development.

I reject the argument of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott). I think that his assertion is so shallow. He comes into this place and says, `Anything ABARE says, you've got to reject'. What sort of considered view is that? I simply make the point that forecasts are forecasts. Whether one comes from an economic background, a trade union background, a farm background or a business background, they are forecasts-nothing more than that. But they are based on the best available information.

ABARE got its information from the industry. It did not dream it up. It spoke to the industry. It got much better advice than it would have got from the honourable member for Maranoa, who comes in here and asserts, in all his glory, that anything that ABARE says has to be rejected. I refute that. People out there in the bush, in his electorate in particular, ought to understand the shallowness of the substance with which he comes into this place to argue the case.

The significant point that I make is that, while I said that I was prepared to negotiate down to 13 per cent, I still believe that 13 1/2 per cent would have been the most appropriate figure because there would have been more opportunities if things went bad. None of us predicted what was going to happen in the Soviet Union in the last three days. It does have implications. I accept what the honourable member for Parkes says about having to see things in context, but the reality is that if we have sold wool on credit and that credit is not paid, that is a debt either to the industry or to the taxpayer generally in terms of the contingent liability that we have underwritten. Opposition members should not forget that and should not forget also that none of the wise people on their side of the Parliament were predicting that that crisis could have occurred.

The Government was saying that there is too much uncertainty. The figures that the coalition was putting up were based on a number of parameters and assumptions and, if only one went wrong, the whole thing could really be jeopardised. Therefore, it was more sensible to err on the side of caution. That is why I would have preferred to have got the 13 1/2 per cent. Having said that, I make the point that I was prepared to negotiate down to 13 per cent. That is a matter of record that can now be divulged simply because the negotiations and the issue are resolved.

We got 12 per cent, but the important thing is that as a result of the negotiations that were undertaken, and as a result of the situation that I found myself in, I was able to get a commitment from the Government to pay up-front that $22.5m, which the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) would recall was an issue in the debate in the House. It was not guaranteed. There was a belief that it had been offered and it had been withdrawn, but the fact is that we got it in the end. The fact that it was there as a concrete figure was the equivalent of one per cent. Therefore, the 12 per cent is 13 per cent but not at a cost to the grower.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you will now stay with 12?

—I indicated that I was prepared to live with 12 per cent. I believe that the National Party's position in asserting 10 per cent was irresponsible. I still believe that. I am prepared to live with 12 per cent because I think that if things go right we can get away with 12 per cent, but I cannot guarantee it. I said in the House when we debated this that I could not guarantee that the tax would continue to come down. I could have, at a higher figure, and I was prepared to guarantee it at 13 per cent. When this legislation finally got through the Parliament on 21 June I said that I could not guarantee it at 12 per cent. I hope that things improve. I agree with the honourable member for Parkes that the Realisation Commission has handled itself properly. It has handled itself well-better than properly.
—It is $71m worth.

—It is not $71m, it is $67m. I will come to those figures in a minute. The Commission has handled the situation well. On the basis that we do not have crises such as the Soviet Union has, and that we do not have a collapse in the price, it ought to be possible to get to a situation in the future where we do not have to put up the tax. It is too early to make that judgment. For the time being, it is not an issue that is before us. That is the point that I make about the 12 per cent, the 15 per cent and the 10 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The promotion and the proportionality of the 12 per cent has been raised by a number of people in the Parliament. I did not make the decision to reduce the so-called promotion from 3 1/2 per cent to 2 1/2 per cent in a fit of pique. I do not do anything in fits of pique. I consider myself to be a rational type of person. I like to consider the issues and make value judgments. I have seen others in this place do things in a fit of pique. I hope not to emulate them and I simply did not do it in this case.

In relation to the figure of 15 per cent, if we were saying that the proportional break-up was 11 per cent for the Realisation Commission, 3 1/2 per cent for promotion and half a per cent for R&, the Opposition would take 3 per cent away from us, yet not expect anything to come off promotion. I think members of the Opposition must be living in cloud cuckoo land if they do not understand the ramifications of reducing the absolute figure without expecting that it will affect the proportionality.

It is not correct to say that this was not signalled, because I indicated it to Alan Bowman of the Wool Council in discussions. I said, `If you don't give me this legislation, don't accept that by regulation I'm going to reduce the tax to 15 per cent'. If this tax was not introduced we would have had 25 per cent. That is the stupidity of the coalition's position in holding up this legislation and leaving me to determine what the tax level should be by regulation.

Under the old structure there had to be agreement with the Wool Council as to what the proportionality would be. Under the new structure there does not. I made it clear to the Wool Council that it was not going to get 15 per cent out of me by regulation as the fall back position unless I had a clear understanding as to what the proportional break-up was. I said, `If you force me down from 15 per cent, don't expect that the other proportions are not going to be affected'.

To members opposite who come into this place and say that I have made this unilateral decision without thinking it through, I simply say this: give me 12 per cent instead of 15 per cent and the other components will suffer. I must say that I took the conscious decision not to reduce the R& commitment because I think that is important. I also took the view that 2.5 per cent was livable with this year because of the significant reserves that the honourable member for Parkes acknowledges the Corporation has.

One might ask-and I guess that if the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) were in this place he would do the asking-why the Corporation has reserves and why has it not been spending them on promotion. However, the fact is that it has the reserves. I spoke to Mac Drysdale and told him of my decision before it was formally announced, and he accepts-honourable members should read his press releases and his speech to the Dubbo conference-that it will not affect promotion this year. He accepts, as I do, that if we do not do something else on promotion in the future, the question of promotion may suffer. I am fully conscious of that. It is my intention to ensure that promotion does not suffer because I think it is a critical component of the new structure in the industry's functions. I will be doing what I can to ensure it is funded, but the industry will have to understand that I will not do it at the expense of continuing to run up the debt through the realisation operations.

It is important to understand that the promotion component being reduced from 3.5 per cent to 2.5 per cent does not mean promotion will suffer. I draw that to the attention in particular of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who has joined us, because he argued earlier that the Government was cutting back on promotion. The Government is not, but I understand the circumstances of the 2.5 per cent. Provided we get through this year properly and the Realisation Commission is meeting the schedule, we will have another look at the promotion. I give that undertaking now, as I have given it to the industry.

The other point raised by the Deputy Leader of the National Party in particular relates to the role of ABARE in this whole exercise. The honourable member for Maranoa-I have alluded to this already-was also critical of ABARE's role. I reject that completely; I think there ought to be a bit more preparedness among honourable members on the other side of the House to be honest. They should sit down with ABARE and go through the figures. ABARE is not just a reputable organisation; it is a great forecasting organisation and has great economic expertise which members opposite ought to use. I do not mind members of the Opposition using ABARE, but they must understand what I said before: there is a commercial-in-confidence aspect to this and the last thing the Government would want to do is take members of the Opposition through confidential details and have them, in their mad grab to get a press statement, release something stupid in the press that sends the price down. (Extension of time granted) I thank the House and I will try not to take up too much more time, but I would like to deal with a couple of the issues that were raised.

I reject the criticism made of ABARE. As I said, I took members of the Opposition through the projections and forecasts that ABARE put up, and I ask them to reflect on this point again: there is no sense in them going around the country telling their constituency that the tax is a cost to farmers without recognising the intrinsic importance of ensuring within the tax a mechanism for getting the debt down.

There has been talk of where the market indicators and things are, and we have talked about price. But it has been suggested that the price is now much stronger than was previously forecast by ABARE. The fact is that when the new market indicator opened with the new selling season, it started at 597c, which is 570c on the old indicator. That was four weeks ago. It is now 529c on the new indicator or 505c on the old indicator. That is a loss of 68c or 12.5 per cent in four weeks, and today sales have been generally softer.

Many reasons have been mentioned in this debate for that, but sales are softer and that cannot be ignored. The old indicator of 475c, which is what ABARE based its predictions on, is 497c, so in essence we are talking about ABARE's forecast as a year average figure. We now have the actual indicator of what members opposite consider to be the good end of the market, because they told the Government when we last debated this in the Parliament that we were 600c and over 600c. It is actually 32c or 6 per cent above where ABARE was. I think the member for Maranoa, if he were in this place, ought to be a little apologetic for his criticism about ABARE because it was actually not too far off the mark. ABARE's point always in this issue was that there is not much point putting more wool on the market, which the Realisation Commission would be forced to do if it were not given enough out of the tax to reduce the debt. Put more wool on the market, and the price is reduced.

In the end what matters to growers is not just the question of tax as a cost but the ultimate return to them, which is reflected by the price. The more wool we put on the market-there is no economic trickery in this; it is supply and demand, a free and open market-the more the price will come down. ABARE was trying to create the forecasting model that demonstrated that, if too much were taken away from the Realisation Commission and it was forced to sell more wool, the price would be decreased and growers would be further away. I guess we can debate this for days.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not debating. Can you clarify the Realisation Commission's figure of $67m?

—Yes, I will come to that in a moment. However the AWRC has sold $67m worth of wool-that is my information-which puts it ahead of schedule for the moment in terms of its sales. These figures are important because at the current estimates of the tax from wool-this is assuming we have still the price currently around in the market-what they will get is the $250m, which I think is what the honourable member for Parkes said. We have that plus the $22.5m which the Government advanced, plus the $67m and the $19m which I understand has come from property income. That is a total of $358.5m against costs at the best current estimate of $340m. That does not yet allow for the $20m. I corrected the honourable member for Maranoa for this by way of interjection and he conceded it. I accept it is heading in that direction, but the reality is that it is not there yet. I think it is important to underscore that point.

SPEECH.PARA: The right honourable member for New England made a number of comments in his contribution. He asked why the Government had to bring this legislation through so quickly. He acknowledged that the existing structures terminated by the end of June and he asked why the Government had to do it on the day it did because Parliament did not have to get up on 24 June. The fact is that this damned House rose on 21 June, and it rose late on that Friday because we were still debating this legislation and trying to get it through. For all the concern raised by the National Party in this debate and all the concern its members expressed--

TALK.START.PARA: —They were not here for the vote.

—I will come to that in a minute. For all the concern they expressed in terms of their constituency and how important this tax was, do honourable members know how many members of the National Party were in the Parliament when the vote was taken?
—One, wasn't it?

—Five out of 14. Of those who have spoken in this debate-the right honourable member for New England; the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), who is not here at the moment; the honourable member for Parkes, who is; and the honourable member for Maranoa, who is not here-not one was present for the vote, and yet they come into this place and tell us of their concern.

SPEECH.PARA: Five out of 14 is not a terribly good figure, but when one takes into account that one of those was the teller for the National Party and another was the person who had the carriage of this Bill on behalf of the National Party-the Deputy Leader-there are three. That is the concern of those opposite. I think it is a disgrace. The right honourable member for New England cannot tell me about the rushed legislation, how important it was and how much more time could have been spent on it-he was not here even to go through the detail. He should not come in here with his cant and hypocrisy and give us his concern for the industry.

The other point that the honourable member for Maranoa made was to have a go at members on this side of the House for going to Europe and arguing the Uruguay Round. He told us that he and others, including Sir John McEwen-much better people than us, he told us-went, and they did not succeed. I will tell the honourable member why they did not succeed. It was because they had a hopeless case. They went over there saying that they wanted increased access, but they tried to defend a domestic market that was so protected that the rest of the world took us as a joke.

That is the hypocrisy that comes from members of the National Party and, in particular, one of its former leaders. They try to pretend that they have done the right thing in this place in representing Australia's interests, but they went with a hopeless case. Then they get up and say, `Don't come along, new Minister, and tell us about value adding; we've said that for ages'. They might have said it, but they have done nothing. The reason they have been able to do nothing is because they have never encouraged an efficient manufacturing base in this country and that is a necessity for value adding. They have efficiency, as have we, because we have deregulated the industry in agriculture. We have the efficiency--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the labour market.

—I will come to the labour market. The reality is that, under the new arrangements that the trade unions have entered into, any greenfield operation which has new value adding potential can get any flexibility it wants-anything that it wants-but National Party members are not prepared to try it. They want to reject it as being part of some inflexible operation to which no flexibility applies. It is rubbish. They do not understand the issues and they are not even prepared to try to find out about them.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry that the honourable member for Maranoa is not here as he asked me to chase up the question of the multifibre agreement. I tend to agree with him that we need to make sure that that agreement is broken down. That is the point that I have been trying to make-the GATT Round cannot just be about better access in agriculture. Agriculture is a key, but if we are going to pursue value adding in this economy, if we are going to get more of a manufacturing base, then we need access to manufactured opportunities, not just commodities.

So I agree with the honourable member for Maranoa. We are not signatories and not party to the negotiations in that agreement, but obviously the success we have in the Uruguay Round will have implications. Therefore, I believe that the efforts that this Government has been making-which, I must say, have bipartisan support from the Parliament-are crucial. They are crucial not just to agriculture, but also to the future of the agricultural base which provides the wealth generation for this economy, not by continuing to trade in commodities but by actually doing a bit more with it. Those opposite never had the strategy for that. They have never understood the importance of linking agriculture with manufacturing. We have. We will do it and we will succeed. It will be better for farmers, it will be better for the nation and it will encourage regional development.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Crean) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 6 June, on motion by Mr Griffiths:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to contribute to this important debate on an important statement from the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) on our defence policy into the twenty-first century. The Defence Force structure review, which was announced earlier this year and which is embodied within the statement issued by the Minister, provides a very necessary and timely focus on Australia's defence needs in the next decade and beyond.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be seen in the context of a dramatically changing international arena with all the implications that holds for foreign affairs and for defence. It should also be seen in the context of domestic pressures to ensure value for money and increased productivity from all sectors of our economy. Economic constraints are as real in defence matters as they are everywhere else. As the Minister's statement noted, the central challenge before us is to organise our defence better so that we can obtain the maximum combat capability in the most efficient and affordable way.

The force structure review contains a number of welcome initiatives which will enhance our defence capabilities. The expansion of commercial and civilian workers undertaking support and maintenance work has the potential to be cost effective and will release defence personnel and resources for more important combat related duties. It is important in the implementation of that program that each case be assessed on its merits. There are clearly areas of activity within the defence forces-particularly in support and maintenance work-which could quite easily be handed over to non-defence personnel on a private, civilian contracted or employee basis. There are, though, a number of areas of maintenance and questions of supply which defence will need to look at closely in making these decisions to ensure that at no time is Australia's combat capacity diminished on those occasions when it is most needed.

In addition, the statement includes increased emphasis on basing forces in northern Australia. This decision recognises the realities of Australia's strategic interests. I think it also recognises and picks up on many of the lessons that have been learned through exercises such as K89. Decisions such as the relocation of the second cavalry regiment to Darwin, I am sure, have occurred at least in part from the lessons that have been learned from K89 and, given the huge geography of our nation, to deploy a larger portion of our defence forces in the north makes good sense.

Continued development and expansion of the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar system is an initiative which I support. As a member of the defence subcommittee of the joint Houses of the Parliament, I have had the opportunity of visiting that installation and seeing the operations first hand. There is no doubt that Australia's efforts in this field are at the cutting edge of world technology. We are, probably with only one or two other nations in the world, able to produce over-the-horizon radar systems that are combat effective. The work that has been done by those involved deserves praise and clearly has a number of beneficial outcomes for the nation.

The decision of the Government to construct six Collins class submarines to be based primarily in Western Australia with two deployed on the east coast will provide Australia with a capability at sea which is unmatched in our region. It will also assist the development of our two-oceans policy which, again, recognises not only the size of our country but also the fact that we are an island continent and need to recognise the importance of maintaining a naval presence in both the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean. Those six Collins class submarines will enhance our naval capacity quite significantly.

All of these changes improve our defence ability in what I believe is a cost effective manner. The most significant changes, though, with immediate or short term effect relate to the Regular Army-particularly the changes which will impact upon 6th Brigade, which is based at Enoggera army barracks within my electorate of Brisbane. The 6th Brigade is currently an integrated regular reserve unit. Its combat units consist of the 6th and the 8/9 battalions of the Royal Australian Regiment and the 49th Battalion Royal Queensland Regiment, which is a reserve battalion. This brigade is to become the new ready reserve brigade of the Army. A good deal of the public debate and comment on the Defence Force structure review relates to ready reserves, and I wish to take some time to talk about that, not only because it affects my electorate directly, but also because it is of some significance to the defence of our nation.

Over the next four years all battalions within the 6th Brigade will be rearranged to become ready reserve units. The ready reserve concept is a worthwhile one which, if successful, will give us a comparatively well trained, full strength regiment consisting of 3,200 ready reserves and 800 regulars. It is pleasing to see that the restructured 6th Brigade will be at full strength. It is a fact that the brigade is not now at full strength and has not been for some time. That is a pity. It is a reality, though, in the context of the tight economic situation we face.

I have some concerns about the introduction of the ready reserve and I shall mention some of those in this debate. At the outset, I have some concern that next year we will find ourselves with 1,000 recruits keen to join the ready reserve and enlist for one year's full time training. All the surveys that have been done indicate that that is not going to be a problem, and very soon we will find out whether that is the case. I sincerely hope that there are more than enough recruits to implement the first-year operations of the ready reserve.

I also harbour some concerns about the effectiveness of training in subsequent years. The two-week block of training for ready reserves in their second and subsequent years will afford Army an opportunity to undertake worthwhile training in locations throughout Australia that are suitable for the purpose. However, the remainder of the training period in subsequent years will be of short duration. It has to be recognised that there are limitations and problems associated with training the ready reserve on two-or three-day blocks, which will be the case, I understand, for approximately half of their training in subsequent years. That matter is being addressed by the Army, and I think it will need some careful scrutiny by the Government.

I also have some reservations about the logistic matters associated with the change of 6th Brigade to a ready reserve. The simple question of where these people are going to be housed needs to be confronted, and I understand that matter is being looked at now. However, I believe that there is not space for 1,000 people at Enoggera from the start of next year, and the Government will clearly need to look at the changes that have to be made and the possible cost implications in ensuring that there is adequate housing for those involved.

My major concern in this area is the reduction of two regular battalions. The 6th Brigade has successfully integrated reserves and regulars into a very effective combat force. It seems possible and desirable to maintain one regular battalion as part of an integrated regular ready reserve brigade. After all, the ready reserve will have the benefit of one year's full time training, not required of current reserves.

I readily acknowledge the cost factor involved in changing a ready reserve battalion to a regular battalion. New equipment has to be paid for, and that is a significant cost which Defence is having to meet. I have referred already to some of the major cost items, particularly in the Navy. There are also some acquisitions in the Army, in particular the purchase of the wheeled armoured fighting vehicle, which will greatly improve mobility. I understand that one of the early trials of that will be with 6th Brigade, and I welcome that. The acquisition of night vision equipment on a large scale is to be commended. One of the lessons that came out of the Middle East Gulf dispute earlier this year was the advanced night vision capability of the United Nations alliance forces. There is no doubt that the large scale distribution of modern night vision equipment will be of great assistance to our infantry battalions.

The reintroduction into service of between four and six Chinooks is welcome. I have made speeches on that point in the past, and I am pleased to see that the Government is continuing to look at ways in which those Chinooks can be reintroduced into service.

However, in the end it is not the equipment but the people who make the difference: how well trained they are and, in defence, how many of them there are. The Government needs to monitor closely the introduction of the ready reserve and to adjust its implementation in the light of developments. There is some irony in the replacement of the two regular battalions in the 6th Brigade. This year 6 Battalion of the 6th Brigade has been recognised for having some of the most outstanding skills and abilities in the Army. It has recently won the overall Duke of Gloucester award, the night operations award and the award for the most outstanding section commander. This is the first time that all three awards have been won by the same battalion. Given the resources and opportunity, it would clearly be desirable to keep this successful combination together. The Minister is correct, though, when he says:

It is easy to draw up lists of what can be done to improve our defence capacity, if there were no resource limits. More demanding is the task of deciding what we can do less of, or to find better ways of doing things so that we can release resources for new projects and activities.
I acknowledge that problem and the costs involved in the suggestions I have made about the need to maintain some greater regular battalion presence in the 6th Brigade.

With the Defence budget maintained in real terms and with strong pressures on other parts of the Budget, I concede the difficulties facing the Government in this matter. However, defence of our nation and its citizens is one of our fundamental responsibilities as an Australian Parliament. New technology is making defence procurement more expensive. I believe we are fast approaching the point where our total expenditure on defence as a nation will need to be revised.

I suspect that my sentiments in seeking some additional funding in this area will be echoed by those opposite. I ask them in their contributions to consider the question of the total Budget outlays and to reconcile what I anticipate will be their call for increased defence expenditure with their often stated view that total government outlays should be reduced. Later in this session we will no doubt hear from prominent members of the Opposition in response to the Budget, when they will be calling for cuts in government expenditure. Last year they proposed a $3 billion cut in Budget expenditure. I put it to those opposite that, when they argue for increased defence expenditure, they might at the same time inform the House how they will reconcile that with their requirement to cut total government outlays. They might enlighten the House as to the specific areas they wish to cut in order to fund not only the overall outlays reduction but the increase in defence expenditure.

I commend the Government and the Minister for their efforts to rationalise the Australian defence forces, their training and support facilities. The savings made in this process can be applied to other areas of greater need. Similarly, I think it is time for us to look beyond our own shores at the opportunity to rationalise our defence in association with other countries, particularly New Zealand, where there is scope for us to look at rationalising our total defence operations in some association with the New Zealand Government.

Finally, I commend the Minister and the Government for acknowledging in this statement the need to strengthen international arms control measures. There are many lessons we hope to learn from the Gulf war; foremost amongst those must be that arms sales and worldwide arms production must not be allowed to continue. I am pleased that the Government has acknowledged that in this speech. The future in defence, as elsewhere, will be about efficiency and effectiveness. I believe this statement is a positive move in both directions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —While it is true that it is extraordinarily difficult to look into the future, it is of concern to me that as we talk on this defence paper introduced on 30 May, today being 21 August, the fundamental circumstances affecting Australia's and the world's security have changed fundamentally. In the course of my remarks I want to pick up some of the aspects mentioned by the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), but it is essential that we understand a few of the crises that have beset us and still beset us today.

SPEECH.PARA: Sadly, the turbulent events in the Soviet Union are there for all to see and to fear. They have two real outcomes. The first is, obviously, the extent to which there is likely to be an armed conflict and loss of life, with all the very serious repercussions that flow, within the Soviet Union; but the second-equally profound for the world-is the extent to which the strategic arms limitation talks and the other disarmament achievements between President Gorbachev and President Bush could founder on the change towards a hard line communist dictatorship within the Soviet.

I say that at the beginning when looking at a statement which I think reflects the progressive deterioration of the Australian defence capacity under the Labor Government. Under successive Ministers-the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) and now Senator Ray-Australia's actual defence capability has been boosted on the premise of self-sufficiency, while it founders on the reality that we are more dependent today on the support of other forces than we have ever been. I intend to pick that up in relation to the Gulf war.

The Minister for Defence (Senator Ray) and the Minister assisting him in this place, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney), said that on 30 May it was premature to reach too many conclusions about the outcome of the Gulf war. But a few conclusions are now apparent. I want to look at those, look at the Australian Defence Force, look at our procurement program and see where we go from here.

Out of the Gulf war there are a few prime lessons. First, allied intelligence was superb. There is no doubt that the movements, the numbers and the extent to which there were changes to the structure within the Iraqi forces were known with absolute precision. The second lesson concerns the absolutely vital matter of air supremacy. If it had not been for the air supremacy of the allied forces, there is little doubt that the extent to which they would have been able to move the large mass of arms across to the western front so that they could come around in the main drive on Iraq would have been almost impossible. Certainly, that supremacy of air power enabled the allied forces to operate in an entirely different environment. That was one of the prime reasons for the capacity for the war to have been won so rapidly.

The third area is the amazing development in technologically sophisticated equipment. Some of it is in a field that is almost mind boggling. The honourable member for Brisbane talked about night vision equipment.
