When we look at the Stealth aircraft and some of the hand held weapons and equipment that were operated by the soldiers in the field, the extent to which technology gave the allied forces unprecedented supremacy is absolutely amazing.

The fourth field, which is equally critical, is logistic support. It was absolutely incredible to move, stage, maintain and train so many in such a harsh and difficult environment and to sustain them for such a protracted period of time. Of course, it was equally amazing that the coalition was politically able to stay together.

I put on record all of those matters, because if we look at those in relation to the Australian Defence Force and say `Where do we go?', we realise how vulnerable we are. If we are going to measure Australia's contribution, it is also important to ask-let us be honest about it-what we sent. Effectively, we sent two frigates. We might have been able to extend that to four frigates. What would have happened if we had lost four frigates? What would have been the impact on the Australian Defence Force? We need to understand that those two frigates-there were several sets of two frigates-were unable to operate independently. The FFGs are not designed to operate independently out-of-station on their own any more than the DDGs-although the DDGs are much more capable ships.

If we look at air superiority, we see the appalling result of this defence statement and the Budget. Although the honourable member for Brisbane properly said there is zero growth this year-in fact, the Government has maintained real spending on defence-we have been told that there will be an actual reduction in expenditure of nearly $84m next year and $177m the following year.

In respect of the Air Force, we are getting to the position where we are not giving enough flying hours to our pilots, particularly with the FA18s and certainly with the F111s. We have to be able to maintain not just the supremacy of those who are flying sophisticated aircraft but also their technical skills, their proficiency and their capability. I find this statement from the Minister laughable. I have a brother-in-law who is a former wing commander and is consequently very skilled in flying F111s. To bring back people who have been out of practice in flying these aircraft and expect them to become proficient air crew or, as the Minister says in his statement, to provide a surge capability, is not realistic, no matter how skilled or proficient they may be. People who are going to fly those modern war machines need a standard of training that is greater than what is now being provided. We are not providing the flying hours or the capacity even to maintain the equipment we have at the moment.

As the honourable member for Brisbane said, it is true that we are looking towards a new wheeled armoured fighting unit and to some more night vision equipment for the Army. They are great measures, but let us be realistic. This Government cancelled the Whaler program. The Whaler program was designed to replace the M113 armoured personnel carriers because it was recognised 10 years ago that we had to do something to get something suitable for Australian conditions. We spent quite considerable sums of money developing an Australian armoured vehicle, and what did the Government do? It replaced it. Now the Government is going to buy something from overseas. Night vision equipment is essential, and it is very important that we acquire it. At the moment we have not enough. Were we required to fight anywhere in our region at the moment, we would find it extraordinarily difficult unless we depended upon somebody else to provide the supplies.

Australia has not the logistic capacity even to sustain an operation in Fiji if we needed to. I query whether we would be able to do anything in Papua New Guinea, with all the difficulties there. When we look at the climate around us and all the instability to which the Minister refers and of which we are all conscious in the South Pacific and our region, we would be foolish to think we had the logistic capacity to sustain a major commitment. If we look at what we might have done had we borne the same proportional commitment as the United States and Britain in the Gulf war, we see that we would not have been able to do it. We would have had to send about 2,000 armed personnel to the Gulf, we would not have been able to sustain them and we would have had virtually no defence forces left here. Nothing in this defence statement changes that.

I want to identify the fact that the defence procurement program has not been advanced by this defence statement. The lessons of the Gulf war say that we are more vulnerable and more dependent on our allies than we have ever been. We have to start working out what sort of a role we will play. I am one of those who say that we have a responsibility to maintain Western stability. In my view, we are far better preserving across the world the sort of peace that we believe can be obtained by working with the Western alliance. To do that, we have committed forces successively in Namibia; we still have a police unit in Cyprus; we have committed defence forces to the Sinai; and we have committed personnel to the United Nations unit in the Gulf: Australians to defend our international interests. But let us be realistic: those measures are as described within the general concepts of those who plan our defence spending; they are not the prime purpose of our Defence Force. Indeed, the whole purport of the Dibb report was to withdraw Australia's defence concepts back into Australia.

The 1987 White Paper, which has been endorsed as the strategic base of the statement made by the Minister, essentially says that there should be some capacity in our region. It does not talk other than incidentally about peacekeeping forces. Nothing in the 1987 White Paper removes us from the prime task set down in the 1976 White Paper, which looked at the overall capacity to which we want to develop defence self-sufficiency while working within an international context.

I believe that this statement leaves us very vulnerable in defence procurement. I am most concerned at the equipment that has been ordered. We have heard talk about the Collins class submarines. I still believe that we could have saved significant sums of money if we had had a refit of the Oberons and looked, as I believe we still should, at a nuclear powered submarine.

We are designing a U-boat of 1950s generation. It has a bit of flash equipment, but essentially it is still a modern U-boat. The U-boat was by far the most sophisticated submarine of World War II; and the Collins class, for all the significant improvements on the safety and other operational capabilities of those vessels, is still powered by an oldstyle unit which requires it to come to the surface to charge its batteries. The Minister says that the submarines will be stationed on the west coast. Our concern is that, if we want to send them somewhere, we cannot get them where we want them when we need to.

One of the lessons of the Falklands campaign was that the British, with their nuclear submarines, posed a threat which kept the Argentinean Navy at home. We want to be able to deter aggression. We will not be able to do it with something that can be observed. Realistically, with our capacity, we will not have the air supremacy to which I have referred as being a vital factor in the Gulf.

Looking at the Air Force, I am concerned that, as the Minister suggests, we will not be able to maintain the PC3s. I hope we can. He talks about replacing the F111s. I do not know with what. I only hope that he proceeds with an avionics upgrade. He needs to understand, with both the F18s and the F111s, that we have to provide more hours for the training and maintenance of those personnel and their pilot skills, or we will be in great trouble.

The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) represents HMAS Albatross at Nowra. That is a typical example. We sold A4 aircraft to New Zealand, and now we have virtually taken them back into the Royal Australian Navy. We have not even been able to work out our acquisition program. The Navy is extraordinarily vulnerable because it has no intrinsic air defence. It would need to depend on the RAAF to maintain defence if it was needed.

I set this very briefly in the context that the procurement decisions have been wrong and that we do not know where we are going. The honourable member for Brisbane asked where we are going to get the money. I understand that it has already been decided that instead of having three over-the-horizon projects there will be two. I would cut the second and develop the original Jindalee over-the-horizon radar project. That would give us some funds with which we could start to look at our AWACS needs. The 707s need to be paid off shortly. We must have an AWACS capability, and I think that perhaps we have to start looking at a 727 or a new generation Boeing, both for refuelling and to develop the airborne early warning command and control system.

Before I close, I think I should say something about the Army's Ready Reserve. Unfortunately, I believe that the Ready Reserve will take resources from the Regular Army and that it will not provide the additional resources that we need to train our real reserves adequately. We have to look at the resources and to provide our regular and reserve forces with adequate training hours and adequate equipment. The Ready Reserve will be made to work, simply because that is what our service men and women are all about-they make things work. But it will not get additional resources; our Budget shows that. If it does not get additional resources, its personnel will come off the existing regulars and that will be to the detriment of Australia's defence capability.

The accommodation problems to which the honourable member for Brisbane referred are real. We have to look at what we have, make it better, train our personnel adequately and properly, house them properly and give them sufficient resources to undertake their tasks. Frankly, nothing in this defence statement gives me any confidence that the Government has looked at our strategic situation and designed its expenditure and its program to meet the real requirement of defending Australia in the 1990s and into the year 2000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that tonight I have the opportunity to speak on the defence of our country. The timing of this debate allows me briefly to pay tribute to the late Brigadier Tony Hammett. He was perhaps the most respected soldier ever posted to Singleton army base, in the electorate of Hunter, New South Wales. So highly regarded was the then Colonel Hammett that during his period as Commandant of Singleton Army base, the Shire President, Neil McNamara, and the Singleton Council conferred on him the highest honour that a community can bestow.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently Tony Hammett was tragically killed in a light plane crash. Mrs Hammett decided that her late husband's ashes should be held in the area that was dearest to him during his military career. So on Tuesday, 3 September, an important ceremony will take place in Singleton when Brigadier Hammett's ashes will be laid to rest. I know that Colonel Peter Cosgrove and the personnel at Singleton army base, the local RSL President-Bill Ruggatt, who served under Tony-all the RSL members and the citizens of Singleton will pay Tony Hammett the tribute that he so well deserves. Unfortunately, Parliament will be sitting that day and I cannot be in Singleton. However, I want to say my own farewell to Brigadier Tony Hammett, who was a brilliant soldier and a champion bloke. I join with others in extending my sympathies to Mrs Hammett and the Hammett family.

The defence statement being debated tonight is a far-reaching and, some may consider, radical statement. But it is a good statement which will take our defence forces well into the next century. The Dibb report highlighted the need for Australia's self-reliance and the Government has been moving steadily in this direction. Three key principles are adopted by the force structure review which examined the current Defence Force structure and recommended adjustments to the year 2000. I have too short a time to go into detail about the three principles, but the changes outlined in the statement on defence are progressive and allow this country to maintain a peak defence ready force, ably served by members of the regular Australian Defence Force and strengthened by members of our reserve forces.

I had a discussion with a senior officer from the Singleton army base who has been involved with reservists. He made the point that generally, in his experience, reservists are the best type of people. They are usually public minded and more dedicated. They not only hold down their own job and do it well, but are always on promotion courses in the reserves. They make excellent soldiers and the only problem is that the reserve forces cannot get enough of them. It is to be hoped that many regular Defence Force personnel will join the new reserve forces and thus continue their military careers.

I am not denigrating the men and women of our regular Australian Defence Force in any way because they, too, are splendid, dedicated people and are the backbone of our nation. They have proved themselves time and time again over many years. Of course, the latest conflict in which they proved themselves was the Gulf war.

The permanent Australian Defence Force is to be reduced by some 10,500 personnel over the next 10 years. The bulk of the reduction in personnel will result from natural attrition with only some minor voluntary retirements. It is hard to argue with the stated aim of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to get more punch for the Defence dollar. Certainly, the Defence vote should not be immune from scrutiny and I am sure the Australian taxpayers will agree with that statement. Defence is a big spending item on the Budget, representing some 9.6 per cent of total government outlay. Like all areas of government activity, the Services have to take their share of cost cutting.

There can be little argument with the plans to allow private enterprise to take over support functions such as catering, tailoring, communications, transport and medical services. Savings from that exercise will be put to more effective use on the combat side.

There should not be any dispute about the idea of a well-trained reserve force to back up regulars in the three services. Singleton army base certainly will not lose from the changes in the defence area, with $130m or perhaps even more to be spent on the Singleton army base and Myambat supply depot. Although I doubt that the defence statement will have much impact on either the Singleton army base or the Williamtown RAAF base, it is possible that Singleton and Raymond Terrace in Newcastle could benefit by the release of very well-trained people in highly sophisticated areas.

That could also have a beneficial effect on towns in the Hunter region because more civilians could be employed. Soldiers doing work that could be done by civilians will be allocated other duties. Savings will be generated by commercialising some activities such as catering, communications, stores and transport, clerical work, non-military training, repairs and maintenance, health care and firefighting functions. Other people can do these jobs very well. Our soldiers would then be allowed the freedom and the time to develop expertise in the combat side of things.

Savings made will be beneficial in two ways. First, they will allow Australia to buy the state-of-the-art technology to maintain our defence-ready capability and, secondly, by commercialising some activities benefits will be derived in the private sector. With regard to the reserves, there will be better pay and conditions for them, but I am a bit concerned about the married reservists. I assume that they will be entitled to the same conditions as members of the regular defence forces. For instance, a married person is not entitled to removal expenses for his family unless the posting is for in excess of 12 months. This situation could arise when reservists might be transferred to Western Australia or northern Australia. Incidentally, there can be no argument at all that we should expand our defence operations in the vast stretches of Western Australia and northern Australia. We are the largest island in the world and our coastline stretches over many thousands of kilometres.

I have always believed it was ludicrous to continue basing major defence operations in the southern areas of Australia. Sure, we do need to have these areas suitably protected too, but any threat to Australia is likely to come from our vast, largely unprotected, western and northern coastlines. Bases in the southern areas of Australia belong to the early days of our history, and certainly have little bearing on our defence needs today and in the future. I believe most Australians see the logic in the reason for this move to protect our most unprotected areas.

While I support the thrust of the defence statement, I do have a few concerns. One of those concerns is about the use of reservists with regard to employers. Some employers do allow their employees leave, particularly government departments and the larger businesses, but other employers, particularly those in small business, cannot afford to lose their employees for long training periods. With the training guarantee scheme in operation, it is possible that some employers will be reluctant to allow employees additional time to participate in the reserve forces.

I am also concerned about what will happen when the new reserve scheme commences next year. It is expected that young people would undertake 12 months training. Where would we find these young people who can get leave from their employers? Certainly, the new scheme will provide employment opportunities for many of our young people who are unable the find jobs.

I can also foresee logistical problems in getting people from all over Australia into one area for training. The timing of that training could also present problems. For instance, the time selected for training may be unsuitable for farmers or may not fit in with the end of semesters for university students and so on. I suppose the Army has been dealing with this sort of thing for many years and has answers to all these concerns.

The Singleton army base, including the Myambat Supply Depot, and the Williamtown RAAF base are very proud of the way they are accepted into and form part of the community. They are an integral part of our Hunter Valley and I hope that this will remain the case for many years to come. Both bases have taken a positive attitude about the defence statement. Their personnel have said to me, `We'll get on with the job and we'll be able to cope with the changes'.

At the time of the Newcastle earthquake in 1989, personnel from Williamtown RAAf base were in the area within 30 minutes to assist with relief work. Their work was so good that they were requested by the SES to stay on and provide further assistance. Williamtown is a great asset to the Hunter. The annual wages bill is about $68m. Major projects have been completed there. Millions of dollars are put into the Hunter Valley economy. All the money is being spent locally.

Another interesting point is that the base is a tremendous user of some of the services provided in the Hunter: for example, the Shire of Gloucester is a fairly large area but at peak periods the RAAF base at Williamtown uses more electric power than the whole of the Gloucester Shire.

So Singleton army base and Williamtown RAAF base are of great benefit to the Hunter Valley. Both bases view the Hunter Valley as being a pro-military area-a pro-RAAF area too, I guess-a delightful place to work in, and they consider themselves part of the Hunter community. It is not just the Singleton army base that is highly regarded by the community; Williamtown RAAF base is equally regarded.

It is interesting to note that there is a fort on the foreshores of Newcastle named after one of the founders of the concept of the Army reserves, Colonel Peter Scratchley, who in 1877 arrived from England and advised that the only need by Australia for defence was a system of armoured forts. He recommended that the forts be backed up by a small but well trained force of full time soldiers, and that the bulk of the troops should be part time paid volunteers; in other words, an Army Reserve.

We will have a darned good Army Reserve in this country. There are reserve units of artillery, infantry, engineers and support units based at Waratah, Hamilton and Adamstown within the Hunter Valley and there are other companies throughout the Hunter region. They are jolly capable personnel. It has been claimed that the Army Reserve may become the poor relation of the new Defence Service. But I reject that claim outright.

When defence personnel leave the Australian Defence Force, they take with them a range of skills and, with attractive pay and service conditions offered to reservists, it should be possible to attract these people to the reserve forces and thereby retain these valuable skills. The defence statement is very comprehensive and covers a whole range of issues such as combatant surface vessels, aircraft needs, et cetera.

Having said that the statement clearly sets out Australia's position on defence exports, I believe that this defence statement is a positive document which, when implemented, not only will allow Australia to maximise its capacity to draw on national resources but also will take our country forward into the next century.
I wish to offer my congratulations to both the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Defence, Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) for the report they have brought down. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly will not be offering my congratulations at all to the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) in respect of this statement.
—That's a surprise.
—It is not a surprise to me.
—It's only commonsense and to be expected.

—It is commonsense. The RSL recently celebrated its seventy-fifth anniversary and, in the context of this debate on the paper entitled Defence into the 21st Century, we might reflect on the motto of the RSL. I remind honourable members that that motto is, `The price of liberty is eternal vigilance'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget yesterday confirmed in my view for all time that Labor has lost its resolve on defence. I believe that the Budget showed conclusively that Labor is not genuinely interested in reforming defence or in developing a genuinely self-reliant defence policy. Although this Government will be thrown out at the next election because of its economic ineptitude, it may well be that its complacency on defence will be the Government's most damaging legacy to the Australian people.

Australians have paid a high price for liberty in the past. Last Sunday the twenty-fifth anniversary of the battle of Long Tan in South Vietnam was remembered. Eighteen young Australians gave their lives there and for them, of course, it was the ultimate price. It is not that Long Tan was a Gallipoli or a Tobruk, but it was the first major engagement between an Australian force and its enemy in South Vietnam, and it was a battle in which Australians performed in the best traditions of Anzac. In that battle 245 enemy were killed. Ultimately 500 young Australians gave their lives in South Vietnam.

The price of liberty then is high. On hearing what has been said by Government members tonight in this debate, I wonder whether the price for the Government is too high. I want to say on behalf of my children here tonight, and on behalf of the children of others, that no price is too high to pay. We cannot take risks with defence. Yet this is exactly what this Government is asking us to do. It is asking us to take unacceptable risks with the defence of this country. But what does it care? The Budget even cut the allocation to the Australian War Memorial. What strange priorities this Government has. Australian veterans will judge this Government on the way it commemorates their fallen comrades, and I believe it will be a harsh judgment indeed.

However, I am pleased to say in this debate on defence that the Speaker and his colleague the President of the Senate have agreed to my suggestion that we have an Anzac commemoration here in Parliament House next year. I intend to take Mr Speaker up on his offer for me to proceed to organise this. I note that he has offered his assistance.

The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in his response to the ministerial statement pointed to the many respects in which the Government strategy for defence into the twenty-first century is flawed. I want to take it further and expose some of those flaws in my contribution to the debate this evening. I want to make the Australian people aware of the path which this Government is taking us down, a path which will put this country's future at considerable risk. As I said, it is an unacceptable risk for I do not believe we can take risks with defence. All of the lessons of military history underline this fact.

If we put this debate into its historical context, we will recognise that Australia has never been properly or adequately prepared for war. Indeed, we have been fortunate that, except for some fairly minor but significant incursions, we have never had to fight a full-scale war on our own ground. But when war came in 1939 Australia was not prepared. Nor was it prepared in 1914.

Our defence policy in 1939 was not adequate for the situation. The RAAF was ill-equipped and the Army lacked modern equipment; in fact at the time, interestingly enough, as we reflect in this debate, we had two armies-the existing militia and the soon to be formed and recruited Second AIF.

Between 1920 and 1935 little or nothing much was done in respect of defence. These were years of neglect, and in a sense we look back at those years of neglect and we see a direct parallel with what has happened in this country in recent times. Of course, the hurried re-armament that occurred after 1937 when the signs became ominous was too late. Governments at the time did not believe there would be a Second World War, and when war actually came to Australia's shores in 1942 we were not capable of defending ourselves; we were clearly totally incapable of defending ourselves.

The two-army policy that existed at the time also caused great difficulties. As I listened to the ministerial statement on 30 May, I could not help wondering whether history was repeating itself, except that now we have before us a proposal not for two armies, but for three armies. The Opposition believes that this proposal will seriously affect our combat capability. We have the Regular Army, the Reserve-already poorly equipped and lacking adequate training facilities, despite what the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) suggested it would have-and we will have an all new Ready Reserve.

I do not believe that can work effectively. The addition of a third tier may well be quite counterproductive and increase the size of the already too large defence bureaucracy. I believe that what the Government proposes now is the worst of all worlds. It proposes to reduce the regular component of the Army to the absolute bare minimum. It will leave us with only four regular battalions. With only four regular battalions, the Regular Army will be close to useless; in fact, it will be unable to maintain a protracted deployment.

The Government's solution in recognition of this is the creation of a Ready Reserve. I say to the Government that that just will not work. What it will do is knock the guts out of the existing Reserve, which may sound the death knell of the Reserve. Reservists have been struggling for years. They have been poorly equipped and there has been very little incentive for them to remain. Now that they will be relegated to third grade, they might as well pack up and go home-and they probably will.

When the Ready Reserve fails, what will we have? We will have a weakened regular force and a decimated Reserve. I believe that is a recipe for disaster. I have no doubt that the whole idea of a Ready Reserve is a pig in a poke. It has been tried in one or two countries. It failed in Canada. Of greater concern to all Australians is the fact that it is extremely risky and it puts at risk the future defence of Australia and, to that extent, it is a completely unacceptable risk.

There will be little incentive for people to join the Ready Reserve. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) suggested that ex-regulars might join. They will not be interested or motivated. Once they have left and have taken up civilian employment, they will not be too interested in going back under any conditions.

The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) earlier tonight made an excellent contribution to this debate. I shall just echo some of the remarks that he made which were based on his very wide experience in this area. When we put the ministerial statement in the context of our most recent military engagement-the Gulf war-we get some interesting insights. Australia participated in that war for national security reasons-although Saddam Hussein did not pose any direct threat to Australia-and joined a United Nations sanctioned coalition. It was a very broad coalition. It was almost a war with the world against Iraq-in some sense it may have been seen as World War III-but Iraq's activities demanded and received decisive action from the international community. It now appears that with the survival of Saddam Hussein, however, the war ended too soon and it may well be that once again peace will be lost.

As the right honourable member for New England said, the Gulf war highlighted then, and continues to highlight, the major deficiencies in Australia's defence preparedness and capabilities. Australia's defence forces were not prepared to react in the Gulf war situation, other than superficially. No matter how much we might like to think we made a great contribution there-that does not in any way diminish the contribution of those who went-we only reacted superficially.

We could not have dispatched ground forces. We could not have risked valuable RAAF assets, and the equipment on our ships-they were ill-equipped at the time-was cannibalised from other ships. Some of it was borrowed from overseas, some was borrowed from the RAAF and some was borrowed from the Army. It was altogether a pretty patched up job. At least it put us there, and that was terrific.

What have we learned from the Gulf war? Clearly, the real problem with Australian defence policy is its persistent failure to respond effectively and in good time to major global strategic shifts. Australia's modern defence policy is based heavily on the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and the subsequent 1987 White Paper. Essentially, it is a policy of alliance plus self-reliance. Unfortunately, the Budget yesterday effectively killed Labor's 1987 defence policy.

The aim was to develop the ADF into an instrument which could support overall security policy and deal with lesser contingencies itself; but the policy has failed. The ADF's independent operational capacity is almost non-existent, and it will be completely non-existent with the planned restructuring. Our war stocks at the moment are very low and we have virtually no independent resupply capacity. This has been exacerbated to some extent by the bleak outlook for Australia's defence export industry.

In this context we find ourselves faced with this magnificent document entitled Defence into the 21st Century. I say to honourable members and to the people of Australia, because I believe it is incumbent on me and I have a responsibility to do so, that this paper, this plan-if I can call it that, using the word loosely-does nothing to engender any confidence at all in the Government's ability to come to grips with Australia's defence needs. The Government has failed in defence. As I said earlier, looking at yesterday's Budget Papers it appears that the Government has completely given up and lost its resolve on defence.

The needs of Australia have changed dramatically in response to the end of the Cold War. We are witnessing rising defence expenditure amongst some of our neighbours. We are witnessing a dramatically changing role in many respects for the United States, where defence expenditure, for one reason or another, is falling, and falling quite dramatically. In real terms, over the next 10 years it will fall substantially. Yet the Government, even in the context of that reality, has continued to give a low priority to defence-a priority that was confirmed in yesterday's Budget.

This is happening at a time when the Government is enthusiastically handing out money all over the place for other things while defence real growth since 1987 has been zero. In other words, we have been going backwards on defence expenditure since 1987. Defence spending over the last few years has been at historically low levels. As I said earlier in my remarks, to put this debate in context we need to consider that Australia has never been adequately prepared for war. I suppose some would say that maybe no-one is ever adequately prepared for war. But the signs are there. There is no reason for complacency in this world today. We must be prepared in the context of world events. Events of the last 24 to 48 hours should impress upon us the urgency of being prepared. Yet we have become extremely complacent, and the Opposition is concerned about this. We feel we must warn the Australian people.

There is now more than ever a need for a major defence review. There should have been in May or earlier this year another White or Green Paper, not just a knee-jerk where-can-we-save-money reaction, which is what we got from the Government. Urgent attention needs to be given to the high and costly personnel wastage rate-- (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Events of recent days certainly demonstrate that the Cold War is alive and well. We have had one Cold War warrior, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), echoing the 1970s defence philosophy and technology. We have a new Cold War warrior, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradfield), using slightly different words, but the message is still the same.

SPEECH.PARA: In looking at defence in the twenty-first century, it is probably best that we go back and look at why we needed the Dibb report and the defence review of 1987. Honourable members may recall that when the right honourable member for New England relinquished his portfolio as the Minister for Defence in early 1983 he did not bother telling the people of Australia how payments on a whole range of equipment had been deferred, particularly on the F18s, because the Budget was going bad. In the 1983-84 Budget, because of the deferred payments left by the outgoing Minister, the defence surplus funds were virtually all expended before this Government could even draw up a Budget.

He did not tell the people that the shells on our Leopard tanks-which are Germany's finest tanks-had to be imported. After all the years we had had them, we had not even negotiated the licence to make the shells in Australia, so to use those tanks in Australia we would have had to get permission to import the shells. He did not tell us that the capacity, suitability and specifications of the Whaler vehicle, which he mentioned earlier and the introduction of which he initiated, that were drawn up were so inadequate that when it finally went through the analysis stage the vast majority of the experts in the defence committees which examined it were unanimous in saying that it was not just a waste of money but also unsuitable for what Australia needed. He did not tell us that the trainer aircraft was in such bad shape and so poorly specified that after some three or four years its design specifications were still not finalised.

The Cold War warriors made all the noises about tanks rumbling through Red Square, giving a great show of strength and letting the world see what wonderful equipment we have. It did not matter to them if there were no bullets for them, if we had not paid for them or if they worked-as long as they looked good. I suggest that the honourable member for McPherson look at the Defence projections in the late 1970s and the actual expenditure. He will find a gap. The projected expenditure on Defence was never matched by the right honourable member for New England, as Minister for Defence, or his predecessors.

There are two aspects to a defence strategy: the first is international; the second is regional. Australia was part of somebody else's international strategy, particularly America via the American alliance. We have never had a regional defence strategy of any nature. It is therefore not surprising that our equipment was inappropriate and that the major criterion for acquisitions was that they contribute to paying the price for international alliances. The main issue was compatibility, adaptability and absorbability into somebody else's army.

The great irony of tonight's speeches is that the comment made by both the honourable member for McPherson and the right honourable member for New England regarding the Gulf crisis was that somehow we were not suitably absorbed. The fact is that we do not need to be fully absorbed by any other army. The vessels that were sent there played a very useful role. There was no pretence that, as one of the 28 countries involved, we could somehow be a dominant or major participant or an individual, stand alone participant. That is both ludicrous and simple rhetoric.

I should go slightly further. The right honourable member for New England initiated the common task submarine project. Tonight he is talking about how that was wrong. He admits that was wrong, but he will not admit that the Whaler and trainer were wrong and that the negotiation of the Leopard tank was wrong; nor does he admit--

TALK.START.PARA: —Were they wrong?
—Yes.
—All wrong?

—Yes, they all were, and I think the Dibb report and the defence review of 1987 shows that. Nor did the honourable member admit the $1 billion of missing offsets that were negotiated with Krauss Maffei on Leopard tanks and with the Americans on the FFGs. This $1 billion was supposed to be spent in Australia but was never spent, and those involved could not be held to it because the contracts had too many loopholes. That is the record; it does not quite match the rhetoric.

SPEECH.PARA: Defence is just that-defence. This country requires a capacity to defend itself. It also needs to be part of international alliances and arrangements. As I said earlier, previous defence policies were simply international. Equipment was designed to fit into other people's forces; it was predominantly designed for somewhere else, to be used somewhere else-invariably under somebody else's control, as we were in the First World War, as we were in the Second World War and as we were in the Gulf war. That is what international alliances are about. To suggest that we do not have a capacity to defend ourselves in the regional context is not just insulting but downright wrong. It displays not an ignorance but a deliberate intention to distort and to frighten.

The khaki elections of the 1950s and 1960s have gone. We cannot bring them back. This week the Cold War warriors in Moscow will get the same answer from their community that the Opposition will get if it runs that line. We cannot resurrect the threat of the Russian ships in the Pacific or the yellow peril. They have gone. Nowadays, Australians are much too sophisticated for that kind of nonsense.

The Defence into the 21st Century report basically is no great departure from the defence review of 1987 nor the Dibb report. It simply takes the next step of restructuring and positioning. One would imagine from the previous speaker's remarks that there had been a massive cut in defence expenditure. Last year defence took up 2.4 per cent of GDP. For the current year defence will take up 2.4 per cent of GDP. There has been no shift. It is important to point out that we are spending 9.3 per cent of Government outlays.

Members opposite are in for a great surprise if they think that when they are in government the economic rationalists will not be looking at defence as a major area of saving. They are in for a great shock if they think that is not the case. I can assure them that the economic rationalists will be looking at defence cuts. Fortunately, this is something those opposite will not carry out, so I do not think we should be too concerned about defence being attacked.

The right honourable member for New England suggested that we remove one more of the Jindalee radar systems, but let us get that in context. The tender for Jindalee was for two systems-not for three, but with a possible extension to three. The Government is saying in this report and in the Budget that the third one will not be taken up at this point, as it was not originally planned. The right honourable member for New England is now saying that we should take one of those away. He did not say which one. One points predominantly west and one points predominantly north. The third one was to point more to the north-east. Which one does he want to take away?

Nor did the right honourable member talk about the difficulties in securing and protecting AWACS in the air. That surprises me because he certainly would be aware of that. When he spoke about the difficulty of defending defence assets, particularly with the FFGs in the Gulf and the like, he did not mention the cost of defending AWACS. The fact is that the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar-JOTHR, as it is now called-does make a substantial potential contribution to surveillance.

The Dibb report and the defence review of 1987 was basically about surveillance, self-reliance and quality. I notice that the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) seemed to equate defence with numbers of bodies. Subsequent speakers have not fallen to that simplistic notion. Clearly, modern defence is about quality. More importantly, modern defence is about community involvement and support. Previous speakers have referred to the Army reserves, their integration and the important role they play in bridging between the defence forces and the community itself. Defence manufacturing does exactly the same.

It is a source of great pride to me to have watched this Government shift defence expenditure. The figures are of some interest. It is estimated that some 87 per cent of total defence expenditure will be spent in Australia in the current year, including 59 per cent on capital equipment, the order for which will go to Australian companies, using Australian skills and an Australian work force. In 1984-85, that figure was only 25 per cent. It is a source of great pride to me to be part of the Government that has started to make us generally self-reliant in our capacity and has given our work force and our organisations the opportunity and the scope to show their ability and to take pride in contributing to their country.

I believe that people who work in defence manufacturing have a special quality-whether they work in shipbuilding, submarines or other areas. They take a great pride in their work, because it is both demanding and of a high quality. They get a special source of pride because they are helping the nation in a visible and substantial way.

Those opposite talk in the rhetoric of the 1960s and 1970s-the Cold War warriors. They left us with only 25 per cent of capital expenditure being spent in Australia. They lecture us on what defence should be about and then they somehow think the community will take notice of them. I think the people of Australia are much more sophisticated nowadays.

There are some important aspects of the paper that I think need touching on. The first of those is the minehunter project-now being shifted from an inshore minehunter to a coastal minehunter. That is an important change, for two reasons: first, the performance of the smaller vessels in heavy weather. I mentioned earlier that the inshore minehunter was a project started by the previous Government. At the time, no-one differed with the view that inshore minehunters were the appropriate direction in which to go. However, with Australian conditions and the capacity for sudden changes in the states of our seas, acceptance of the need for larger minehunters rather than the smaller inshore ones is an appropriate and important change. I express my public concern, as I have on previous occasions, at the performance of the Navy in the sonar assessment for those vessels. That was lamentable and I think that over time more will be heard of that.

The second important matter that has not been picked up is the shift from a three-tier Navy to a two-tier Navy. That may sound esoteric, but it is a substantial change. What do we need most? Do we need fewer bigger ships or more smaller, smarter ships? I suspect that, with our seas and the expanse we cover as a country, the latter is appropriate.

The paper says that by 2009 there will be 16 vessels, compared to the current figure of 10, with enhanced Anzac frigates starting in 2006 and a new patrol boat starting in 2004. That is a very important statement in the paper because it gives a clear definition.

I was going to touch upon the nuclear submarine option, but time will not allow that. It is important regionally and nationally that we are seen to be defensive of ourselves, and not seen to be overtly offensive to others. The signal that we must give to the world is that Australia is about defence-not about first strike capacities, not about invading others. Our equipment must be seen and must be able to defend our shores, our shipping lanes and our regions. Australia must not be seen to be primarily a country of first strike capacity. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the Opposition have listened with interest to the observations of the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) on what is a very important debate, although it is taking place some three months after the ministerial statement, Defence into the 21st Century, was made in this Parliament on 30 May last.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to draw the attention of the honourable member, who has just left the chamber, to some of the rather intriguing observations he made; for example, his observation that defence is just that-defence. I would certainly like to see how he could analyse that in the context of what we are seeing before our very eyes on television stations around the world of events in the Soviet Union at present. Surely they demonstrate for all to see the fundamental reality of defence planning; that is, international circumstances can change so rapidly and can have such a fundamental effect on whatever principles one may have placed as the basis of one's defence planning.

In fact that was rather well addressed by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) when he spoke on behalf of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) in this place on 30 May. He stated:

Defence planning by its nature must be dynamic and evolve with changing strategic and economic circumstances. We face considerable strategic uncertainties as we enter the 1990s. We are not in Europe, where we might benefit directly from the decline in superpower confrontation.
When the Minister made that statement no doubt he, all members of this House and, I am sure, the entire world hoped and believed that the days of superpower power confrontation were over.

While we have seen, as I said earlier, the most extraordinary events unfolding in the Soviet Union, we still hope we will not see the return to the Soviet Union and to the communist system of a Stalinist government which would once again cast the world into two rival camps. That is something which we must all hope and pray about if we are to develop to any degree a new world order-the words used by President Bush at the time glasnost and perestroika were hailed around the world as being the great step forward-from the abyss of international destruction which has been held over the world since at least the 1950s. If we are not to see a return to that, the reality for nations like Australia is quite simple: defence above all else must, once again, be taken far more seriously than this Government has taken it over recent years.

The force structure review we are debating here tonight represents a recognition that present strategic, economic and political circumstances can no longer support an environment in which defence can look to real funding increases. In fact, it is not unreasonable to say that it would be lucky to achieve zero real growth and negative growth cannot be excluded. That is the underlying reality of this paper, despite the efforts by the honourable member for Newcastle and others to try to read into the statistics a very different situation.

The honourable member also drew the attention of the House to what he regarded as the Cold War warriors of the past. I hope I have managed to put that argument to bed once and for all. He also complained that the previous policies-by that, I presume he meant the policies of Liberal and National governments in the past-were simply to integrate Australia's defence capability into international requirements and to fit in with other people's systems. Anybody who can make a comment like that merely demonstrates the paucity of his understanding of international defence realities and of the need for access to the best and most modern research capabilities and most recent weapons systems.

Of course, the Australian military system must to a considerable degree be integrated with those of our allies. That is not to suggest for one moment that we should be incapable of defending our own national interests-quite the contrary-but it demonstrates the lesson which NATO failed to apply for so long. Despite the fact that all those nations in western Europe were members of that alliance, had signed its treaties, had claims of all sorts of degrees of integration of strategic and defence preparedness, the simple fact of the matter was that when their navies went out onto the North Sea, they found it very difficult to transfer fuel from one ship to another of different navies because they did not even have the same connection on their pumps.

Precisely for those sort of reasons, it is fundamental for the integration of the Australian military capacity that we have the ability to work with, to train with and, if necessary, to fight with similar forces of our allies.

The papers before us have introduced a whole series of interesting reforms. I must emphasise that the Opposition parties do not disagree with all the reforms which the Government has introduced; quite the contrary, some of the reforms are sensible and should be applauded. That is not to say, however, that we totally agree with some of the decisions, such as the decision to reduce our regular battalions from six to four.

We are firmly of the view that a nation of the territorial size of Australia, which has a sea zone equal in area to the total area of our land mass, and one that is a major nation in the South Pacific, is simply incapable of defending its regional interests at this southern end of the Asian land mass without having a Regular Army of at least six battalions. Merely playing around with reserves, establishing a new reserve structure and doing what one likes with the numbers cannot for one minute remove the fundamental reality that, as we saw in the Gulf, the men on the ground are the final determinants of who wins and who loses in a land war.

I need to emphasise this point no more than by drawing attention to the fact that when it was feared that the Iraqis could mount a force of up to a million men, the United States and its allies determined that they could not possibly face that force without at least an enormous additional air capacity and a military force on the ground at a ratio of at least 1 : 2. So for Government members to seriously ask anybody who knows anything about defence to accept any formula of less than six battalions as the basis of the Australian Regular Army is simply absurd.

What we saw in Iraq, and what we have seen in every single military campaign in which Australia has been involved, is that even when one has significant aerial superiority it is the men on the ground who have to fight and die to hold that ground or who have to attack and therefore gain access to the enemy's territory. That is a formula and a dictum that has been in place for hundreds of years and was emphasised so clearly by such outstanding military historians as Clausewitz.

The greater use of civilian infrastructure is one of the major objectives of this package and it is one which the Opposition parties support. It is quite clear that there is a whole range of support tasks currently being carried out by the ADF which could be and should be transferred to the private sector. These tasks include catering, communications, depot level maintenance, the maintenance of defence assets, transport, medical services and various aspects of non-military training.

One of the objectives of the Government's policy is to establish a Ready Reserve of approximately 20,000 men, who would require a year of full time training followed by a rigorous return of service requirement for a further four years. The numbers of that Ready Reserve are estimated to be some 16,000 for the Army, 3,000 for the Navy and 1,500 for the Air Force. In terms of the Air Force-I wish to draw particular attention to this unit-Australia has reached the absurd position where we virtually have more front-line aircraft than we have pilots.

That may seem an extraordinary statement, because I remember only a few years ago when the ratio was precisely the other way around. It demonstrates what the Royal Australian Air Force is facing, as are all other Western air forces, which is the drain-off until quite recently-since the economic recession, which may well have had some effect-of the best-quality pilots. Therefore, it is necessary to have a reserve structure which can maintain the defence readiness of pilots even if they have left the regular service. Any move that can be put in place and that will attract and retain that extraordinarily valuable group of personnel, who I am reliably informed cost about $2m each to train, is clearly in Australia's national interests.

I turn now to cuts in regular ADF numbers. Among the suggestions, as I said earlier, is a reduction from six to four Army battalions. Effectively that means the second line of defence is now, more than ever before, going to be in the hands of the reserve component of the Australian Army. As an ex-reserve officer myself, I have to say in this House that this is a matter of grave concern because, while this document talks about maintaining the existing size of the Army Reserve, the document does not tell us whether adequate resources are being made available so that the reserves can be maintained at an adequate level of preparedness.

I have already been informed by various battalion commanders in my own State that they have had cutbacks in their training funding by up to one-third when compared with their allocation last year. If those figures are even half right, this is a very serious matter indeed. It demonstrates clearly that, if we are to maintain an active and efficient and effective reserve force, it cannot be based on simple numbers of men or women in and out of the service. We must be able to maintain our unit strength to the maximum extent possible and for as long as possible.

As the Government is well aware and as honourable members of this House have mentioned before, the figures quite clearly show that the capacity to retain reservists in Australia in most units is unsatisfactory. Clearly, one of the reasons for that is that reservists honestly believe that, when they are facing all the competition from their wives, girlfriends, local sports clubs, jobs, et cetera, if they are not going to get the support that they regard as absolutely fundamental to ensuring that they do a decent job they simply will not stay in military units. On 30 May in this House when the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) made his statement, he emphasised the need for the defence services to be supported by the community and at the same time to be made up of men and women who were willing and able to serve. I think it is not unreasonable for the Opposition to say to the Government that it is all very well to say those sorts of things, but let us cater to the realities which can make that a viable possibility.

A further change in the structure which the Opposition would support is cuts in civilian numbers to change the ratios between Regular Army personnel and civilians while at the same time ensuring that some functions of the regular reserve services can be transferred to civilians. The final point I want to make concerns base rationalisation. The document contains some useful suggestions in the context of moving units from Victoria and New South Wales into northern Australia, in particular the Northern Territory. It is perfectly clear that, in terms of theatres of operation, it is northern Australia which must be given higher priority than any other part of the mainland. I should also add it is not just northern Australia in the accepted sense of the term, but north-west Australia in particular. The policy contains some significant changes, including the movement of base facilities for the Navy to Western Australia. Again that is useful, especially for the submarine squadrons and the new ships that will be coming on strength.

Perhaps the saddest thing of all is that, although the review adds some credibility to our northern defence posture, it simultaneously sends signals to the region that we are unwilling to come up with the funds necessary to support a significant power projection capability. Those who claim-as did the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris)-that defence is all about keeping people away from Australia miss the fundamental point that the principal defence in a democracy is the capacity to retard any threat to its national sovereignty or national interest. A fundamental strategic review has taken place but regrettably the principles in the White Paper of 1987 are still being applied. As I said in my opening remarks, circumstances change rapidly in international diplomacy and international strategic realities, and regrettably this document does not take that into account. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Snowdon) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Snowdon) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never have there been more Labor members in Federal Parliament from Queensland than there are at the present time. Yet never has Queensland been more poorly treated by a Federal government. Is it that this record 19 ALP members and senators are not doing their job, or is it that they have been squeezed out of the government process? Not one of those 19 members is in Cabinet. There are two minor Ministers but there is no representation at all in the Federal Cabinet. This is the first time since Federation that there has not been a Queenslander in the Federal Cabinet.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, in the whole sorry history of the Hawke Government there has been only one Queenslander in his Cabinet. That was, of course, the Governor-General, Mr Hayden, who was Minister for Foreign Affairs and out of the country for most of the time. Indeed, Labor's treatment of Queensland has been disgraceful. There have been plenty of opportunities to include Queenslanders in the Cabinet but they have never been taken up. Over the years, of the 252 positions in Labor ministries and shadow ministries only 19 have been filled by Queenslanders. That is only 7 1/2 per cent. So its record is consistent in ignoring the talent from the sunshine State. The coalition record is more than double that number and certainly contrasts very favourably.

There is another stark contrast when one looks at what Labor has done for Queensland compared to what is happening in Victoria. Despite the fact that in Victoria the Labor Party was mauled at the last Federal election, it also is represented by 19 Federal members and senators, among them nine Cabinet Ministers, including the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) as well as the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and his Deputy, Senator Gareth Evans.

Every State is better treated than Queensland. Even the ACT has a Minister in Cabinet. Queensland continues to miss out. The ALP does all of its deals to get people up, to sort out the factions and to make sure the mates are looked after, but no Queenslander is ever found a place. Senator Richardson was reported by Peter Beattie, the former State Secretary of the Queensland Labor Party, as saying that none of the Queensland members were any good. But when has talent had anything to do with who the Labor Party appoints to ministerial positions?

In these times of depression, unemployment and record bankruptcies is it suggested that the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) or the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) could not do just as good a job as the Ministers occupying the seats at the present time? When we look around at the pathetic Budget we listened to yesterday and the Bills that have been messed up and regularly brought back into the House, is it suggested that the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) or the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) could not do just as good a job?

Queensland has been consistently discriminated against and disadvantaged by its lack of representation in the Cabinet. When it comes to State grants, local government grants, allocation of tertiary places, road funding, awarding of defence and other government contracts, location of government departments, the parochial allocation of services, arts grants, hospital funding, tourism promotion, and appointments to quangos, wherever one goes Queensland has not been given a fair share of the deal.

This has so angered and embarrassed Premier Goss that he even recruited the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) to become a de facto Minister for Queensland. Premier Goss has expressed no confidence in the Queensland Labor members of parliament to put the case, so he has recruited a Western Australian, an honourable member from Perth, to look after the interests of Queensland. Of course, this honourable member makes occasional visits to the Queensland beaches, like the Prime Minister and some other Ministers, but he holds a marginal seat in Perth. It is hard to believe that he will put the interests of Queensland ahead of his own State whenever a contract is to be awarded or a decision to be made.

Labor treats Queensland with contempt. The Queensland members should stand up and be counted rather than meekly support the Prime Minister in any leadership challenge. On the last such occasion their reward for taking care of the Prime Minister, for being loyal, was to get nothing. Disloyal Ministers remain in office while loyal Queensland members are given no opportunity. After the next election there will be few Queensland ALP members left to be chosen as shadow Ministers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second anniversary of the establishment of the Parliamentary Education Office has passed. I place on record members' appreciation of the work of the dedicated and talented people who are achieving such wonderful results in that office.

SPEECH.PARA: Schools are urged to visit their national Parliament and take part in the full range of programs which have been developed for visitors. First, and most important from a member's point of view, we have the larger public and soundproof galleries, which optimise both access and learning opportunities for students when the House is in session. Second, the Parliamentary Guide Service assists schools by explaining the workings of Parliament and conducting tours of this magnificent building, explaining the finer points of its artistic and architectural features.

However, perhaps the most exciting innovation for the Parliament has been the decision by the Presiding Officers to establish and fund an Education Office to assist members in their efforts to bring the Parliament closer to the thousands of young Australians who visit Canberra each year.

I have had the pleasure of observing participants in the Education Centre's mini-parliament Question Time, and I left the program feeling that we as upholders of parliamentary democracy in this nation should continue to support and enhance the Parliamentary Education Office in all possible ways. The students, under the guidance of a parliamentary education officer, in the program which I witnessed took on the many roles that this chamber has and proceeded to debate the issues which concern government and opposition alike. I understand that committee hearings and debates on Bills also take place in the Education Centre.

As well, the briefing before the role-play gave students an accurate and informative idea of how the process of representation works. This was done by means of the `Parliament Stack' computer display, which is an outstanding achievement by any standard. The debriefing component of the session highlighted the key points relating to the Question Time as the focal point of any parliamentary sitting day. I understand that almost 30,000 students each year are able to take part in the Parliamentary Education Office programs, which are conducted in committee room 1S1.

You, Mr Speaker, and the President of the Senate, Senator Sibraa, have supported the office and the vital role that it is playing in enhancing the knowledge of future generations of citizens from whom our parliamentarians and civic leaders will be elected. It is important that all citizens, including primary and high school students, learn as much as possible about our constitutional heritage, the great Australians who have shaped our political and social history, the process of law-making and how Parliament is the `clearing house' for ideas and issues relating to all Australians.

We are nearing the centenary of our Federation and it is paramount that this Parliament continue its work in getting across the message that parliamentary government is a system which deserves the continuing loyalty of all Australians and their elected representatives. It can do this only if it maintains the proactive stance which our Presiding Officers have established in this area.

I congratulate all members of the Parliamentary Education Office staff and I exhort them to keep up the good work. I pay particular tribute to Richard Gilbert, John Carter, David Arnold, Peter McMahon, Di Weddell, Janice Hourigan, Marie Ferris, Sue Frost, Therese Rogers, Ros Lilburn, Jenny Nyman, Sue Irvine and Cathy McLean.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Victorian Treasurer, Mr Tom Roper, criticise the Reserve Bank for failing to play a more positive role before the collapse of the Pyramid Building Society.
(2) Did Mr Roper attribute a number of problems in Victorian financial institutions to deregulation in banking.

(3) What actions (a) should have been taken and (b) were taken by the Reserve Bank with respect to (i) the collapse of the Farrow Group of building societies, (ii) the collapse of Tricontinental and (iii) the consequential problems of the State Bank of Victoria.

(4) What part did deregulation play with respect to (a) the collapse of the Farrow Group building societies, (b) the collapse of Tricontinental and (c) the consequential problems of the State Bank of Victoria.
(5) Did Mr Roper suggest that control of financial institutions, including building societies, should be exercised at a national level.
(6) Did the Hon. E.G. Whitlam claim that the problems with financial institutions in Victoria would not have occurred if Part IV of the Financial Corporations Act 1974 had been proclaimed.
(7) Has Part IV of the Financial Corporations Act 1974 been proclaimed; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (5) Comments by the Victorian Treasurer are a matter for him.

(3) The answer to this question should be seen in the context of the responsibilities of the Reserve Bank for the main groups of financial intermediaries. In terms of the Banking Act 1959, the Reserve Bank is responsible for the prudential supervision of banks authorised under that Act. The Act does not apply to state banks or to non-bank financial intermediaries (NBFI's) such as building societies or merchant banks. However, all State banks have undertaken to comply voluntarily with the Reserve Bank's prudential requirements which apply to Banking Act banks.

In the case of the State Bank of Victoria (SBV), the voluntary arrangements agreed between that bank and the Reserve Bank were replaced during 1990, at the Victorian Government's initiative, by a formal understanding between the Victorian Government and the Reserve Bank on future supervision of the SBV. (These arrangements lapsed when SBV was acquired by the Commonwealth Bank.)

The Reserve Bank is not involved in on-site inspections of banks but monitors prudential matters relating to banks and encourages sound prudential practices. It does this through the collection and analysis of statistics, regular consultations with banks' management and arrangements with external auditors of banks. In recent years some supervisory requirements have been extended to comprehend the operation of banks' subsidiaries as well as banks themselves.

Given the Reserve Bank's general role in maintaining a stable and efficient financial system, it takes a close interest in developments affecting non-banks. In broad terms, if an NBFI gets into difficulty, the Reserve Bank has a twofold role:
To assess possible implications of that intermediary's difficulties for the stability of the wider financial system and, if necessary, to consider steps to deal with any threats to that stability;

To ensure that bankers to NBFIs are aware of the Reserve Bank's policy that banks should be sympathetic to reasonable requests for liquidity support from NBFI's which they judge to be viable and well managed, and that the Reserve Bank would assist banks should their own liquidity come under strain in providing assistance to an NBFI.
Turning to the particular financial institutions mentioned:
I am informed that when the difficulties of the Farrow Group of building societies emerged in the first half of 1990 the Bank, consistent with its broad role as described above, acted to:
Authorise a reference to the Bank's understanding with other banks on liquidity support in the press release by the Victorian Treasurer and Attorney-General on 13 February 1990;
Initiate regular discussions on developments with the Victorian Registrar of Co-operative Societies, who is the supervisor of building societies in that State;
Discuss developments with Mr Farrow and other members of management of the Farrow group;
Liaise with senior management of other building societies, as well as with representatives of the building society industry;
Confirm with banks their understanding of the Reserve Bank's policy on liquidity support for NBFI's; and

Issue on 2 July 1990 a press release noting that it had been involved in discussions leading to the support package arranged by the Victorian Government for non-Farrow building societies, and stating its assessment that the problems of the Farrow group were not shared by the other societies in Victoria, or in other states.

In recent years, in its consultations with SBV, the Reserve Bank had sought to test the appropriateness of that bank's strategy, including the fast rate of growth of Tricontinental and of the group as a whole. It pressed SBV to comply on a group basis with the capital adequacy standard which was introduced in 1988.

To help stabilise the situation when problems began to emerge during 1989, the Bank accepted the provision by SBV of substantial liquidity support to Trico and, subsequently, its guaranteeing of Trico's liabilities.

The Bank also took a series of steps to ensure that the interests of SBV's depositors were protected. These steps included advice to the Victorian Government and the bank aimed at maintaining minimum capital requirements, and close monitoring of SBV's liquidity position. It consulted closely with State Government officials and the management of SBV regarding the support arrangements implemented by the Government.

(4) I do not wish to comment specifically on the causes of collapse of the Farrow building societies and Tricontinental, which are the subject of ongoing investigations in Victoria. Nor do I wish to pre-empt possible findings of the current Parliamentary inquiry into the banking industry and deregulation. I can, however, make some general comments.

The major thrusts of financial deregulation were to remove direct controls on the operations of banks, to relax restrictions on entry into the Australian financial system, and to open up foreign exchange markets. These measures saw a substantial increase in the numbers of banks and non-bank intermediaries operating in Australia and, in turn, led to increased competition. In this competitive environment, combined with rapid growth in demand for credit for a variety of purposes, including asset speculation, there was some erosion both of credit assessment standards and management practices by lenders. These factors impacted on some financial institutions more than others.

Prudential supervision for many groups of financial institutions has been upgraded in recent years in response to problems that have emerged or appeared in prospect. However, prudential supervision, no matter how good, cannot give absolute assurance that individual institutions will be problem free.

Ultimately, the continuing viability of financial institutions depends on the competence and integrity of their managements. While deregulation has highlighted this necessity (particularly in regard to management of credit risks), that process as such cannot be held responsible for the worst problems experienced by some financial institutions in the past year or so.
(6) The Hon. E.G. Whitlam's comments are a matter for him.

(7) Part IV of the Financial Corporations Act 1974 has not been proclaimed. As I said in my answer on 11 March 1991 to Question No. 143 also asked by Mr Scholes, Part IV was seen as providing reserve powers over financial corporations to be used if necessary for monetary policy, rather than prudential supervision, purposes. The powers were broadly equivalent to those that applied to banks covered under the Banking Act. Monetary policy no longer relies on the Banking Act provisions but is exercised through open market operations. Recourse to Part IV is not, therefore, relevant.

Part IV powers, even if invoked, would not be an adequate basis for prudential supervision of non- bank financial intermediaries. The Part does not contain provisions relating to the financial stability of corporations, or to the protection of depositors; nor does it contain requirements directed at the financial soundness or prudent operations of financial corporations.
