QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 12 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What (a) number and (b) proportion of the total number of persons in Australia who have died from AIDS or been diagnosed as suffering from the syndrome since it was first identified in Australia were (i) homosexuals who were not intravenous drug users, (ii) homosexual intravenous drug users, (iii) bisexuals who were not intravenous drug users, (iv) bisexual intravenous drug users, (v) heterosexuals who were not intravenous drug users and (vi) heterosexual intravenous drug users.

(2) Does the number under category (v) in part (1) represent a small proportion of the total and do the numbers under the other categories represent a high proportion; if so, do the advertisements about AIDS promoted by the Federal Government put an exclusive emphasis on low risk areas and none on high risk areas; if so, why.
(3) Will more advertisements be aimed at other low risk categories such as geriatrics and clergy in enclosed orders; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The following statistics on AIDS cases and deaths were reported to the National Centre in HIV Epidemiology and Clinical Research to 31 March 1991.
(i) and (iii) homosexual and bisexual men who were not intravenous drug users (the data cannot distinguish between homosexually and bisexually acquired AIDS):
(b) These were respectively 86.5 per cent and 87.5 per cent of the total adults AIDS cases and deaths;
(ii) and (iv) homosexual and bisexual intravenous drug users,
(b) 2.6 per cent and 2.5 per cent of all adult cases and deaths respectively;
(v) heterosexuals who were not intravenous drug users,
(b) 1.5 per cent and 0.8 per cent of all adult cases and deaths respectively;
(b) 1.5 per cent and 1.1 per cent of adult cases and death respectively.

(2) The numbers and proportion of AIDS cases and deaths arising from injecting drug use and heterosexual contact in Australia remain low. However, AIDS represents the end stage of HIV infection: the average time between initial infection and diagnosis of AIDS is around ten years.

There is evidence that HIV infection among heterosexuals and injecting drug users is rising in Australia. Heterosexuals who were not injecting drug users comprised 6.5 per cent of new adult HIV diagnoses in Australia (excluding NSW for which no data were available) in the last six months of 1990. Heterosexual injecting drug users comprised 3.1 per cent of the total for that period. The experience from other Western countries shows that HIV can spread rapidly among these groups. Australia is almost unique in having avoided this spread to date.

(3) Preventive education will continue to target those groups for which there is clear evidence that HIV infection can pose a significant threat. This includes injecting drug users and sexually active young people who are not always readily distinguishable and are spread throughout the population. HIV/AIDS is a communicable disease for which there is no vaccine or cure and where there are often no observable symptoms for many years. There is a responsibility for health authorities to provide clear education messages about modes of transmission and the means of prevention to all Australians.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Coverage of Parliament

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 11 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a letter from Mr David Hill, the Managing Director of the ABC, sent to all Members of Parliament indicating that Mr Hill and not Parliament will determine how Parliament will be covered by the ABC.

(2) Has his attention also been drawn to claims that the ABC's news department enhanced a recording of Question Time on 6 March 1991 which resulted in a different presentation on ABC news from that recorded on the official tape of proceedings during a speech by the Member for Bennelong.
(3) Does the ABC's coverage of Question Time on 6 March 1991 represent a proper exercise of the ABC's right to make its own decisions on its coverage of proceedings in the House.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of Mr Hill's letter of 26 March 1991 to all Members of Parliament. The ABC has advised me that this letter was in response to queries from parliamentarians and viewers about the procedures adopted by the ABC during the current trial period of televising from the House of Representatives. The ABC has advised that the letter sought to fully inform members of those procedures and, in so doing, clarify any misunderstandings which may have existed. The ABC considers that in covering proceedings from both chambers of Parliament, the ABC observes the broadcasting guidelines prescribed by both the House and the Senate. For this purpose it maintains regular contact with the appropriate officers of the Parliament.

(2) I am aware of claims that the ABC's news department enhanced a recording of Question Time on 6 March 1991. The ABC considers that careful examination of the item in question, including comparison with Hansard and the official tape, shows that there was no `enhancement' of the recording. Nor was there any departure from the House guidelines governing such excerpting. The three excerpts from the Member for Bennelong's speech used in the ABC news report were not in chronological order. However, the ABC considers that this does not constitute `enhancement' nor was it in breach of the televising guidelines.

(3) Yes. The ABC's coverage of Question Time on 6 March 1991 represents a proper exercise of the ABC's right to make its own decision on its coverage of proceedings in the House, subject to compliance with the conditions laid down from time to time by the House. A recording of the ABC's coverage of Question Time in the House on 6 March 1991 was broadcast late that night. The ABC has advised that that replay had been edited in accordance with House guidelines after consultation with officers of the Parliament. If the honourable member has a further problem with this he might raise it with Mr Speaker.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 11 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) At what price does Australian liquid petroleum gas sell on the (a) Japanese and (b) domestic market.
(2) If there is a price difference, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Australian liquified petroleum gas (LPG) is sold on the Japanese market in major cities at between 60 cents per litre for automotive use, to about $1.20 per litre for household use.

(b) Australian LPG prices are around half or less than half those prevailing in Japan, although there is considerable regional variation in prices. For example, automotive LPG can vary from around 20 cents per litre in Melbourne, to nearer 40 cents per litre in coastal Queensland towns.
Australia exports about one third of its LPG production, with Japan our major market. The prices which Australian producers receive are consistent with world traded prices.

(2) Prices are higher in Japan because of the high costs of shipping, internal transport and distribution, and taxes on LPG use. There are no taxes on LPG use in Australia, except for a small State tax in Tasmania.

The benefits of the Australian Government's LPG policies have been reflected in low prices and seen LPG demand in all its uses in Australia grow by an annual average of 12 per cent in recent years. The most recent Government LPG policy initiative has been the deregulation of LPG markets from 1 January 1991. This has sent the right signals to industry so that the necessary infrastructure is set in place to ensure supply, and to encourage further LPG production in association with crude oil and natural gas resource developments.

At the same time, Australian consumers also benefit from the close monitoring by the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA), in conjunction with State authorities, of producer, distributor and retail prices of LPG.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Wollongong University Centre for Technological and Social Change

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the history of the Minister's Department's commercial and other dealings with the Wollongong University Centre for Technological and Social Change.
(2) How many contracted research reports did the Department seek from the University in (a) 1989, (b) 1990 and (c) 1991.
(3) What was the cost of each of the reports referred to in part (2).
(4) What other sources of contracted research are available to the Department.
(5) Why was the Australian Science and Technology Council not used with respect to the reports referred to in part (2).
(6) Why could not the Department complete the reports.
(7) Were other organisations officially contacted to tender for the reports; if so, (a) what organisations and (b) if they were considered unsuitable, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) With the incorporation in the Department of responsibility for technology in 1985, it was realised that the complex issue of Australia's technological development required detailed research to provide the information with which to develop sensible policy options. This expertise was not available in-house, was largely undeveloped in the academic community, and virtually nonexistent in the private sector. It was decided that a critical mass of researchers was needed and the Centre for Technology and Social Change (TASC) was the only sizeable group with appropriate expertise.

DITAC entered into a general consultancy for three years to carry out a series of research projects. The aim was to provide security of funding to facilitate the expansion of TASC to enable the Centre to develop further expertise in areas vital to policy development and to carry out studies of significant science and technology policy issues for DITAC. A steering committee of Departmental officers and TASC researchers was established to oversee the consultancy and a senior Departmental officer was placed on the TASC Board. In 1990 the steering committee was disbanded.
In 1990, four consulting contracts to be carried out over a two year period were awarded to TASC on the understanding that all future work would be on the basis of a competitive tendering process.

The Department has had an additional five contracts for purposes other than the production of reports with the University of Wollongong over the period in question. These contracts were let for running symposia, courses and workshops.
To produce a report on Technology Policy for the 1990s, lessons from the 80s $30,875
To undertake a study of innovation and competitiveness in the food processing industry $160,952
To undertake a literature survey on research and development effectiveness and provide an analysis $12,400
To undertake an analysis of space investments by overseas countries $15,000
To undertake a study of major industrial collaboration in ASEAN countries $95,000
To undertake a stocktake of published science and technology policies of Pacific Rim nations and provide a report $10,000
To establish two databases, one containing details of Australian expatriate information technology researchers, the other containing curricula vitae of these researchers $72,600
To undertake a study of Australian leading edge customers and industrial development and provide three papers and one report $175,000

(4) Over the last five years a few other sources of contracted research on technology policy have developed. These include academic policy and management researchers. The capabilities and expertise of these sources vary widely.

(5) ASTEC is an independent advisory body established by Government to respond to issues and references put to it by the Prime Minister or initiated by the Council itself. The Council is fully occupied with these tasks.
(6) DITAC did not have the staff resources to carry out these detailed technology policy research projects and the objective was to build up expertise outside the Department.

(7) The Department's commissioned reports were in the context of the aims set in (1), ie to facilitate the expansion of TASC and the development of its capabilities in significant areas of technology policy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many (a) items of intellectual property developed or (b) ideas conceived within the CSIRO since 1975 have been commercialised by (i) overseas or foreign owned companies, (ii) Australian owned companies and (iii) joint ventures between the CSIRO and (A) overseas or foreign owned companies and (B) Australian owned companies.
(2) What was the commercial significance of each item or idea referred to in part (1).
(3) Which research projects deemed by the CSIRO to warrant commercial support have failed to obtain such support.
(4) With respect to each of the projects referred to in part (3), (a) why did the CSIRO believe commercial support to be warranted and (b) why was the support not forthcoming.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) From July 1975 to June 1990 CSIRO filed in Australia 1,290 patent application accompanied by a provisional specification. Statistics are not maintained on non-patentable ideas conceived by CSIRO officers. Centralised computer records of agreements entered into by CSIRO were not kept until 1984. An examination of current agreement file records (which date back to 1984 and include agreements entered into earlier than that date which were current in 1984) has shown the following breakdown:
(i) agreements with overseas or foreign owned companies (186);
(iii) (A) joint ventures with overseas or foreign owned companies (2)
(B) joint ventures with Australian owned companies (6)
These numbers include licences and joint ventures which have been in place or under negotiation since 1984; they include some which have lapsed.

(2) The commercial significance of intellectual property the subject of the 1,290 patent applications and 952 agreements referred to in part (1) varies enormously. CSIRO has had a number of important projects assessed for their potential commercial value by independent experts. but the expense of carrying out such evaluations is too high for this mechanism to be applied universally in CSIRO. The following table shows the numbers of provisional patent applications filed and the royalties received by CSIRO between 1975 and 1990.

Comprehensive data are not available on the benefits to Australia of CSIRO innovations. However, studies which have been done [including a major study of the output of the CSIRO Division of Entomology by the (then) Industries Assistance Commission] have confirmed that these benefits significantly outweigh costs.

(3) and (4) CSIRO has a statutory function to carry out scientific research in support of a wide range of areas of Australian national interest, including assistance to Australian industry. In carrying out the latter role, CSIRO aims to produce research results which will be relevant to industry. The Organisation has a widely publicised priorities exercise designed to ensure early dialogue between scientists and companies to ensure more efficient transfer of technology to Australian industry. CSIRO assesses its portfolio of research projects against a range of criteria related to potential national benefits, costs, technical achievability and (where relevant) likely market interest. In assessing potential market viability CSIRO is strongly guided by the market itself. Commercial-in-confidence discussions are usually held after a call for expressions of interest from the market in Australia. CSIRO's policy is to involve commercial collaborators at the earliest possible stage - ie before major investments have been made in the particular technologies. A failure to attract market interest is not necessarily seen as an adverse judgement on the technology itself; quite often similar technologies are being vigorously pursued overseas. The judgement may reflect market factors peculiar to the circumstances of Australian firms in the relevant industry individually or collectively. In the main, therefore, CSIRO tailors its industrially oriented research to the needs and capacities of Australian industry, and most of the Organisation's important output in this area is either being used already by industry or is the subject of collaboration or negotiation with industry with a view to finding mutually satisfactory ways of developing and applying the relevant technologies for the benefit of Australia, especially by promoting exports. Gene Shears is a recent example of a development which does not fit this model exactly; it is of such global significance that it required participation by world-leaders in the relevant industries to ensure its proper commercial development. At the request of the CSIRO Board, CSIRO is at present identifying and delineating six projects not already committed to commercial collaborators which appear to have major commercial potential. The results of this exercise are expected to be available in August 1991.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With respect to each grant made under the Teaching Companies Scheme since its inception, (a) who received the grant, (b) with which institution was the recipient affiliated, (c) with which private sector company was the recipient undertaking a research project, (d) what (i) did the project cost the company and (ii) was the object of the project.
(2) How does the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce determine (a) who should enter the scheme and (b) what is a viable research project to be conducted within the scheme.
(3) What procedures are used to monitor the outcomes of the Scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The National Teaching Company Scheme provides financial support for company based projects and as such the grant is awarded to the company, although the Associate employed under the Scheme may be administratively employed by either the company or institution. If the company chooses to be the employer, the Scheme pays the company over a maximum two years, $6,000 towards administrative costs of employing the Associate, $34,000 towards the Associate's salary and pays $10,000 to the participating institution department for the provision of academic support and equipment.

Should the company and institution agree that it would be more convenient for the institution to be the employer of the Associate, the Scheme pays the institution, on behalf of the company, the administrative and salary component of the grant as well as the academic support costs. In either case the company pays the balance of the graduate's salary, salary on-costs, project expenses and travel costs associated with the Associate's attendance at the Annual Conference of Teaching Company Associates.

(b) The National Teaching Company Scheme is supporting projects where companies are collaborating with the majority of Australia's public sector research institutions. A list of companies and participating institutions is available for the honourable member's information.
(c) The Scheme has provided support to 212 projects involving some 200 companies. The list available will provide the honourable member with the names of the companies.
(d) (i) This information is not available as it is provided to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce under a `Commercial-in-Confidence' classification.

(ii) The object of all projects supported under the Scheme is to facilitate the growth and international competitiveness of Australian companies by providing support to projects designed to improve company performance. It is not possible however, to provide details of the objective of each project because this information has `Commercial-in-Confidence' status.

(2) (a) All Australian companies and firms (incorporated or not), public trading trusts and overseas owned companies incorporated in Australia are eligible to apply for support under the Scheme. Officers of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce visit all applicant companies/institutions to assess project applications against established criteria. Applications and assessments are then considered against the selection criteria by an independent committee comprising members from industry, academe and officers of the Department.

(b) A viable project supported under the Scheme is one that meets all the selection criteria and which the Department/Committee considers, on the basis of relative merit, will be of significant benefit to the company and the economy of Australia.

(3) Under the terms of the National Teaching Company Scheme agreement between the Commonwealth, company and institution, the parties are required to submit quarterly financial and project progress reports to the Department. During the course of each project, officers of the Department make regular visits or contact with the participating companies and institutions. At the conclusion of each project the Department also conducts a final assessment to determine the outcome of the project against both the Scheme's and project's stated objectives.

Additionally, the Scheme is subject to external review. The Bureau of Industry Economics released a report on the Scheme on 2 June 1991. This report makes a number of recommendations, which are currently being considered. It should be noted, however, that the Bureau of Industry Economics found, inter-alia, that the Scheme:
Is policy relevant in operating at the interface between industry and research institutions;
Sensitises companies to the value of investing in research and development:
Demonstrates the benefits for companies in establishing links with academe and research institutions.
The Bureau of Industry Economics recommends continued Government support for the Scheme at about its present level.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Industry, Science and Technology Counsellor Network

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the prescribed duties of international science and technology counsellors.
(2) Are the duties applied uniformly.
(3) When was the counsellor network initiated.
(4) What is the total operational cost, including travel and entitlements, of the counsellor network in 1990-91.
(5) What is the total sum spent on the counsellor network since its inception.
(6) Has the effectiveness of the counsellor network been evaluated; if so, what are the details.
(7) What concrete results have been achieved by the counsellor network.
(8) What is the (a) justification for the location and (b) diplomatic status of each counsellor.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The main duties of the Counsellors in the Australian Industry, Science and Technology Counsellor Network (ASTCON) are:
(a) Articulating the national viewpoint on matters within the responsibility of the Industry, Technology and Commerce portfolio in a range of forums in their host country;

(b) Promotion of industry, science and technology cooperation between Australia and the various host countries, eg. via inter-firm collaboration, investment promotion, technology transfer and cooperation in pre-competitive research and development;
(c) Analysis and evaluation of the implications of significant industry, science and technology policy trends in their host countries or other countries on request;
(d) Development and maintenance of high level contacts with industry, government and research institutions;
(e) Gathering information and policy analysis as requested by the Department and other bodies associated with the Industry, Technology and Commerce portfolio, and other portfolios as appropriate; and
(f) Promotion of Australia's industrial, scientific and technological achievements and capabilities.

(2) Counsellors are encouraged to exercise their initiative in developing their role in their host country's IS& communities. As a result the resources allocated to these duties will vary over time and between posts. In the case of France the Paris Counsellor is required to devote a considerable amount of time to Australia's participation in the ongoing work of the OECD, particularly the Industry Committee and the Committee for Scientific and Technological Policy, as well as pursuing bilateral work with the French Government.

(3) The Australian Industry, Science and Technology Counsellor Network (ASTCON) was established in 1985 as a program of the then Department of Science and was incorporated into the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce when those Departments were amalgamated in 1987.
(4) The estimated operational cost in 1990-91, in terms of direct administrative expenses, salaries and allowances paid to the Counsellors is $802,000.

(5) The estimated cost, since amalgamation of the Science and Industry, Technology and Commerce Departments in 1987, including 1990-91 - based on administrative expenses, salaries and allowances - is $2,938,000.

(6) Evaluation of the Department's overseas representation is an ongoing process. The mission statement of the Counsellors was reviewed in 1990 to ensure that it remained consistent with the Government's objective to internationalise Australian industry.

(7) In addition to the support provided to the Portfolio and the wider S& community in Australia (see response to Question (l) above), concrete results from the work of IS& Counsellors during the past twelve months include the following:

(a) Meetings arranged by our Counsellor (IS&), Paris, with the French Government resulted in the successful French/Australian Science Colloquium held in April 1991 in Australia which covered marine science, astronomy, informatics and telecommunications, and environment and Antarctica.

The Counsellor assisted in negotiations leading to my predecessor signing with his French counterpart M Curien, two new arrangements to facilitate bilateral collaboration under our S& Agreement with France. One of these established the French- Australian Industrial Research (FAIR) program; the other will provide a conduit to link research and commercial developments in marine sciences.

The Counsellor has also been active in OECD work, resulting inter alia in her election as chairperson of the Experts Group on Subsidies and Structural Adjustment, the General Working Party of the Industry Committee, and the Information Services and Invisible Transfers working groups.

(b) Following the meeting in Bonn between my predecessor and the German Minister for Research and Technology, Dr Riesenhuber, general agreement on the need to raise the level of R& interaction between the two countries was reached. Our Counsellor (IS&), Bonn, has been closely involved in developing specific opportunities for collaboration in the areas of new materials, advanced manufacturing technologies, and environmental technologies. The work has involved coordinating interactions between DITAC and the German Ministry for Research and Technology (BMFT).

In addition the Counsellor has arranged a formal Agreement between the University of NSW and the University of Bonn that involves exchange of post- graduate students and academic researchers. She has also played a major role in the successful conclusion of an Agreement between the Australian Research Council and the Humboldt Foundation. The Counsellor has also facilitated several joint research projects between Australian academic institutions and research bodies in Germany.

The Counsellor played an important role in the successful Joint Workshop on Software Engineering organised by the Australian Software Foundation and the German National Research Centre for Computer Science held in January 1991 in Australia. She has also facilitated the visits to Australia of several leading German officials.

(c) Our Counsellor (IS&), London, provided support for discussions in Italy and Spain and for the Commonwealth Science Ministers Meeting in Malta in November 1990. He also arranged Minister Beddall's visit to the UK in February 1991, provided necessary briefing and accompanied the Minister.
The Counsellor has been involved in both the negotiation and development of activities under the recently signed Education and Science Agreement between Australia and the UK.

The Counsellor has participated in investment/offset activities, the major one being involvement in preparation for the UK/Australia Trade and Investment conference, including management of the preparation of the consultancy report used as the basis for the talks.

Because of the relationship and similarities between Australia and the UK, combined with a strong S& policy research base in the UK, a key activity for the Counsellor is monitoring and reporting relevant IS& developments. He also monitors these developments in Ireland and the Netherlands.
The Counsellor has also been involved in developing activities under the Netherlands/Australia Technology and Industrial Cooperation Agreement.

(d) Our IS& Officer in Brussels, has carried out valuable work in support of ongoing negotiations for a S& agreement with the EC. When the Agreement is finally negotiated, Australia should be the first non-EC member and non-EFTA country to access the Community's research and development programs.

In addition, the IS& Officer has provided essential support for the officials and ministerial bilateral consultations held respectively in March and May 1991 with the Commission of the European Community (CEC). She also played a key role in negotiations with the CEC regarding Australia's participation in the EC Business Cooperation Network (BC-NET). This is a major EC initiative to foster strategic alliances between small and medium sized businesses in EC member countries.

(e) The Counsellor (IS&), Washington, was closely involved in facilitating closer links with Canada's Toronto-based Centres of Excellence. Follow-up work has included identification of specific areas of potential collaboration which he matched with Australian institutes. Direct outcomes from these activities include contact by Australian researchers with the Canadian centres, and proposals by Australian researchers to travel to specific Canadian centres to discuss further possible collaboration.

The Counsellor also provided extensive and essential key liaison with the Office of Congressman Robert Roe, then Chairperson of the US House of Representatives Science, Space and Technology Committee, during the organisation of Congressman Roe's successful fact finding visit to Australia in November 1990.

Over the last twelve months the Counsellor has provided input of both a significant and timely nature on the US position on the Intelligent Manufacturing System (IMS) project. The IMS is a major international collaborative research project in advanced manufacturing technologies, with potentially important benefits for the future of Australian manufacturing industry. The intelligence provided by the Counsellor was an important factor in consideration of the nature of Australia's involvement in the project.

The Washington Counsellor, like the other Counsellors, has provided a wide range of reports on various industry, science and technology issues and trends in his host country. The reports have covered issues such as how the host country sets science and technology funding priorities, regulation of transgenic manipulations and small business programs. These reports are important inputs into policy and program development processes.

(f) The Counsellor (IS&), Tokyo, has undertaken a wide variety of liaison activities with Government Ministries and organisations in relation to bilateral interaction under the S& Agreement and broader aspects of industrial cooperation including liaison on specific proposals for S& and industrial cooperation.
He was involved in discussions leading to an agreement in September 1990 to increase the emphasis in S& Cooperation on applied research.

This position has also provided an important link during the development of Australia's position on Japanese initiated multilateral S& programs such as the Intelligent Manufacturing System and the Human Frontier Science Program. The Counsellor also provides information on Japan's national R& programs, in which foreign companies and research bodies are invited to participate.

The Counsellor is actively participating in the development of the MOUs covering Australia's participation at the Photon Factory (at Tsukuba) and marine biotechnology cooperation. Both of these agreements are expected to result in commercial benefits in the longer term. He has also been involved in commercial negotiations (eg for ANSTO in respect of silicon irradiation contracts).

The coordination of science research exchanges, and the organisation of research missions to Japan such as the Optical and Opto Electronic Materials and Joining and Casting Missions also form an important component of the Counsellor's activities.

(8) (a) The geographical locations of the ASTCON Counsellor posts represent the major centres of international, industrial, scientific and technological influence, thus affording Counsellors the best opportunity to forge links which facilitate the internationalisation of Australian industry. However, the location of ASTCON posts is constantly under review. Only last year a part-time IS& Officer was appointed to Brussels to monitor on a day to day basis, significant developments in industry, science and technology in the EC, as well as to report on Benelux.

(b) The Network has Counsellors, Industry, Science and Technology (IS&) located in Washington, London, Paris, Bonn and Tokyo. They all enjoy full diplomatic accreditation to the Governments of their host countries. The Department's representative in Paris is also accredited to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), while the London position is also accredited to the Commission for the European Communities in Brussels. The Department's IS& Officer at the Australian Embassy in Brussels coordinates her work with the Counsellor in London but has no diplomatic accreditation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) To what extent is the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce involved in seeking tenders for the Cape York Spaceport project.
(2) Have any (a) local or (b) overseas enterprises lodged tenders; if so, (i) who and (ii) what evaluation has been made of their commercial and technical competence to undertake the project.
(3) What role has the Australian Industry Development Corporation played in seeking tenders for the project.

(4) Did any member of the Space Board have any direct or indirect involvement in or foreknowledge of the withdrawal of the Cape York Space Agency, owned by Essingtons, from the project; if so, what are the details.
(5) If the spaceport does not proceed which other spaceports in the region will derive a likely commercial benefit from the resulting lack of competition.
(6) Are other efforts being made to develop or expand commercial launch facilities in the region; if so, what are the details.
(7) Has the Space Board ever (a) made or (b) seen assessments of the commercial viability of a privately funded spaceport at Cape York.
(8) Is there interaction between the CSIRO's Division of Space Science Applications and the Space Board; if so, what has been its extent since 1988.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Firstly, in responding to the various parts of this question I must emphasise that the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce is not involved in calling tenders for the Cape York spaceport project. They are, however, interested in receiving assurance that the funds and other resources required to move the project forward are available within industry, and have sought registrations of interest from commercial organisations who believe they could satisfy this requirement.

The Australian Space Office has contracted AIDC Ltd to review and confirm the commercial viability of the spaceport project. AIDC Ltd will then prepare an investment package and conduct negotiations with commercial and industrial interests to establish a proponent.

The activity of AIDC Ltd is therefore not a matter of calling tenders but one of vetting and accepting proof of the credentials of those who wish to be the spaceport proponent. Since the spaceport is not a government project, the final composition of any spaceport consortium will remain a matter for private commercial interests to resolve.

As noted in Senator Button's Press Release of 19 February, the purpose of the AIDC Ltd activity is to determine if there is a single substantial Australian proponent with access to the financial, technical and management resources which will be necessary to complete the next phase of the spaceport's development and with whom the Government can proceed with confidence.

(2) The 23 companies (both local and overseas) which registered interest with the Space Office did so on a commercially confidential basis. It would therefore be inappropriate to release their names without their consent. It should be noted however that it is open to any of these 23 companies to approach any of the other companies which have made public their interest and intentions regarding the development of a spaceport.

No evaluation has been made at this stage of these companies' commercial and technical competence to undertake the project. AIDC Ltd has held preliminary discussions with the majority of registrants in order to establish the level of their interest.
(3) As advised earlier in this reply, neither AIDC Ltd nor anyone else has been involved in calling tenders.

(4) To the best of the Government's knowledge CYSA has not withdrawn from the project and Essington is understood to be still seeking equity partners with the objective of satisfying the Government's requirements.
(5) Except for China, there are no other commercial spaceports in the region. China might or might not benefit from lack of competition.

(6) There have been reports in the press and elsewhere that Hawaii, Indonesia or Kiribati might be the site for a spaceport. Hawaii is known to have the matter under active consideration. There has been no official confirmation that any of these are to go ahead. The Japanese have not decided whether to start up a commercial launch service from their spaceport at Tanegashima.

(7) (b) No, but the Space Board has received verbal briefing by the Australian Space Office on the findings of Cape York Space Agency (CYSA) commercial viability studies. This information is propriety to CYSA.
(8) There has been ongoing interaction between the CSIRO's Office of Space Science and Applications and the Space Board with:
Representation by CSIRO at meetings of the Space Board through the Director of CSIRO Office of Space Science and Applications, and
Cooperation between the Space Board (through the Space Office) and the CSIRO's Office of Space Science and Applications in many areas including major projects such as:
The Atmospheric Pressure Sensor (APS) - a passive remote sensing instrument being developed to measure atmospheric pressure at the earth's surface from a satellite platform, and

The Tasmanian Earth Resources Satellite Station (TRESS) - a satellite receiving station capable of receiving down-linked remotely sensed data in X and S frequency bands from both current and planned earth resources satellites.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 8 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Government delegate the provision of inoculation services to State governments in 1989 and subsequently reintroduce the provision of those services by Australian Government Health Services; if so, (a) why, (b) will private practitioners be affected by the reintroduction and (c) did the Government indicate when provision of the services was originally transferred that they would subsequently be reintroduced by the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) and (c) With the exception of yellow fever vaccinations, the Commonwealth did not delegate the provision of inoculation services to State governments in 1989. Unlike childhood inoculations (such as measles and mumps) and most vaccinations required for overseas travel (typhoid, cholera), yellow fever vaccinations were, prior to 1989, solely provided by the Commonwealth Government. In March 1989, provision of yellow fever vaccination services for members of the general public was delegated to State governments as a staff saving measure and to facilitate public access.

The Commonwealth retained the right to provide a yellow fever vaccination service, together with a full range of other vaccination services. In 1989, it limited the provision of vaccination services to government employees and other officials. Because of a continued demand for the Australian Government Health Service (AGHS) vaccination and health advisory services, combined with the transfer of AGHS operations to a cost recovery mode from 1 July 1990, AGHS again opened its vaccination service to the general public on a user pays basis.

(b) It is not expected that private practitioners will be affected significantly by the reintroduction of AGHS public vaccination services. AGHS does not seek a monopoly in the market and the cost of its services to the individual higher than those of private practitioners.

(5) No. There is no obligation on the State to provide such information to the Federal Government. Planning responsibility for the project is primarily a State matter.

(6) No. There is no obligation on the State to provide such information to the Federal Government. Planning responsibility for the project is primarily a State matter. It is understood however that the service centre is to be sited some five metres above the flood plain.

(7) Yes. The Administrative Procedures under the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988 require that any rentals to be paid for the leasing of the land sites purchased with Federal funds should be credited to the State Road Authorities for expenditure on the construction and maintenance of the National Highway.

(8) Yes. Although service centres as such were not envisaged at the time of the second reading speech for the National Roads Bill in 1974, the principles of improving road safety on the National Highway were paramount.

Implementing the development of service centres, rest areas and truck parking bays on the National Highway is in the interest of road safety to reduce driver fatigue by encouraging travellers to stop and rest frequently. The Federal Government has recently adopted a policy for the development of service centres along the National Highway. With regard to the establishment of the Glenrowan service centre, Victoria has complied with the Federal Government's guidelines for development of service centres.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to the Minister's announcement of the proposed reduction in manning levels for the Australian Defence Force (ADF) and the proposed increase in civilian and reserve participation in defence, (a) will the proposed changes reduce Australia's capacity to resist attack, (b) will Australia's ANZUS obligations to maintain an effective defensive force be compromised by the proposed changes, (c) will ADF personnel be guaranteed advantageous treatment should they apply for civilian positions within the restructured defence forces, (d) what criteria will be used to reduce the numbers of currently serving ADF personnel, other than through natural attrition, (e) will currently serving public servants have greater access to new civilian positions than currently serving ADF personnel and (f) what training programs will be implemented to ensure that civilian appointees attain a similar level of flexibility in skills to that of serving ADF personnel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) No. A key principle of the Force Structure Review was to maximise the combat capabilities of the Australian Defence Force.

(c) Section 33(1) of the Public Service Act requires that appointments to the Public Service be made on the basis of an assessment of the relative suitability of applicants having regard to the nature of the duties and the abilities, qualifications, experience, personal qualities and potential for development of each applicant that are relevant to the performance of those duties. Section 47A of the Public Service Act is a provision whereby a re- turned serviceperson is to be given preference when considered equal with another applicant following the normal merit selection process. It is not proposed to amend these provisions.

(d) Reductions in each Service will be achieved through a plan developed by the Chief of Staff. To provide the Chief of Staff with increased flexibility, some of the reductions may be achieved through redundancy measures. It is expected that redundancy measures will only be used when reduction in particular rank or skill categories are not being achieved through natural attrition. The overall numbers who may be given this option will be small. The redundancy procedures will recognise the need for consultation.

(e) Decisions on the terms of advertisements for positions created in the `civilianisation' process, ie. for a civilian to replace a serviceperson who was carrying out an administrative support function, will be decided on a case by case basis. This process is largely distinct from new positions created as a consequence of the rationalisation and down sizing of the existing civilian structure in the States. In the latter case, it is doubtful that the key criteria warranting opening the field to applicants outside the Australian Public Service will apply, i.e expected difficulty in obtaining a good field from within the APS or a known shortage of suitable people in a particular area or category of employment.

(f) Serving ADF personnel carrying out an administrative support function require military skills as well as those used in the administrative support function itself. In large part it is the additional requirement for creating and maintaining military skills which make it more expensive to use serving ADF members to perform these essentially civilian administrative support tasks. Hence, it is not the intention for civilian appointees to such positions to have a similar level of flexibility to ADF personnel. Training will, however, be provided as necessary to civilian appointees to enable them to carry out administrative support duties specific to their position.

It is the magazine of the Commission for the Future and replaces a previous Commission publication, `In Future', which was distributed free of charge to anyone who asked for a copy. The Commission changed from a free magazine to a subscription magazine in an effort to reduce annual publication costs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 5 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the annual (a) cost and (b) revenue generated by the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics' research vessel Rig Seismic.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Research Vessel, Rig Seismic, is the vehicle for the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics' Continental Margins Program - the program of regional geological mapping and petroleum and mineral resource assessment covering the 12 million square kilometres of Australia's offshore jurisdiction.

The Continental Margins Program is a key element in the Government's strategy to promote effective and efficient petroleum exploration around Australia. It does this by providing the geological base maps and concepts which allow industry to make informed assessments of exploration risk. Much of the activities of the program are aimed at increasing industry interest in so called `frontier' areas which are underexplored or unexplored. The program also generates the datasets (principally sediment thickness and bathymetric information) needed to support Australia's future claim to a `legal continental shelf' under the 1982 UN Convention on Law of the Sea.

Rig Seismic is a 1545 tonnes displacement vessel built in Norway in 1982 and was chartered and fitted out in 1984 in Australia for geoscientific research by the Bureau. It is registered in Newcastle, New South Wales, and is operated for the Bureau by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. The vessel is equipped with a modern seismic acquisition system, direct hydrocarbon detection capability, underway geophysical and echo sounding equipment and seabed rock and sediment sampling equipment.

Direct expenditure on the Continental Margins Program is expected to be $11.6 million in 1990- 91, of which $5.1 million is for the basic operation of the vessel, $3.4 million for operation and maintenance of shipboard scientific equipment, and $3.1 million for processing and analysis of data.
Direct revenue from sales of geoscientific data and reports was $210,000 in 1989-90 and is anticipated to be $250,000 in 1990-91.

In terms of indirect revenue, the program contributes significantly to petroleum exploration and development which in turn generates very substantial revenues for the Commonwealth amounting to some $1,300 million in 1989-90.

With the assistance of Government initiatives, such as the Continental Margins Program and a supportive taxation regime, the level of exploration offshore Australia is at an all time high. Analysis of the work program commitments of exploration companies in the period 1988-91 suggests that some $488 million of new petroleum exploration investment over that period has been dependent on or strongly linked to data, information and concepts generated by the Continental Margins Program.

Investigations which are related to the definition of Australia's `legal continental shelf' and for future seabed boundary negotiations with adjacent countries account for expenditure of $3.0 million per year and do not generate revenue.

External funding from industry for joint projects enables extension of the program and amounted to $250,000 in 1990-91. This is expected to increase substantially in 1991-92. The Bureau is also negotiating to contract out some unused capacity of the ship in 1991-92 which would generate additional revenue.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 20 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did an incident involving an East-West Airlines BaE 146 aircraft occur at or near Hamilton Island, Qld, on 31 December 1990; if so, (a) was the aircraft forced to `go around' allegedly because of windshear difficulties experienced on the southern approach of the Hamilton Island runway, (b) did the crew of the aircraft allegedly make a right turn procedure instead of the specified left turn procedure and (c) was the incident reported to civil aviation authorities; if so, when.
(2) What is the required reporting time to the relevant authorities of incidents such as that referred to in part (1).
(3) Should flight recorder information be made available to the civil aviation authorities and to Bureau of Air Safety investigators in circumstances such as those referred to in part (1) .
(4) If the incident referred to in part (1) did occur, was the information referred to in part (3) provided; if so, when; if not, why not.

(5) If the incident referred to in part (1) did occur, (a) what are the results of any investigation conducted so far and (b) has disciplinary action been taken, or will it be taken, against, (i) the crew and (ii) the company involved with respect to any noncompliance with the relevant regulations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I can confirm that an incident took place involving an EastWest BaE 146 aircraft during an approach to Hamilton Island on 31 December 1990.

(a) At the time the area was under the influence of a tropical cyclone, which had produced strong and gusty winds. The aircraft was approaching the island from the south-east, and the crew intended to carry out a right hand circuit for landing back towards the south-east. The aircraft broke out of the clouds in the vicinity of the aerodrome, but while manoeuvring for the landing heavy rain and low cloud was encountered, and the crew lost sight of the ground. A go around was carried out, in accordance with normal operating practices.

As the go around was commenced, wind shear causing a loss of altitude was detected, and the Ground Proximity Warning System activated. The pilot applied additional engine power, adopted a higher climb altitude than normal to correct the situation, and subsequently completed an uneventful landing.
(c) The incident was not reported to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI), which only became aware of the event a number of months later.

(2) Air Navigation Regulations require that an incident involving an Australian civil aircraft is to be reported to BASI within 48 hours of the occurrence. This requirement applies equally to both the pilot in command and the operator of the aircraft.
(3) BASI has access to flight data recorders for purposes of accident and incident investigation. This access is not available to the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA).

(4) No. Modern flight data recorders store information for the previous 25 hours of flight time. By the time this incident had come to the attention of BASI the aircraft had flown sufficient hours for the relevant information to have been over-written.

(5) (a) Both BASI and the CAA conducted independent investigations. These found that the crew had acted correctly under the circumstances of the incident. However, neither the crew nor the company complied with the requirements for prompt notification of the incident to BASI.

(b) Both BASI and the CAA have reminded the company and the crew of their obligations with respect to the reporting of incidents. The company has indicated that procedures have been put in place to prevent a repetition of this problem. No further action is considered to be necessary on this occasion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 21 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the existence of mystery swine disease or mystery reproductive syndrome in Canada and the USA.
(2) Has he initiated Departmental action to report on the underlying causes of the diseases referred to in part (1).
(3) Has his attention been drawn to the concern of the Australian Pork Producers Federation about the diseases.
(4) Will he cause the banning of importation of all pigmeats into Australia until the matter has been satisfactorily investigated; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) has commissioned a Working Group to report on this disease, which has been officially named Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome or PRRS. The Working Group's interim report has been circulated to other Government Departments and to industry for evaluation and comment.

(4) Three classes of pigmeat are presently allowed to be imported into Australia - canned pigmeat from many countries, uncooked pigmeat from the South Island of New Zealand and uncooked pigmeat from Canada. The canning process inactivates disease causing organisms and canned pigmeat is not considered a risk. PRRS has not been recognised in New Zealand and New Zealand product does not present a risk. PRRS or a disease similar to it is present in Canada but I am advised by AQIS that, on current information, the banning of uncooked pigmeat from Canada could not be justified on disease grounds. This is based on the fact that there is no evidence that the disease in Canada, is transmitted in pigmeat; the organisms believed by the Canadian officials to cause the disease are not carried in pigmeat; in fact no other country in the world has imposed restrictions on pigmeat due to concerns about this disease. AQIS met with industry organisations and other interested parties on 5 July and there was general consensus with AQIS' proposed course of action for pigmeat
and pig semen. Another meeting with industry is to be held on or before 8 August to review the situation.
